150137600.review:
It's always the same formula since the mid 90's: point and click mystery games. But it's still working, even better than it used to, as the puzzles generally gets less dull over time, from game to game.
This one is good: graphics, music, characters... dialogues in particular. Sometimes it can get a bit stereotypical (I read this in the comments). But what do you except? It's a 90's style of game set in the 90's. It's an homage.
I was really pleased with the Twin Peaks vibe overhaul, and even more with the Dark Seed turn near the ends.
If there is a "Kathy Rain 2" I would buy it (on discount, cause I'm poor, but I would buy it all the same).

> Boot it up and bam, hit with that sweet 90s pixel art like a nostalgia truck
> Kathy, our protagonist, is like if Nancy Drew rocked a leather jacket and a mean mullet

> Combine a rubber duck with a coffee pot and save the day, because why not

149234603.review: This is a superb game on many levels. The sense of mystery hooks you in very quickly and the story does a great job of not being overly predictable or cliched with a very strong finish. The characters are fun and interesting and feel real. Unlike so many other point-and-click games, the puzzles aren't overly hard and some of them (can't help but think of the hacking voice synthesis thing) are wonderfully creative. The art style is strong, with a very nostalgic 90's era feel. The sound and music are good. The dialogue is a lot of fun and makes the characters feel relatable. If you're looking for a point-and-click adventure game with a great storyline this is it! Thanks to everyone involved for creating something so cool. :)

148546104.review:
First thing first: Yeah this is a thumbs up review but you're probably better of looking into separate Director's Cut standalone, as it seems to address the flaws of this one.

Anyways, this is a pretty classic adventure where you play as young female journalism major in the 90s, reconnect with family after death of a relative, solving old town mysteries, and then it geometrically progresses into a Twin Peaks pastiche the moment story kicks into high gear.

It's not too long, atmosphere and style-wise it's fine and puzzles are mostly ok, some feel tedious but nothing genuinely obscure and confusing here, apart from finale embracing moon logic just a bit. It's all lovingly pixelled up in a very classic old adventure style which is endearing.

The less endearing bit is some clunkyness and slowness, not to mentioned forced retro resolution... was this made in Adventure Game Studio?! Another major complaint is that... while everything does congeal into a really nice personal arc of overcoming past and trauma for lead protagonist, it doesn't give much closer for many other characters you encounter and get to befriend over the brief period.

So yeah it's neat but consider Director's Cut which seems to both expand the story and epilogue and upgrades the game on the technical side.

147490855.review:
Keks- und knackig gesagt...

Kathy Rain ist ein "gutes altes" Spiel, das wie Nach-Hause-Kommen an einem verregneten, kalten Tag ist. Erstmal raus aus den nassen Klamotten, an den PC und vielleicht eine Tasse heiße Schokolade oder einen Keks... Es umfängt dich mit seiner Geschichte und den sympathischen Charakteren, die dich durch die Story tragen. Es ist wie ein Heimkommen zu Freunden... Die Länge ist angemessen und die Rätsel logisch knackig. Ich empfehle das Spiel im Sale zu kaufen.

Short and sweet said...

Kathy Rain is a "good old" game that is like coming home on a rainy, cold day. First, get out of your wet clothes, go to the PC and maybe have a cup of hot chocolate or a cookie... It surrounds you with its story and the likeable characters that carry you through the story. It's like coming home to friends... The length is appropriate and the puzzles are logically crisp. I recommend buying the game on sale.

Concerning the cookie...

Chocolate Pecan Caramels

Ingredients

    1 tablespoon plus 1 cup butter, softened, divided
    1-1/2 cups coarsely chopped pecans, toasted
    1 cup semisweet chocolate chips
    2 cups packed brown sugar
    1 cup light corn syrup
    1/4 cup water
    1 can (14 ounces) sweetened condensed milk
    2 teaspoons vanilla extract

Directions

Line a 13x9-in. pan with foil; butter the foil with 1 tablespoon butter. Sprinkle with pecans and chocolate chips; set aside.
In a heavy saucepan, melt remaining butter over medium heat. Add the brown sugar, corn syrup and water. Cook and stir until mixture comes to a boil. Stir in milk. Cook, stirring constantly, until a candy thermometer reads 248° (firm-ball stage).
Remove from heat and add vanilla. Pour into prepared pan (do not scrape saucepan). Cool completely before cutting.

145628136.review: Kathy Rain is a point-and-click adventure that presents a murder-mystery with a classic vibe. I was genuinely surprised how well this game was made and the voice acting got me totally hooked. The first 1.5 days were a bliss, and I was thinking I finally found a really good no-nonsense point-and-click adventure that is not a comedy. Unfortunately, the puzzles become more illogical as we progress. Additionally, there are esoteric and psychological elements that creep in and try to convince us there's more to the troubled past of the main protagonist than meets the eye. I suppose this is why I became a bit weary toward the end, even though I enjoyed the game and took my time. The game isn't long with an average playtime of 7.5 hours, give or take 2.5 hours. Nevertheless, I can recommended Kathy Rain for point-and-click adventure lovers but I would probably recommend getting the Kathy Rain: DC on sale instead.

143052826.review:
[h1]Kathy Rain[/h1]
es una aventura gráfica y Point & Click muy completa, para mí una [b]joya escondida[/b] (me atrapó desde el primer minuto de juego).

La historia gira en torno a las misteriosas circunstancias de la muerte del abuelo de Kathy Rain, la protagonista. Al principio el juego es todo lo que esperas; un juego de detectives en el que tienes que trabajar con Kathy para descubrir pistas y resolver misterios, al menos de eso trata durante una parte del juego. Después queda claro que no se trata de una ''simple historia de detectives'', si no que ocurre algo... Digamos... Extraño. El final del juego realmente me dejó confusa, hasta el punto de tener más preguntas que respuestas; en parte sentí que fue un tanto precipitado. A pesar de esto, disfruté mucho la historia.

El juego es precioso, tanto el estilo gráfico como sus efectos visuales. Su doblaje está completo y, en mi opinión, muy bien hecho. Y ni hablar de la banda sonora, que encaja a la perfección en cualquier escena. Los puzzles son bastante sencillos pero variados y coherentes. Valoré muchísimo que Kathy tuviera una frase para casi todo a lo que hagas clic, ya que soy el tipo de persona que mira por todos los rincones.

142594649.review:
I originally wanted to like this. The beginning half / two-thirds of the game was pretty neat. The puzzles were sometimes pretty novel, the mystery engaging, the characters pretty cool. But that last 1/3 ended up with bad pixel hunting and nearly-nonsensical puzzle solutions such as [spoiler] not being able to open the scarab with the notably sharp pen but instead opening the scarab with dropping a sharp metal cage onto it [/spoiler] or [spoiler] pulling the door off the hinges with the elevator. [/spoiler] The last part of the plot seemed to totally stumble over its own feet at the end. Seems the quality of the whole story and the puzzles shat the bed after [spoiler] you enter the sinkhole. [/spoiler] I feel the story didn't know how long to be and ends up overstaying its welcome...

Also, the [spoiler] abortion [/spoiler] plot thread being resolved as it was at the end was pretentious at best and horridly tasteless at worst. It was introduced during the [spoiler] dream between day 1 and 2 [/spoiler] and never touched upon until the very end when [spoiler] the protagonist apparently had guilt over the abortion she had as a teen, guilt that I had no idea she was suffering from until the very end when oh seems she DID have guilt or maybe even considered it an mistake! [/spoiler] Either the writer was trying to throw in a horribly heavy topic thinking they either could handle it or just that having such a heavy topic in their story makes it deep. I don't wish to point fingers or make assumptions, but I DEARLY hope that the writer [spoiler] actually has no condemnation of abortions. [/spoiler]

Overall, I was very disappointed. At the end I had a sigh over the last nonsensical puzzles and a wince over the bungled serious plot point. A serious skip. Buy a better point and click game...

142084946.review:
Underneath the supernatural point & click adventure, there are interwoven tales of loss and regrets.

Content warning for [spoiler]abortion[/spoiler], though it's handled sensitively (at least in the dialogue options I've picked).

[h1]The good:[/h1]
+ Beautiful pixel graphics
+ Very good voice acting
+ The point&click gameplay expected from the genre :)
+ Atmospheric music
+ Some dialogues are quite funny

[h1]Mixed:[/h1]
~ The story felt a bit wobbly, like multiple times it [i]just[/i] teetered on the edge of not making any sense, but in the end it always managed to not fall completely apart.
~ The puzzles had satisfying difficulty, but occasionally I was lost about where I was supposed to go next, so had to consult a guide.

[h1]The bad:[/h1]
- The characters felt one-dimensional, though this was somewhat attenuated by the good voice acting. The shallowness was especially noticeable with the protagonist, as we experience the entire game through her mind and actions.
- Also with the protagonist I feel they went overboard with "badassness" all the way to sociopathy. [spoiler]At one point she electrocutes someone who is doing her a favour, just to serve her own interests.[/spoiler]
- Some locations have intro+exit animations 20-30 seconds long, which is an annoyingly long time to wait around, when you're visiting them in quick succession while trying to figure out what to do next.

[h1]Final thoughts:[/h1]
If you like the genre, do play it! You probably know what to expect :)

139257555.review:
I was all set to give this a highly positive review after the first three hours. Solid voice acting, distinct characters, an engrossing story and puzzles which actually had some logic to them. The only nagging annoyance was a little bit of a mean-spirited aspect to some of the characterisation.

Then I went through the last couple of hours, and was left wondering what on earth went wrong. Characters behave nonsensically (or just disappear altogether), the main plot devolves into mumbo jumbo and heavy topics are superficially grazed over. The ending was so abrupt and unsatisfying that I thought I'd missed a section.

It feels unfinished at best, and it's especially frustrating as I was genuinely interested in where it was all going.

138671151.review:
I've tried to get into this game on 3 separate occasions now with a year of time inbetween each attempt and every single time it fails wholeheartedly to capture me in any way, each time after about 45 minutes to an hour it becomes a painful slog and I ALT+F4 because I cannot for the life of me be bothered.

I can't be bothered with the story, I can't be bothered with the actual gameplay, voice acting is great but story wise I dislike the main character, puzzles often do not follow logic making you want to use a walkthrough.

The Director's Cut re-release should be free for previous owners. It's a copy/paste of the same game except that some cut content was added back in.

135938373.review:
Kathy Rain es un jueguito indie de point and click que tiene unas vibras tremendas a Twin Peaks con una prota copada que tiene toda la onda, es medio ortiva y bien afilada; una historia con misterio y background de lo más interesante que me sorprendió gratamente. 
Cuando muere su abuelo Kathy vuelve al pueblito de su infancia para asistir al funeral y en este memory lane se toma como misión personal descubrir qué fue lo que le pasó al hombre unos buenos años atrás en el bosque que lo terminó dejando en una silla de ruedas. Ahí tenemos todo el factor de aventura gráfica con un poco de trabajo detectivesco amateur, buscar pistas. resolver pequeños puzzles y descubrir todo un entramado turbio que venía infectando este pueblito desde hace años. 
Me copó que la prota tenga sus buenos traumas porque la vuelve un personaje más real y complejo y eso se explota un montón a medida que vamos avanzando con la historia. No sé si terminarán haciendo una serie o una continuación del Kathy Rain pero que la piba tiene potencial y la historia estuvo muy buena no se puede negar.

Bien por Khaty Rain!, un juego tipo thriller, tenso y poco convencional con pistas perfectamente trazadas, sinceramente en el juego se siente esa sensación de estar investigando en su historia, por cierto una historia muy convincente a mi parecer en donde trabajar en sus últimos capítulos se convierte en algo más íntimo y adulto, y junto a juegos como the cat leady, downfall,lorelei o apocalipsis es uno de los mejores juegos point and click que he jugado.

Nuestra protagonista llamada kathy estudiante de periodismo, sarcástica, adicta a los cigarrillos y afinidad por las motocicletas con su estilo particular de chica grunge regresa a Conwell Springs para el funeral de su abuelo, quien murió en circunstancias sospechosas después de estar 10 años en estado vegetativo, luego de esta exposición inicial,kahty se encargara de resolver el misterio de la condición de su abuelo que la llevara a descubrir sucesos más profundos personales de la vida y pasado de ella , además el evento desvelara oscuros sucesos de la ciudad tejido por un suicidio de una adolescente en 1981.

El juego es una aventura de apuntar y hacer click retro, posee muchos diálogos y va lento, me refiero a que deberás prestar atención a los diálogos y observar tu entorno para la investigación, aunque no tiene nada preocupante y enroscado, tendrás que resolver como funcionan los acertijos y armar algunas combinaciones.
La narración es el fuerte del juego, con un personaje principal bastante carismático, sarcástico y duro, khaty no se endureció por casualidad, todo proviene de un lugar dañado, cubriendo algunas cicatrices y gran parte de la narrativa se preocupa por descubrir las razones de su naturaleza.
khaty rain en su totalidad es un juego pixel Art (son la clase de juegos que más amo y disfruto personalmente), por lo que gran parte del viaje se tratara de buscar pistas, como nombres, direcciones o números de teléfono y anotarlos en una libreta pequeña que guardamos en nuestra mochila, así como también fotos, disquetes de computadoras y demás accesorios, para usarlos con las personas o el entorno para recopilar más pistas que nos hagan avanzar, los sprites de los personajes son bien detallados los escenarios son bien trabajados y, a veces increíblemente hermosos, la música es misteriosa e intensa como para coincidir el estado de ánimo de la narración, mientras que las voces son acertadas especialmente la de khaty <3

El juego es fascinante, la historia, las voces, las actuaciones son bastante espléndidas, pero como dije el juego es lento, se ajusta perfectamente al arquetipo clásico de apuntar y hacer click, no está centrado en la acción directa, así que es recomendable para aquellos que les guste leer mucho, se sumerjan en lo narrativo, las historias profunda y adultas sobre el dolor, la transición, la religión y las decisiones personales que nos construyen o nos destruyen...

125852806.review:
Algunas Aventuras gráficas siempre fueron una especie de trampolín, que me sirvieron para transportarme a la pre adolescencia y esto mismo sentí al terminar Kathy Rain, un point and click dentro de todo moderno, pero que mantiene la esencia de aquella época dorada, donde este tipo de juegos eran moneda corriente

La historia nos sitúa 1995, en la piel de Kathy Rain, una estudiante de periodismo que recibe la triste noticia de que su abuelo ha fallecido, por lo que decide volver a su pueblo de la infancia (Conwell Springs) para participar del entierro. 

A medida que van pasando las primeras charlas, entendemos que el abuelo de Kathy fue ex piloto del ejército, que sufrió un accidente (poco claro) el cual lo dejó en estado vegetativo durante sus últimos 14 años. Kathy encuentra unos documentos y grabaciones de su abuelo, en el que el mismo se encontraba investigando un caso sobre el suicidio de una chica del mismo pueblo.

A partir de este punto, no solo nos comprometemos en averiguar que fue lo que realmente le ocurrio a nuestro abuelo, sino que tambien vamos encontrando puntos de conexión con dicho suicidio 

En términos de jugabilidad, tendremos el clásico menú de mirar, agarrar, pensar para relacionarnos con el entorno, un inventario de objetos, y el agregado de una libreta, donde Kathy irá anotando tanto los pasos a seguir, como la información relevante.
Para desplazarnos por los distintos escenarios, se nos mostrará una animación, donde se la ve a Kathy en su moto y las distintas ubicaciones disponibles.

Actualmente hay 2 versiones disponibles del juego, kathy rain a detective is born (original 2016) y la versión Director's Cut (2021), la cual incluye la historia ampliada con algunas localizaciones nuevas y más puzzles para resolver.

Realmente merece la pena darle una oportunidad y si lees esto y aun no compraste el juego, te recomiendo que vayas por la version mas nueva.

125129557.review:
[h1]Kathy Rain - A detective with a rebellious but warm heart and a big brain[/h1]

I will start this by mentioning, i really am not into point-and-click games. and the last 6-7 years, not into puzzles anymore, however, i am trying to learn to love new game genres.
Because of that, my opinion should be taken with a grain of salt (or, drop of water, if you will).

Since i am not used to Point-and-Click games, i did find some parts of the game boring (i felt like some dialogues were longer than necessary for example), and the animation/movement weren't so quick and smooth as i would've liked.

I did get stuck few times, and i am not ashamed to admit but i had to use a walkthrough, i suppose if you're a connoisseur of this type of games, you won't have the same issue, as the stuff you have to do in the game does make sense, but my brain couldn't really make the connecions.

I liked the story and dialogues, they were a healhy balance between creepy, funny and trippy.
Voice acting was good, except for a character's (actor was talking too close to the microphone i suppose. However that was only one occurence, apart from it, the game is profesionally made).

Style/design-wise, it reminds me of Phantasmagoria, if you're familiar with it, a point-and-click from 1995.

It was a decent experience, and it would've been cool if the game had a short-film at least, made after it.

soft recommend for a point-and-click junkie, with the assumption that the director's cut version of the game is probably the better buy.

decent point-and-click for a lazy afternoon. not super challenging but it fortunately avoids being absurdly obtuse as well. the story felt like it was on fast-forward for me, especially in the second half of the game, as new people and things were coming and going at what felt like a blistering pace. my understanding is the director's cut fleshes some things out with extra dialogue and locations. the game's art style is solid, most closely resembling the wadjet eye games or what i would assume a 32-bit lucasarts indiana jones adventure game might look like. i did find myself thinking that the art style was kind of bland and wasn't totally doing it for me; i think i just prefer a more stylized approach to the art in point-and-click games, like day of the tentacle or monkey island, which is kind of unfair to compare any game to, especially when kathy rain's visuals were clearly done by a talented artist. characters were fine but i didn't particularly find myself really liking anyone.

recommended on sale to those who are looking for a basic, easier, shorter adventure game- but buy the director's cut instead for what i think is the same price as this.

116127995.review:
Kathy Rain joins the slew of 90s point and click throwback games, following very closely in the tradition of the look and feel of the SCUMM engine. Taking particular tonal, story, and thematic influence from Gabriel Knight, Broken Sword, along with subtle nods to Full Throttle, Kathy Rain tells the story of a family mystery surrounding the disappearance of the protagonist's grandfather. The setting of the very mature story is very intimate by taking place in a small rural community which adds to the story's haunting atmosphere. Additionally, the low-fi synth infused Darkseed style soundtrack further enriches the environment with its 70s radiophonic tinge. 

Much like its visuals, the gameplay of Kathy Rain is very faithful to the 1990s point and click adventure games by offering puzzles, combining of items within the inventory, and character conversations. All of the games technical elements (gameplay, soundtrack, and look) mostly adhere to its retro premise with success. The lesser elements of Kathy Rain are to be found in the hit and miss voice acting, some repetition in the gameplay, and a disappointing plot development and resolution in its final chapter. The final chapter does suspend belief in its logic, reveal, and overall resolution of the story. But, Kathy is a very likeable protagonist while the throwback to 90s pop culture was well handled by avoiding a Stranger Things style of hammering of the premise. 

A solid game, with potential to develop into a series. Although the story does take some disappointing, not to mention sudden turns that raise more questions than answers, Kathy Rain is a very solid point and click. 

3.5 out of 5

The story is compelling, but I felt that some of the heavier themes were not handled properly. Using and showing mental health and other real problems just for shock value is cheap and harmful. There was often not enough time to process the emotional aspects of what was happening, which made things feel a bit rushed. A few of the puzzles were a bit too complicated, and there was some frustrating running between locations, performing a single task at each, but other than that, it was a pretty smooth experience. All in all, I did enjoy the game and would recommend it to people who feel nostalgic about the 90's and like detective/thriller stories. A word of caution, though: it does contain many triggers.

114254613.review:
If you've played point-and-click adventure games, you know the routine: exploration, inventory puzzles, and hopefully an interesting story along the way. Kathy Rain mostly succeeds on those counts.

The basic story is you're the titular character, and come back to your hometown after your grandfather dies, reconnecting with your grandmother. But not all is as it seems. Something odd happened to your grandpa years ago, and it's up to you to figure out exactly what it was.

The game takes place over the course of five days. The early going is pretty good, as you feel like you're doing legitimate detective work to track down information and people. But around day four, the tone of the game changes, and it becomes more of a supernatural horror game, to its detriment. The story, which starts out strong and intriguing, gets a little muddled, and while the game was never exactly bad, it wasn't as satisfying as it could have been.

The puzzles were mostly sensible and interesting. I only had to look up answers on one or two occasions, although I got slightly frustrated once or twice as well. Overall though, it was fun to figure things out.

Despite my complaints, this is definitely worth playing if you enjoy the genre. It's better than some of the other games published by Wadjet Eye without a doubt.

However the puzzles are very easy and answers are pretty much given away at points. This for me takes away a lot of the enjoyment I find in this genre. Sure some of the 90s originals were cryptic to the point of tedium but this swings too far the other-way.

106833945.review:
El juego se trata de Kathy una joven estudiante universitaria que, después de que su abuelo falleciera, vuelve a el pueblo donde nació después de años sin poner un pie ahí, encontrándose con su abuela, quien le cuenta que su abuelo ya no era el mismo desde un incidente hace tiempo, quedando así envuelta en un misterio ¿Qué le paso realmente a su abuelo? ¿Ella podrá descubrirlo o será un misterio por siempre? Bueno de eso se trata el juego, con un estilo muy noventero Kathy Rain nos pone en la piel de esta detective dispuesta a llegar a las últimas consecuencias para comprender el pasado de su abuelo en un pueblo donde nadie es lo que parece y donde el misterio está tocado por un surrealismo fantástico que de alguna extraña manera cierra muy bien la historia.  
IMPORTANTE si no te gusta el surrealismo no compres el juego, ya que lentamente el juego va entrando en él hasta sumergirse completamente, para mi es esto lo que le da el toque de gloria
Pd: cuando lo termine me dejo queriendo más, por cuestiones totalmente subjetivas.

There are only two things I personally disliked about it but they do not take away from the game itself, which are spoilers:
1. [spoiler]I have yet to play a video game that properly represents Christianity or Christians, which itself is common throughout the world and media. However when it comes to a mystery game, the trope of "seeming good religious person is actually evil" is just very overdone. It's not [i]bad[/i] so much as it's predictable and I personally wish it was less so, or atleast far less obvious hahah.[/spoiler]
2. [spoiler]As the game goes on it starts to lose itself a little or feel like it goes off the rails a bit. Very minor, but I mean it in the sense that as you begin to climax you are of course going to get a lot of exposition quickly so games will have crazy things taking place. However when finishing the game it leaves a couple of questions left unanswered, or questions that would be nice to answer. 

You can understand the story and infer enough, but it might be a case of the developer wanting the interpretation to be up to the player or left a mystery which in this case is fine. I wanted to like this game but in the end I was left a bit disappointed. I liked the graphics and music, as well as the overall vibe, but those couldn't really save the game for me.

Sometimes I also felt like it was very unclear what I was supposed to do. All of that could be overlooked, but most of all I didn't like the plot.

I didn't actively hate playing the game, but wouldn't recommend anyone buy it either.

99587959.review:
Awkward tonal shifts and a laundry list of pop psychology name-dropped and left unexplored turn this game's initially decent detective story into an amateurish mess.

A funny sassy biker girl coed decides to uncover the mystery of her grandpa's strange death, with a tinge of the supernatural. Well, instead of what happened to grandpa she learns that [spoiler]the local priest is a cult leader, the depressed artist tricked her mentally retarded brother into strangling/drowning her, grandpa had PTSD and was an abusive husband and parent, the protagonist's own dad was in a biker gang, her mother is committed to a mental asylum, and, incidentally, the protagonist herself was pregnant as a teen so we even get to see a ghost of her unborn child being rude to her[/spoiler]. So what? So nothing: [spoiler]the protagonist has a horror-themed mystical experience where she confronts a doppelganger (no joke) whom she tells that nuh-uh she don't hate her daddy [i]that[/i] much, which immediately solves the matter. The mystery actually is that there are hallucinogenic flowers growing in the forest[/spoiler]. This incorrigible silliness was not worth the six hours of my life.

Adventure gameplay is alright, albeit barebones. Most puzzles are simple but fine. One single puzzle is actually stupendously hard... but the protagonist handholds you through it, stopping you whenever you're about to make a mistake. What the heck was that, game designer? That was just weird.

Voice acting was admittedly good.

I have to confess I  first HATED this game because I wasn't in the right mindset for it.

98744459.review:
While I enjoyed most of the game, I think it started to drag a bit towards the end, and a lot of stuff was open-ended. The ending failed to leave and impact on me; I was expecting something deeper, more interesting from a philosophical standpoint (and it really seemed like it was headed that way for the most part, it just failed to deliver). Also, I was expecting the main character to grow a bit more. It's like the growth is supposedly there, but at the same time you don't really see the character change in any significant way. You don't see any sort of emotional consequence on her, you just see the process she supposedly went through. I think you actually see more of a change on ||E, the "sidekick" according to the game||, but it also could have been shown in a deeper way (e.g. ||have her views on religion changed at all after what she went through?||). Many of these plot points could potentially be explored in a sequel, but since there were no original plans to make one, nor have they been announced since then, I can't judge it for what it could become, but for what it is now. There are also a few messages that are at the very least questionable from an ethical stand point, and some violent scenes that are pretty much gratuitous and could have been avoided. And so, in spite of the good voice-acting, and the addictive story, I think the game ultimately failed to deliver what it could have, and so I can't truly recommend it (these weren't the only reasons, but I think they are the most relevant for prospective buyers to know).

P.D.: I also encountered an audio bug I couldn't fix. I use my TV as a monitor to play games, and I couldn't get the sound to work on this one. After several tries at fixing it, reading about it and trying everything anyone suggested and anything I could thing of, I ended up using my normal speakers because there was no other way to get it to work. I did lose at least an hour trying to set it all up.

96726101.review:
Kathy Rain is a fun, suspenseful point-and-click game that succeeds in being exactly what it wants to be: a solid detective story that dips its feet in some Twilight Zone-esque strangeness. It surpasses expectations, makes no excuses and captures your attention – nothing more, nothing less. In other words, it's a good time and a safe bet.

But what does it do differently? Well, firstly, it's well-balanced without being boring. When having supernatural elements, I think there is a risk for a story to either be overwhelmed by it or not doing enough with it. It's easy for one element to get lost when realising the concept. Kathy Rain avoids this, managing to have a focus on the detective/mystery mechanics while having the supernatural lend weight to the story. It's good craftmanship, something that isn't praised enough in general.

Secondly, this game has very good pacing. The tempo is good, never loses focus but still finds time for both light-heartedness and gravitas when needed. As a character, Kathy Rain gets straight to the point in all of her interactions and it reflects in how the story flows. It's entertaining, as simple as that. It doesn't exactly play your heartstrings like a fiddle, to be fair, but it's not without impact either. Good, not great, but that's far from a bad thing.

If you would ask me the one thing that would be my takeaway, however, I would bring attention to the way that the characters are designed. While Kathy herself is pretty damn good as a character, the people around her aren't exactly deep. More deep puddles than vast oceans, if you catch my meaning. With that said, what they do have is, well, [b]character[/b]. In reality, one does not have to show a lot of depth to be interesting, no matter what writing schools and/or literature critics might want to tell you. A little is most often enough, which is something Kathy Rain grasps very well. There are stereotypes in this game, but they avoid being harmful and instead make the characters have edge, adding colour to the picture without making it garish. It's Kathy Rain's best quality, in my opinion, and something I personally learned from.

Kathy Rain isn't a game that you should play. It's not a game I would expect to see in any top 10 lists or anything like that. Nonetheless, it's an easy game to recommend, simply because it does everything it promises and more. In the end, it makes for a satisfying game. What more can you expect?

96600127.review:
Kathy Rain es un indie-aventura grafica-point and click en el que debemos guiar a una joven estudiante de periodismo a investigar sucesos extraños ocurridos en su pueblo natal. Como primer conflicto debemos lidiar con el misterioso fallecimiento del abuelo y averiguar porque algunas personas del lugar estan entrando en una especie de locura.

Puntos Positivos:

+ La historia es muy interesante
+ El arte pixel esta muy bien
+ Personajes secundarios y lineas de dialogos, justos pero correctos
+ La duracion media de este point and click es de 5 horas

Puntos Negativos:

- Algunos puzzles o puntos son un tanto engorrosos

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Kathy Rain es un buen point and click, una historia interesante y puede ser terminada en una tarde. Muy caro para su precio base, es mejor aguantarse a las ofertas.

96381650.review: Well, this started as a feminist themed pixel point&click adventure. It all the usual tropes, strong girl, but her room is sloopy, implied lesbian relationships, drives a heavy motor bike, chain smoker, troubled family background, has had an life ending inside her experience. All the usual signs of a woke game that make me stop gaming, BUT for some reason I stuck with it. Maybe because the game goes the extra mile to show how the main character, Kathy, is damaged and is not a role model to look up to. Anyway, if you stick with the game, you will be rewarded with well written dialogue between Kathy and her straight christian roommate and other supporting characters. There are a lot of strong men portrayed in this game and although Kathy really does go toe to toe with some of them, it's not in a way that demeans them. The game doesn't go out of it's way to make Kathy overpowered nor the men whiny little weaklings. Voice acting is good, you won't be skipping the voice lines for some of the more important story dialogue. All in all, if you like old 2D pixel point&click adventure then I would definitely recommend this.

96378704.review:
An excellent point and click adventure puzzler that will feel right at home with players familiar with the Lucasarts point and click titles.

Kathy Rain, despite its initially dull and seemingly drab setting and opening, unfolds its wings rather quickly and pulls the player in with its captivating story and colourful, vibrant characters, each one a different taste from the rest. 
Unlike many of the other reviewers, I did not really have a problem with [spoiler]the story taking a turn into the supernatural territory.[/spoiler]
I think it twisted the story in an intriguing manner that made for some very tastefully disturbing scenes that enhanced the narrative overall.

The puzzles are fairly reasonable and you can interact with many objects that sometimes give an amusing response from the sassy lead or other characters around her.

95922959.review:
This game surprised me in a number of ways.  First off, I was not convined the "badass motorcycle riding leather jacket wearing 90's chick" could be pulled of without feeling extremely cringey.  I'm happy to report that not only did they make her feel more grounded and realistic than I thought, she was a delight of a main character with a well fleshed out backstory.  Her character is definitely what held this game together.

I was also not expecting the game to first dabble in and then fully dive in to the [spoiler]supernatural[/spoiler] the way it did.  To be honest, I preferred the earlier parts of the game that worked more as a burgeoning detective/investigative journalists origin story than what came later, but I will admit there was some pretty cool moments and imagery later in the game.

For a first time release, this was really an excellent showing and I'm interested to see what else this dev can make.

95660621.review: The story is super good and the puzzles aren't too hard to figure out. Would recommend to anyone who is into story-based games.

95645912.review:
The game is set in 1995, and it feels very 1995.
But in a good way!

Playing the game, gives me very nostalgic vibes of playing LucasArts 1990s games.
I feel like playing the LucasArts' Indiana Jones games for the very first time...
And I like it!

But it also comes with the drawbacks of the 1990s adventure games.
Namely: backtracking. And lots of it.
As games needed to be minimalistic back then, there was a lost of re-use of locations. So you basically did different missions on the same set of locations, going back-and-forth between locations. Which also prolonged the game time (you both needed to find the right location, which took time. And the travel between locations took time too).
So Kathy Rain is not a bad as 1990s games were at this, but there is definitely some backtracking, and looking for the correct location to continue the story.

I must admit I was somewhat disappointed by the ending.
It was complete nonsense to me, and very much underwhelming.
I expected some kind of explanation and maybe a surprise reveal.
But instead got nonsensical rambling, and a corny ending.

But overall it is a good game.
I would give it 7/10.
8/10 if you're a 1990s adventure games fan.

95627405.review:
I hated every second I had to listen to the insufferable prick of a protagonist vomiting their bad attitude and treating everyone around them like they were nothing. 

I begrudgingly recommend this game, every fibre in my bones screams to down vote it. But I enjoyed it. I enjoyed it despite the protagonist.


Pros:
The game is a massive nostalgia trip with almost every other line of dialogue including an old school adventure reference. And it’s glorious.
The voice acting and casting is expertly done. Everyone is believable and seems to be enjoying and enthusiastic about their roles.
The mood and setting of the game is fantastic, the old school pixel art has been done extremely well and is strongly reminiscent of actual 90’s adventure games.
The puzzles are very well done. I’d say they lean towards overly simple, but at the same time they fit the theme and are laid out in such a way as to keep the pace of the game going with almost no points where you have to resort to rubbing things on other things. 

Cons:
I hate the protagonist. She’s an abuser, physically and psychologically, and proud of it. She’d petty, vindictive, cruel, and her veneer of ‘reasons’ are nothing more than excuses to continue to choose to act in a disgusting way and her vile behaviour begins right out of the gate. (Which I guess means she was very well written.)
The story goes weird. It starts out as an intriguing mystery but it feels like the writer was getting progressively more baked as the game goes on. This could easily be a positive too, the signs are all there foreshadowing from the start. It just feels a bit out. I’d have liked some ambiguity.
The game goes out of its way to investigate trauma later on in a particularly uninspired way. The protagonist seems insincere at every point of the experience, though that could be my extreme dislike of them speaking.

Suggested improvements:
Apparently there is a remake/extended edition on the horizon for this game. Hopefully they develop everything a little more without killing pace. I would be interested in knowing more about literally everyone one of the side characters. 
There is ample room here for some side plots intertwined with the main story, and even some optional bits that aren’t. (Dave vs Clyde, More about the base and gramp’s history, etc.)

I think closing off areas the player doesn’t need to go to was a nice idea, but for me it detracted from red herrings I’d created for myself. I’d reopen those places and allow the player to roam, but I acknowledge that runs the risk of damaging the snappy pacing of the game. 

Overall recommendation:
Overall I recommend this game. It isn’t an old school adventure, but it’s a damn good tribute. I suspect most people will actually enjoy it more than me because they won’t hate the protagonist. So I give it a thumbs up, even if I don’t particularly want to.

95626164.review:
When Kathy Rain’s grandfather dies, the sassy, devil-may-care student reluctantly returns to her hometown for the funeral. There’s not much in the way of happy memories for Kathy here; her father disappeared when she was young and she was forced to commit her own mother to an asylum.

True to Kathy's recollection of Conwell Springs, the town's harbouring plenty dark shadows. So when it quickly becomes apparent there was more to her grandfather’s death than meets the eye, Kathy starts an investigation of her own – asking questions that lead to increasingly disturbing answers.

It took a little while for [i]Kathy Rain[/i] to hook me. The premise felt a bit banal, the characters quiet, the setting soft. It openly invites comparisons to the superlative [i]Twin Peaks[/i], but Joseph Rain’s passing has none of the impact Laura Palmer’s brutal murder had (although it's probably asking a little too much of a point and click to echo the nightmares of David Lynch).

But stick around Conwell Springs long enough and you’ll find a game that’s not afraid to tackle big themes (not always gracefully, but at least directly) - and with a surreal twist of its own. The more Kathy digs, the darker the town becomes, forcing her to confront multiple of her own traumas. It’s potent adventure game stuff, with well-written lines spoken by rather good voice actors.

There’s a director’s cut coming, but my hope is for many more adventures with Kathy and her unlikely sidekick Eileen – a pious but savvy college roommate. Apparently it didn’t make mega bucks (whatever that’s meant to look like for a game of this sort), but thankfully publisher Raw Fury are committed to supporting the developer’s future.

In the meantime, you should do your part and buy the game. It's very good.

95617311.review: Amazing game, thank you to everyone who worked on it. I loved everything; the music, the voice acting, the art, the story, it was all so well done! A perfect point and click puzzle game that really scratches a specific itch.

95248202.review: Great mystery! Never got boring or tedious; Always something exciting to try and uncover

95210936.review:
This was in a bundle of games Steam recommended based on other games I've played. Despite it coming out a few years ago, I'd never heard of it before, which is annoying, because it was excellent! I don't believe I've ever posted a review for a game before, even games that I've spent hundreds to thousands of hours on, so that should tell you how much I enjoyed 'Kathy Rain'! This will be a spoiler-free review. Something I want to say straight away is that a director's cut of the game will be released soon, so rather than buying this version of the game, you should wait and buy that to get what I assume will be the best possible experience!

The story was so much fun - I LOVED the setting and all the different characters. I was a little worried in the beginning that I'd ended up purchasing a Chick tract in the form of a game, but thankfully, this turned out not to be the case! I like Kathy a lot, although her 'I'm not most girls' line straight up left me cringing; I understand she's meant to be a tough-talking, leather-jacket wearing cool rebel type, but... come on lmao. She can be all those things without resorting to that - and both her story and personality are so interesting that that kind of worn-out cliche risks weakening what is a genuinely solid, funny, likeable character whom I really connected with. Arielle Siegel, who voices Kathy, did a fantastic job and I'm delighted to hear that she's returning for the director's cut version of the game.

Honestly, the voice actors really make this game, which I'm not writing to diminish the strength of the story, but to emphasise how great they are! The whole voice cast really knocked it out of the park, and I was tickled pink by Goober! The characters are very well-written, although I was left with the feeling of wanting a little bit more. However, given that Kathy's running around trying to solve this mystery over the course of a few days, I do understand that she wouldn't exactly be standing around trying to get every single person's life story! So that's not really a criticism, more a testament to how interesting and well-written the characters were. There were a few moments during the game where the English seemed a bit off and it seemed something had been written (or perhaps translated?) inaccurately - but by 'a few', I really do mean that - no more than two or three times, and it didn't affect my understanding of what was being said. 

I thought the story was highly enjoyable and enjoyed the classic sci-fi-esque vibes. There are a bunch of different references to various other works in the game, and the creators make their influences pretty clear, but the story is by no means derivative or unoriginal. You'll recognise a lot of narrative tropes and character archetypes, however, they're very well done and so feel nostalgic and not remotely dull. The 90s setting was very cool - the last time I saw a floppy disk in any setting must have been over 15 years ago, so all of that older tech made me oddly sentimental.

I didn't find most of the puzzles difficult other than the very early one in the attic (which I needlessly over-complicated for myself and had to look up - it's actually so simple that you, like me, will think you've missed something major: you haven't!), and the one involving the poem. I don't think there's any shame at all in looking any of the solutions up, especially if it's been a while and you're getting frustrated; games are supposed to be fun, after all! That being said, please don't use a walk-through: the game is a lot of fun and the story is fantastic, it would be a shame to spoil them.

The art style is lovely! I feel like the lighting was especially well done - whether it was sunlight coming in through blinds in a window or coming from a lamp, I was struck by how good it looked and it's clear that a lot of care and attention to detail was paid to making it all look just right. I also really loved the soundtrack. In fact, it reminded me a lot of the game 'Bully', though the themes of these two games are worlds apart! 

With regards to the ending, I agree with 'purpledragon42' that it's evident early on that the story is going somewhere weird, haha. I really wasn't expecting how it turned out though, and I'm guessing there's a lot more to come, not just from the director's cut, but from possible sequels or perhaps games set in the same universe. The ending makes it very clear that 'it's not over yet',  and there seemed to be a lot more lore/world-building than you might expect for this kind of game. I noticed other reviewers felt that there were a lot of unanswered questions etc, and I do agree with that, but I think my reasoning above is why the game is like that. So I'm excited to see what happens in the future! 

All in all, I'd give 'Kathy Rain' a solid 8 or even 9 out of 10! It was hugely enjoyable and the ending was very touching and meaningful. As I wrote at the beginning, I'd recommend waiting until the director's cut comes out before spending any money, but I am definitely going to be purchasing that myself and am looking forward to its release!

95027473.review: a specimen of a standard-issue, old-school, VGA point-and-click of early 1990s ... no hard puzzles, no frustrating pixel-hunting, a moderately interesting story... I liked it :)

94856001.review:
This game has good pixel graphics. I like the small-town vibes, and I can almost smell the petrichor through the screen. I really like the nostalgic ambience which was further enhanced by the sound effects.  I must have clicked on everything that could be interacted with because I enjoyed the cultural references. 

This game reminds me of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/merrychristmasknight/recommended/1220930][b]Metaphobia[/b][/url]. Their stories and themes are also quite similar. They both have pretty good voice acting: some characters who sound different also turned out to be voiced by the same people! If you don't count the 2 hours where I fell asleep while stuck on a puzzle in Metaphobia, I actually have similar playtimes for both games. I did find Metaphobia's puzzles more challenging.

Going back to [b]Kathy Rain[/b], I have two technical problems with this game. The first one is with the volume and speech box. Whenever I load a save file, the master volume goes all the way up, and the speech box becomes unchecked. The second one is the lack of a scroll bar for the saves. I saved many times through the course of this game (even though it was probably unnecessary), but there wasn't a bar to indicate whether I was in the middle of my save files or at the end. These aren't a big deal, but I think they could be improved, especially in the upcoming [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1395030/Kathy_Rain_Directors_Cut/][b]Director's Cut[/b][/url]. 

These technical issues aren't necessarily dealbreakers, so why am I not recommending this game? 
[list]
[*]I find the protagonist very unrelatable. I know this is personal preference, but in every game, I hope to at least be able to relate to the main character on some level. I can understand where she's coming from, and I can see where some of the humour comes from, but it's just not my style of humour and not my preference to choose between bad, worse, and worst for her dialogue options. 
[*]While I liked some of the Easter egg achievements, I found that some of them were not in good taste. Again, I know this is a personal preference. I considered listing some of them out here, but I'll refrain from doing so since some of them are hidden achievements. 
[*]I agree with [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198145439976/recommended/370910/]another reviewer[/url] who said that this is more of a sentimental, coming-of-age story with supernatural vibes. The way this story was set up, Kathy didn't seem to be on her path to becoming a detective. Her roommate Eileen seemed more like it to me. My favourite characters in this game were probably Eileen and Goober.
[/list] 

From my experience with this game, I think it's highly unlikely that I'll check out the Director's Cut when it's released. I know it will be available at a good discount for those who own this game, but getting this at a deep discount (80% off for 2.99 USD) doesn't alleviate my issues with the game's achievements, dialogue options, and not-quite-detective story. That is not to say that I didn't enjoy this game at all. There were parts that I enjoyed, but I'm not recommending this due to my personal preference. I do appreciate the developer's engagement in the forums and that they're creating a new game to hopefully give a more satisfying ending, so I'm not completely closing the door to trying out the Director's Cut someday. However, it's a no for me at this time.

94342460.review:
It pains me to give this game a negative review. Kathy Rain, when it came out, got me back into point-and-click adventure games, after years and years of not touching one.

So let me list the things this game does right: It has a charming enough main character, that is full of late 90s flavour - that's not for everyone, but it sure as hell is for me. It starts right off with a decent mystery, has resonable voice acting, good art, and a solid old-school gameplay. The puzzles are also really darn good, there's no moon logic, except for that time you need to tase discount Phill Colins (mostly because up until that point, you never did any action even remotely similar to it, and I wasn't even aware I could do it).

The bad: Somewhere at around 1/3rd of the game, it switches into being X-Files lite, and it goes quickly downhill from there. Instead of exploring a story of human tragedy, or tragedies, the writers decided to take this into supernatural lovecraftian territory. Now, this decision seems to me like they thought this would allow them to create a deeper story, and explore the undertones more effectively, but it feels rather cheap and poorly thought out. Here's how poorly they handled this: if you're going to do narrative interpretation, you can easily read this as a really dumb anti-drug game, or something so much worse. But I don't think this reading is their intent at all, they really screwed up.

Let's see if the director's cut salvages this game, or just makes everything worse.

It's a pity, because if the story kept both its feet on the ground, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game. And it was not impossible to do so, even the weird things could be explained logically, but it seemed like the developers gave up on the narration half way through. Welp.

Kathy Rain es una aventura gráfica que recuerda a las mejores ideas de Sierra o LucasArts, con una visual de los noventa perfectamente conseguida. La historia gira en torno a la misteriosa muerte del abuelo de la protagonista entrelazado con situaciones personales que la llevaron a ser lo que es. 92530708.review:
A lot of the time grounded point-and-click games like these that try to avoid getting too cartoony with the mechanics end up feeling pretty boring. Kathy Rain does a good job of avoiding that by using a notebook system and other event-specific gameplay elements (listening to tapes, using computers etc.) to pivot you towards interacting with the world in a more realistic way, which felt really natural to me. The downside of this is that the puzzles end up being pretty easy but because Kathy Rain's story was paced so well, just playing through it was satisfying enough without needing massively challenging puzzles to keep my interest. Although the story isn't anything mind-blowingly clever or original, it's told very well and the way the puzzles are interspersed and the twists and turns are revealed is pretty much perfect. It gets a bit sloppier towards the end (pretty common problem with point-and-clicks, which struggle a bit with action and tension) but overall very engaging.

My only major complaint is the character art. It's all fine and well animated enough but the designs themselves felt pretty uninspired. The game is set in the 90s but there's very little in the fashion or aesthetics that give that impression and a lot of the characters just look kind of generic. Definitely not enough to ruin the game for me though.

92242185.review: Very good and catching story, interesting characters that develop quite naturally over the course of the game. Relatively easy and logical puzzles without too much going headlessly back and forth between locations. Cool popular culture references (anno 1995).

92238597.review:
tl;dr As it is now, I would probably give it a 6 out of 10, decent game for fans of weird mysteries, but you won't miss out on much.

Kathy Rain is a point-and-click adventure mystery game that takes place in small town Americana in the 90's. Its story takes place over the course of five days, during which you uncover the mystery of an incident involving your grandfather and the people he knew. This game draws quite heavily from the famous 90's TV show "Twin Peaks", by David Lynch & Mark Frost, and features many parallels and direct references to it. By the end of the game, I'd argue maybe it draws too much.

I think I got this game for free from some other website a year or two back. I was interested in it exactly because of the above connection to Twin Peaks, which I am a big fan of. Just when I decided to play the game I saw news that there would be a new edition of this game coming out, so I was unsure if I should have waited or not. But I figure that the game has been out for 5 years now and that's fair enough to just enjoy it for what it is.

The game took me about 6 hours to complete and I missed just one achievement. To gripe about that real quick, the very first achievement in the game rewards you by saying "You missed the funeral". Most people playing will probably get this one as soon as they start playing it, and it concerned me because it led me to believe you can miss events in this game, or that there was some sort of day-night cycle I would have to play around. I looked into it briefly and the achievement lies to you really, it's just triggered by inspecting a set number of items in the first room in the game. Don't worry about getting into this and feeling like you will miss out if you play it your way.

Point-and-click adventures aren't usually my genre, but I've always been interested in them. I haven't played enough personally to hold this up to others. It seems like pretty standard fare, however. 99% of the objects you inspect or interact with are meaningless. Click on a lamp? "It's a lamp," You have a lot of options to interact with things, only for Kathy to say "No, I don't want to". There were many instances of inspecting photos and paintings, but there were no close-up models of these made. I would have liked to see the things my character is actually inspecting for clues, so that maybe I would have been able to see them myself. No such case in this title.

On the subject of minor gripes, there is no way to review past dialogue trees (you have a journal which would have been perfect for this), nor any way to pause during dialogue. I also noticed no in-game resolution options which would have been handy since I had to relaunch the game a few times to get it to look how I wanted, but perhaps that's a limitation of the engine the developers used. I noticed no bugs aside from the music cutting out randomly and restarting 10 seconds later rather than smoothly looping. On 2 or 3 occasions, the end of a dialogue tree forced me to leave a location before I was finished exploring it. Normally this would be a big no-no, but as mentioned in the previous paragraph, there was nothing for me to explore anyway.

Graphically the game looks nice, but some of the sprites do a really bad job of representing their character portraits, namely the sheriff, who looks nothing like his sprite suggested to me. The music is decent, a small assortment of indie rock and dark synth music, maybe another influence of the 90's drama the game loves so much. Not any one track stands out as particularly memorable, but the soundscapes were best when it was most quiet and synths most jarring.

I did like the voice acting of the game, and appreciate any game where you play as an angsty young woman. There are plenty of moments where you can curse people out and threaten them which is always great. I enjoyed a couple of the characters in the game, but really there's more people to talk to than there are characters, and there's not that many to talk to in this game. Many of them and their stories are abandoned entirely after their usefulness to you is done, which is not all that surprising considering how selfish your character is. I don't even recall being able to check on Goober after his "accident" which is just cold.

There are a few different kinds of puzzles in this game, and the one at the hospital was my favorite just for how evocative it was of its goofy 80s-90s gaming roots. That said, the game thankfully lacks many of the illogical puzzles those games used as well, with all of the few puzzles being fairly quick to solve, though they do not trick you into feeling very clever. One stands out as pretty bad, and this is where you lie about your identity on the phone. You get called out for this right off the bat because of your caller ID. So sounds like you have to figure out a new way to get this info, right? No. You just call again from the right phone, with the exact same voice and exact same question, to the exact same person, and he falls for it. Also Day 2 was a pointless slog which could have been cut entirely.

The elephant in the room is this games obsession with Twin Peaks. spoiler warning for the genre this game shifts towards. In the first hour of the game it hits you over the head pretty hard with a pretty bold name drop, and the more you learn about the mystery the more parallels you find. Some are just innocent references and that's totally cool. The setting, the owl, the bikers, cryptic speech, the connections to the local air force base and ufology, the.... dreams, ...the man in the red suit?? the mending?! The hole! Literally the entire ending sequence.

The red plants are even another strange connection, this one to the game Deadly Premonition, which is an even bolder rip-off of Twin Peaks than Kathy Rain is. The difference with Deadly Premonition is that the game is set up as a loving and goofy satire of the show and of video games in general, which it uses as a base to create its own mysteries and crazy train of a story that ends up nowhere near where it started.  Another good example of a successful Twin Peaks inspired game would be Life is Strange 1. It wears its wide range influences on its sleeves but uses their better parts to intuit its own story, own set of rules and imagery, and gives its main characters time to grow for a somewhat similar ending to really pay off.

Kathy Rain on the other hand seems so obsessed with its influences that it practically turns into an unabashed fanfic rather than using that inspiration for its own stories. It is essentially a remix of the Twin Peaks mythology with a tiny sprinkle of Cthulu mythos thrown in (which it does nothing with), just in case you thought they were running out of ideas. I was sure as soon as we got to the final day that the game would really start to pick up, and while some character points finally paid off, it did not shine when it needed to the most, and overall I do not feel like it earned its ending where Twin Peaks or Life is Strange did.

This makes me question why I criticize this game when normally I enjoy tropey things. Perhaps it is the specificity of what this game borrows that really bothers me, while genre-broad strokes I just take for granted in most games.

I don't wish to be misconstrued. I enjoyed my time with Kathy Rain the more time I spent in it, it has a good atmosphere, good voice acting, good protagonist, isn't frustrating to play, and the mystery is engaging. But gripes about the originality aside, it is ultimately is filled to the brim with backtracking, missing characters, ideas not followed up on, and a lukewarm payoff. There is a lot holding this title back from being Great, it seems more like a proof of concept or resume piece for future projects. I also mentioned before that this review is written before the Director's Cut edition of Kathy Rain comes out, its changes seem significant. Perhaps that will address some of the more general complaints.

92116955.review:
[h1]JUGANDO BAJO LA LLUVIA[/H1]

Estupenda aventura gráfica y buena opera prima de Clifftop Games, el pequeño estudio sueco que ha desarrollado el juego y que, a juzgar por su trayectoria, ha decidido especializarse en el viejo género de las aventuras gráficas.

La aventura bebe directamente de la vieja escuela, con un estupendo y flamante pixelado, una jugabilidad totalmente clásica, una buena historia y una carismática protagonista como carta de presentación. 

Una maravillosa combinación de ingredientes que, usados en su justa medida, garantizan no solo el disfrute de los aventureros mas avezados sino que además se convierte en un estupenda opción para introducir a los mas novatos en el género.  

La historia es una interesante e intrigante investigación detectivesca ambientada en los años noventa, desarrollada con mucha coherencia y un sorprendente final, abierto a diferentes interpretaciones y a una posible segunda parte. En cuanto a la dificultad el juego se mueve en un rango medio o incluso, salvo alguna excepción, en un rango de dificultad medio bajo, con unos puzzles y unas conversaciones basados casi siempre en la lógica y la deducción mas elementales. 

O dicho de otro modo en Kathy Rain no nos vamos a encontrar ninguna situación que requiera un mono palanca para progresar en la Isla del Mono.

En ese sentido cabe destacar, y algunos celebraran,  que el progreso en el juego y la resolución de las situaciones son totalmente coherentes, salvo quizás en el final del juego debido a como esta concebido en si mismo y que por motivos obvios no puedo argumentar sin recurrir a escandalosos spoilers.  

Aunque el humor esta presente en el juego nunca se cae en el absurdo y se basa sobre todo en los sarcásticos comentarios y peregrinos pensamientos de nuestra carismática protagonista. Una protagonista que, con permiso de las muchas virtudes de la aventura, es sin duda el mayor acierto del juego y que justifica de largo el título del mismo. 

Desde el principio Kathy nos cae bien, nos conquista a lo largo de toda la aventura y cuando esta finaliza... nos deja con mas ganas de Kathy Rain. 

Por buscar algo negativo decir que el juego se antoja demasiado corto, incluso para ser una aventura gráfica, y deja al aventurero con ganas de mas. Aunque hay que decir que a fecha de la realización de esta reseña ya esta anunciada una versión Director´s Cut que ampliará la duración del juego con nuevos escenarios, personajes y acertijos.

Una nueva versión que no dudaré en jugar a la menor oportunidad. 

Algunos pueden cuestionar también el críptico final del juego, muy abierto a diferentes interpretaciones. Pero allí donde algunos solo ven confusión y ambigüedad otros vemos un interesante tema de especulación y debate, a la espera de una más que posible segunda parte... con permiso de la Director´s Cut, claro. 

Juego muy recomendado, casi imprescindible, para todo tipo de aventureros, con independencia del tiempo que lleven frecuentando este magnífico género. Especial atención al futuro del estudio desarrollador y a lo que podría convertirse en una estupenda saga protagonizada por Kathy Rain. 

Abstenerse los más impacientes, los intolerantes del pixel y los detractores de las aventuras gráficas. Simplemente estamos hablando de deportes diferentes. 


8/10.

I was wanting to play a point and click adventure and got this game on sale. I would say I enjoyed it, the story was compelling enough for me to want to finish it, plus the game isn't particularly long (it took about 5 hours to complete). The puzzles required some thought but weren't too challenging which is nice! 

I wasn't sure how to feel about Kathy as a protagonist. While I liked that she was strong-willed, I thought she was borderline mean in some parts but this was supposed to be seen as.. cool? Also the "I'm not like most girls" line... jesus. Yeah that was goofy. It's possible to write a strong female protagonist without resorting to that 'edginess'. It was nice to see her open up more emotionally later in the game, however. 

The depictions of mental illness and neurodivergency were a little stale too. I understand the game is set in the 90's, but I think some things could have been done better (e.g. the infantalisation of Nathan). 

The ending felt a little rushed, but I was fine to shrug it off since the game was short. Overall I did enjoy it! If another Kathy Rain game came out, I'd play it, but in the hopes that they write Kathy a little better.

Great game - looking forward to the next Kathy Rain; really like the voice actress for both this and WoaM (same woman).

Advance through puzzles by lying, breaking the law and hurting vulnerable people. Be needlessly spiky and rude. Do untold emotional damage to a family and never face the consequences. 

This game feel so American 90s in how it deals with its characters and topics and their motivations. The main character felt like the product of a moral story: 'the don't turn out like her' kind.

The UI felt over complicated, especially after coming off of a point and click with a far more streamlined interface. Not sure if the 'think' action was strictly necessary.

90915249.review:
Kathy Rain is an adventure game that pays homage to 90s style adventures by studios like Sierra and Lucasfilm (Indeed, there are a couple nods to the Latter's "Full Throttle" tucked into Kathy Rain such as her taste in Motorcycles).  Retro fanciers will enjoy the nostalgic charm of the game's pixellated sprites and painted backgrounds, which are nicely done and will not torture the player with the need to waste time pixel hunting, although the simplicity of the gameplay felt to me a little like an overcorrection of 90s Sierra's sometimes notoriously convoluted puzzles.  Veteran adventure games will breeze right through this game for the most part as there are actually very few difficult  obstacles in their way here, and the game's snarky protagonist chooses her words carefully, dropping little hints to guide the player along.

Speaking of our Main Character, she felt to me like the end product of someone in development saying, "Okay, so what if we took a smart-ass adventure game style protagonist and MADE THEM EDGY????"  The writing just sort of bonks you over the head with Kathy's damage and makes her all sharp angles, especially in contrast with her Okily-dokily Flandersesque roommate/sidekick, Eileen.  I'm sorry, I get that unlikely friendships do happen, especially when you have to share cramped accommodations like a dorm room, but for the life of me, I could not for the life of me buy this partnership with the way the characters are written.  It just seemed to me that Kathy's big pile of accumulated trauma combined with her general abrasiveness would be a volatile combo with Eileen's cheerfully creepy intrusiveness and total lack of boundaries.  Which I guess sort of sums up the game's tonal problem.  Is this a small town mystery with a scrappy gal reporter unafraid to break the rules?  Is this a heartfelt exploration of generational trauma? Is this a psychotropic, supernatural, Jungian Hero's Journey?  Who knows!  It has elements of all three, sure, but falls short of really committing to any of them and just sort of skips across the surface on all counts, which is a little underwhelming.  You get the feeling that Kathy Rain doesn't quite know what it wants to be when it grows up, which is a little concerning for the possible sequel it teases. 

The sound design is fine. The English voice cast play their parts well.  The music is just sort of there. It does its job of providing atmosphere but is otherwise unmemorable.

 Overall, Kathy Rain is a pleasant enough diversion, though it probably won't stick around in your head for very long afterwards.  It looks good, it sounds good, it plays smoothly.   It's just sort of regrettable, though, that like the sad final years of Kathy's Grandfather, Joseph Rain, the spark at this game's core is MIA.

I guess a 6/10 sums it up.

Kathy Rain starts out like a casual detective point and click, but gets fairly dark and intense about halfway through. The story that drives the game is pretty intriguing, and the end does eventually tie up most questions to some degree. For the most part, the puzzles are easy to figure out, though there were a few places in the final stage where I got stuck. Having the ability to clearly point out interactable items can be helpful in these cases, as the issue was that I was missing a hot spot that was directly next to another.

The game looks like it's set up to be a launching point for sequel games, but I don't see any other Kathy Rain games by Clifftop Games, unfortunately. I would definitely recommend this game to people who like detective style point and click games and don't mind dark themes.

88839046.review:
Kathy Rain takes us around a Conwell Springs, a small town in the US, where you have to solve mysteries through clues and small puzzles. The story unfolds around Kathy's Grandpa' passing away, and Kathy digging into the mystery behind his death. You get your way around on your motorcycle, and you get information by talking to people, or clues by searching different places. This works like any other point and click game, very well. When you start a new point and click game there will always be alot of dialogue to get you started, and you have to get to know the different people and their personality before you get into the story, and into the game.

My patience for this game has been going up and down as I've played. Most of the time I could figure things out by myself, but when I was truly stuck, I felt I would rather get to know how to get further, than sitting for a very long time to figure it out myself. Normally figuring things out myself is how I do, but for this game I didn't feel it was worth spending so much time on it. The reason for that is the crazy story, mixed humour and things that are weird. The way you get around in the game is actually pretty good, and how you interact with people and objects are great, but I did feel I missed some more excitement. There are alot of good jokes in the game, but sometimes you're just sitting there cringing. The characters are pretty dramatic aswell. Maybe a bit too much. I did like doing the achievements though. They were hilarious, and are worth doing!

To sum up the game. If we ignore the weird story, the cheesy humour (which could be both good and bad), I would say that my biggest problem was patience. As I said earlier, I did finish most myself, but I felt that there were few puzzles that were really good, and sometimes, especially if you were stuck, it could get really boring fast. Most of the time you know where you wanna go next, but sometimes you have to guess stuff, that makes no sense. I know a few of the puzzles were all about guessing more or less, with some logic too, but I realised fast that it was better to check what to do, rather than being stuck for a long time.

In the end, I have been thinking alot about if I would recommend this game or not, but I have to choose one, so I give it a thumbs up. It's a good game as long as you keep progressing.

P.S. If you wanna do all the achievements, without having to do a new full playthrough, save at every different location, or at least before doing important stuff.

negatives:

- mechanics could use some tuning, i got stuck on a thing or two just because i didn't know how to "steer" correctly or cue the game to understand what i was trying to do, if that makes sense

- two characters straight up disappear in the last two chapters and as far as i know we're not given an answer as to where they went?

overall: i feel like this game had a REALLY solid start. i was really interested in the set up and figuring out where the story was going. i liked the puzzles; one of the first puzzles you're presented with kind of gives you a vibe of what you'd be getting into. the title's design made me think i was getting into a nancy drew-esque game and, again, i think the first  half stuck with that. unfortunately, once certain elements of the story are introduced, i think things kind of fall apart. things start happening real quickly, i feel like a lot of loose ends are left untied, and i felt like i had a lot more questions than i did answers. i'd definitely recommend this to friends if not in hopes that a sequel or some kind of DLC might be introduced to help expand on the story and characters and lore, because--again--it started pretty damn solid. just wish it had kept that up instead of flying off into left field. maybe a 3/5 star? i liked it but i feel a little disappointed in the end. :/ alas.
