Kathy Rain isn't a bad game, but the i really believe that the story is too forced for it's own good. It starts interesting, but gets weirder and confusing as the game progresses and the end leaves the story open, possibly indicating a sequel. Even after finishing it, I still don't understand the actual meaning of some characters. Personally I played the game for 1 hour then I didn't touch it for 1 month before I finished it.  The controls are clunky, with the old-school point-and-click system in play. Every item has a Think-about-it,See-it and Combine option, Combine also meaning "Use on someone", which took me far too long to understand. For 80% of them the See-it is just the same thing with different dialogue.
The graphics are pleasant and the sound and music are nice. The puzzles were not bad, but 2-3 times I had to look them up because it seemed they make no sense. Even now I don't understand how they got the briefcase code. 
In conclusion the game is worth it if you buy it during sale. I hope the director's cut gets rid of some of these problems.

88204869.review: point n click n point n click

88164233.review:
Nice Point & Click Adventure which has a modern feel - despite being set in the 90's - which I really like (released 2016). Hf <3


[h1]Story and Protagonist[/h1]
   The Story follows Kathy Rain, a journalism student, who gets confronted with her childhood and family struggles after attending her grandfather's funeral whom she hasn't seen for years.

In the beginning I was a tad bit concerned about Kathy as a protagonist because even tho I liked her from the start she also felt intentionally edgy and "not like other girls". This concern was unneccessary tho and she as well as her friendship with Eileen grew on me. Especially near the end you can truly understand why Kathy became such a sarcastic and sometimes harsh person. (Not that she isn't funny or compassionate.)

Overall the plot was weird but I liked it.
I can totally see why some may be disappointed by the ending. It wasn't outright illogical or anything but too open for my taste. A lot of things were left without proper explanation and I wanted to know more.
At least there was somewhat of emotional closure for Kathy tho.

[h1]Praise[/h1]
   The thing that really stuck out to me - besides the pretty pixel graphics and the good voice acting - was the functionality of the interface and dialogue. It really makes the game so much more enjoyable that Kathy has her notebook where she writes down dialogue options and she remembers for herself what she already asked so most of the time you won't need to ask a greyed out option twice. She also updates it when getting new information not only crossing out stuff but also tweaking it a bit. This gives you a satisfying feeling of progression in your work as a detective.

[h1]Difficulty and Achievements[/h1]
   Difficulty is okay. I got stuck and had to look up a few things but I wasn't tryharding most of the time. So if you have some experience with Point & Click Adventures (I don't really), a bit of patience and are focused on the game I doubt you'll have any troubles. Otherwise you can always either try everything until something works (Calling E. for advice is also very helpful in the beginning) or look up your next step in some neat guide on steam.

Achievements are also doable. Fun and not too outlandish. I got the missing ones after my first playthrough with a guide but I feel like you could get them just by paying attention.
Also be sure to save a few different times in your playthrough so that you don't have to do another full one to get to 100%. Exploring every possibility helps and often doing the rude thing gives you an achievement.

86882433.review:
So, I'm going to start off by addressing one of the major complaints I've seen in negative reviews in the best way that I can without spoilers.

I've seen a lot of reviews talking about how 'unexpected' and 'out of left field' the ending was, but honestly, I got a 'this story is going to be weirder than I think' vibe as soon as the kid showed up in the graveyard on DAY 1.  I really think the people upset with the roads this story took went into Kathy Rain expecting a run-of-the-mill mystery; they didn't pick up on the subtle clues along the way that there was more going on (or kept hoping there was a 'scientific' explanation), and then got upset when the story evolved into something else.

So let me just say this - if you're a fan of the original Twin Peaks TV series (Did anyone else catch the in-game reference?!), and you enjoy classically-styled adventure games (ala Gabriel Knight), then I think you're going to enjoy Kathy Rain.  The puzzles are challenging, the voice acting is well done, and the pixel art is both lovely and nostalgic.  As long as you don't go into this game expecting a 'Nancy Drew' type mystery, then I really think you'll have a lot of fun with this game, just like I did.  :)

86672648.review:
This game isn't really [i]that[/i] bad... it's solidly made with no bugs or characters interacting weirdly that I could detect.  The voice acting is top-notch and the style is super-90s which I expect is exactly what they were aiming for.

But that said the [i]gameplay[/i] is extremely linear, to the point where it felt like a middling fanfiction rather than a game with interaction.  That feeling stuck when the denoument failed to resolve to my satisfaction. I'd guessed three different ways: [spoiler]
- some industrial chemical... something, due to one of the two more ambitious characters mentioned (would explain things like your photo and the success of Mr Wade).
- a natural plant with psychoactive properties exploited by the local cult in aid of... ???
- and least interesting to me, some Lovecraftian deux-ex-machina to sweep all the plot inconsistencies under the rug.[/spoiler]

To me the ending was a near equivalent of "And then she woke up and it was all a dream. Or *was* it???" where if you accept that one thing happened, a different thing makes far less sense.  Adventure games need to have a well defined story and I felt this got mushy 1/2 way through.

If horror adventure is what you're after, I'd recommend you check out Yahtzee's "5 Days a Stranger" and sequels.

86587097.review: Fun puzzles, compelling story, sensational voice acting. Can't recommend highly enough

86383906.review:
The most stylistically convincing of recent retro-styled point-and-click adventures that I've played. It's [i]actually[/i] 320x240 - the pixels aren't fake! - and the designer has a real knack for the subtle rhythms of this weird, finicky genre. [i]Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Fathers[/i] is obviously the main model here, but not in a distracting or derivative way. Kathy Rain intelligently follows in its footsteps, with its own character and atmosphere. It's not just a nostalgia exercise; it's an actual revival of the style.

I thought the first half of the game was truly impressive. It put me in touch with authentic point-and-click feelings from 25 years ago, which was extremely satisfying, and I was grateful for that.

The later sections aren't quite as solid. The standard problems all crop up (pixel-hunting, tedious travel times, guess-what-I'm-thinking puzzles), and the writing gives the distinct impression of losing its way. As others have noted, the final act doesn't land. And, honestly, even from the start I could quibble about all sorts of things in the writing... 

... but I was willing to roll with all of it, because it was so clear that the game as a whole had been made thoughtfully and with care. If you're a fan of the old games Kathy Rain sets out to resemble, you'll very likely enjoy this experience. It feels like the real deal.

84721229.review:
[b][u]Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Fathers lite edition with female protagonist[/u][/b]

I'm joking, but I'm not really. This game borrows from GK1 very visibly, quite directly and by the truckloads. Which isn't a bad thing, GK was one of strongest titles of genre, technology and era.

[u]The graphics[/u]

Everything about graphics in this game is quite [i]professional[/i]. Professional as "I am solo indie dev and I need to make a game by deadline, and everything has to work and look good". Not someone's Artstation portfolio with 120 hours dumped into a single image just to squeeze as much out of pixels as possible or whatever. It's a clearly mission-oriented level of effort.

Thus it takes no risks. Everything looks as it should, character sprites have functional animations, doors open with according animations and so on. But there's no apparent attempt to "wow" the player or any serious extra effort, luxury animations with way more frames than needed or whatever. It's a decent-looking game, with some scenes looking quite good, others barely functional. Same goes for character sprites and animations. Not great, not terrible. They just do what they're supposed to do. So it's hard to either praise or criticise anything. If anything, it looks like game has used photos (or 3D renderings?) here and there for scene elements. They're really well obfuscated to fit in with overall style, but a pixel art purist would still easily notice them.

[u]The sound[/u]

The sounds are quite basic, as it's usual for this genre, voiceacting is most for good part. Worst offender in voiceacting is the priest character, because he sounds way too much like actor reading script from paper. And his sound mix doesn't have effects to the environment he's in, be it church or talking to a bunch of people in a cemetery. It all just sounds like dude in a studio reading lines to himself.

[u]The music[/u]

Kathy Rain has quite minimalistic music, but if you take a moment to notice it, it's pretty good in most places. I especially like the track at the clinic ward, which greatly reminds of me of Jesper Kyd and his Hitman: Codename 47 soundtrack. Pity this track is limited to this very briefly used scene.

[u]The mechanics[/u]

The notebook system, very elegantly solved inventory and fast travel system are excellent. You can highlight interactible items with spacebar, which is also must-have in such titles.

Thing to pick on here is quite pointless addition of verb coin - this game's need could have been solved easily by just using two mouse buttons, since there's rarely any need for 3 or 4 actions per scene element. Kathy Rain also suffers from common problems of the genre; main character moves very slowly and since there's a ton of backtracking despite quite few scenes, it just gets grindy. You cannot skip animations, either, so strap in to see Kathy Rain putting on and taking off her bike helmet for 500 times or slowly stroll into a police station/cemetery.

[u]The gameplay and puzzles[/u]

Main problem is that game is super strictly linear, you'll be backtracking everything to find that hidden trigger you missed. Puzzles are definitely on very easy side, with just 4 or 5 more clever ones peppered in. Puzzle-wise, game is very suitable to people new to the genre, Point-and-click veterans will just breeze through.
Luckily, there's no annoying puzzles with math or sliding elements or some other stupid filler stuff. Everything serves the story and mostly makes perfect logical sense.

[u]The characters and plot[/u]

The writing, in general, is pretty weak. There's no character development, no ulterior motives, nothing like that. Just your basic episode of a TV show, more or less. Grumpy Sheriff will stay grumpy, nerdy roommate will stay nerdy.

The plot starts from dull family mystery, tries to get more serious with message about forgiveness, but spoils it all with supernatural angle. So despite few "serious" keywords, entire thing is pretty light as a package. Which isn't really a bad thing, but don't expect to have deep emotional connection with anything in this game, during or after.

There isn't much humor in this game, either. Plot follows pretty narrow tone and mood, and stays on that.

[u]The verdict[/u]

Kathy Rain is a point and click adventure game with mostly everything functioning as it should. It's light enough to play through in an evening, easy enough for newbies in the genre, neutral and forgettable enough to suit all tastes and well-done enough to be one of modern staples of the genre. Recommended.

84491966.review:
A very deep transcendent experience in a mystery detective cover. What you will find here is:

1. A good well-thought [u]plot[/u], an entertaining [u]story[/u], exciting, and keeping you involved till the end. What is this all about? You will find out when you walk the path to the edge of the rabbit hole.

2. Funny dialogues, choices and [u]achievements[/u]. Don't miss a detail!

3. A rebellious teenager, disturbed by a dark past and never old parents-children problems. And a bunch of other charismatic [u]characters[/u], none of them being boring.

4. How did the grand-father end up in that vegetable state? What made his friend go insane? What made the young girl... and wait, who the hell is that dude in red?! In an attempt to [u]answer these questions[/u] Kathy Rain will need to face her demons, both real and psychological. Or is there any border between them?..

5. An entertaining [u]point-and-click gameplay[/u] with interesting [u]riddles[/u]. They may seem easy for riddle-lovers, difficult for beginners, but easy enough not to disturb those who would like to pursue the story.

6. An old-fashioned pixel [u]graphics[/u] that is really, really beautiful. I like every bit of it. Every pixel, I meant.

7. A well pertained slightly sad [u]atmosphere[/u] with fitting [u]music[/u] and environment sounds.

[strike]8. The way to seek God.[/strike]


[spoiler]9. Resemblance to Blackwell series (games) and Supernatural (TV series).[/spoiler]


What you will not find here:

1. Boredom.

2. Bugs.

3. Irrationality. In the meaning of absence of logic, not in the meaning of surreality. Because that you will find, in the meaning of transcendent experience...

Just stop reading this review already and play the game!;)
10/10

Lo termine hoy:
puedes pasarlo en unas 8 horas aunque el tiempo dependerá de tu nivel de ingenio para resolver puzles.

Mi reseña, dedicada a jugadores que al igual que yo no acostumbran a jugar juegos del genero point and click y que se dejan llevar por los gráficos. 

Primero, el juego tiene todas las voces en ingles pero lo mas importante es que todo lo que es texto esta traducido al español, a un buen español. No tendrás problemas en entender todo aunque he de decir que al cerrar el juego y volver a entrar el juego estaba en ingles, por ende tuve que volver a ir a opciones para ponerlo en español nuevamente. 

segundo, no encontré ningún tipo de bug o error o problema con el juego. 

tercero, la música del juego es bastante agradable y se adapta bastante bien a cada lugar que visitas. Me atrevo a decir que incluso ciertas músicas me recordaron un poquito a algunas de Life is Strange. Los efectos de sonidos tambien son bastante apropiados para cada objeto. 

cuarto. cada escenario es relativamente pequeño por lo que recorrerlos no te tomara nada de tiempo y presionando la barra espaciadora puedes resaltar todos los objetos y personajes con quienes puedes interactuar. 

quinto. sobre la historia: bastante interesante. al principio no pensaba que seria llamativa pero poquito a poquito el juego te da incentivos para averiguar mas y entre mas averiguas mas grande se vuelve el interés por saber más. cada misterio que resuelves entrega nuevos y te dan ganas de avanzar y avanzar y no parar o al menos ese fue mi caso. 

sexto. sobre gráficos, realmente pediría que no juzgues el juego por ellos. En mi caso me acostumbre rápido a ellos y terminaron siendo agradables a la vista. Si realmente juzgas el juego por los gráficos entonces recomiendo que te enfoques en jugar para descubrir la historia y no te enfoques en intentar descubrir alguna belleza visual.

séptimo. sobre la historia pues podrías quedar mas que sorprendid@ y de seguro se ganara un buen puesto en tu lista de recomendados. Puedo añadir que cada personaje se adapta también bastante a su personalidad, no sientes que ningún personaje actúe de manera falsa u obligada y lo mismo con las voces.  hay juegos de compañías enormes cuyos personajes y como actúan han dejado mucho que desear, en el caso de Kathy Rain, eso no sucede. 

octavo. sobre el precio pues . . . soy una persona algo pobretona y preferiría gastar semejante cantidad en otra cosa. Compre este juego por que estaba en rebaja y valió la pena. Recomiendo pagar el precio completo si eres realmente fan de los point and click y no tienes ni idea de que juego de dicho genero comprar. Tu dinero no sera mal gastado, pero si no ere tan fan y buscas un juego para relajarte por unas horas y disfrutar de una historia muy muy decente e interesante pues espera a que este en rebaja. 

Sea como sea que adquieras el juego, realmente lo recomiendo a quien sea.

83973699.review:
Picked up this game after playing Whispers of a Machine and if I could go back in time I would reverse the order. Whispers of a Machine is far superior in story telling, plot, characters, and pacing. Had I not played it first I might have liked this one a bit more. 

The protagonist Kathy Rain is a "not your typical girl" tomboy who rides a motorcycle, drinks, smokes, and always has a witty comeback. She came off as pandering and way too much of a caricature to be relatable or likable. Eileen your chipper nerd girl christian sidekick isn't any better. Her entire substance as a character is that she is a mildly obsessed stalker who knows way too much about you (she knows your ssn? wtf...) and does not respect boundaries. Every time she crosses a line the game writes it off like it's nothing which bothered me a bit. 

The plot itself was confusing at best and predictable and corny at worst. It started off as a regular murder mystery only to take a lazy turn into the supernatural around the middle. The puzzles themselves weren't all that difficult and just required going back and forth until you had all of the info. Some points of the game required you to make weird intuitive leaps that meant minutes upon minutes of frustrated clicking and just eliminating all your options until you did the right thing. 

That being said the art is really nice and evokes that classic 90's point and click vibe and the voice acting is decent if not good for most of the game. The soundtrack is also fairly solid and sets the tone well. Is this an award winning game that everyone should buy? Nope. But if it's on sale and you like point and clicks you probably won't regret picking it up for an afternoon. 

Also the abortion bit near the end was seriously messed up. What a disappointing plot twist. At least they gave you an option to say otherwise.

83907569.review: Overall, this game is more interesting than most in the genre. The story has some good twists, if incomplete in presentation, and maybe a bit too abstract. They pull you out of the game, which is otherwise mostly intuitive and world-based.

83127229.review:
Alright, I panned this hard because of some initial impressions and a serious bug that caused a complete Black Screen of Death on Windows 10 Pro. But after restarting, I set the game to windowed mode and played it through.

DO NOT RUN THIS GAME IN FULL SCREEN MODE OR YOU MIGHT LOSE EVERYTHING ELSE RUNNING IN YOUR CURRENT WINDOWS SESSION.

I thought this was an old game, they did well convincing me that it was retro. One reason I legitimately thought it was an actual old game was the config uses DirectX9, which was released initially in 2002. The other option is DirectDraw 5, which is a long discontinued API. The game refused to load using DirectX9, so I had to select DirectDraw 5 to get the game to work.

Upon learning this game was released in 2016, I'm quite miffed that they didn't make this more compatible with modern computers, and for that alone I'm still tempted to keep a negative review.

So, to repeat what I yelled above, do not use fullscreen mode. I did so, and tried to switch to the Windows desktop via Alt-Tab and the game immediately caused a Black Screen of Death. I had open a couple database files, a development IDE, and many browser tabs.

I could not even break out of the BSOD by hitting Ctrl-Alt-Del or Ctrl-Shift-Esc, I also couldn't use the Windows hotkeys to switch to another desktop (which I've done on other misbehaving games like FarCry 2 which seem to like to BSOD).

As a result, I may have lost some things I was working on, all to play this game for a break from work. I do not consider that acceptable, given the year this was released, and that Windows 10 is fairly standard. As such, I can not recommend this game.

All that aside, this game is a point and click adventure the likes of The Secret of Monkey Island. It does have some humor to it, but it's got more of a Life is Strange feel.

The opening was quite heavy with religious narratives, and that put me off as an atheist that doesn't want to have some game attempt to be a morality play encouraging one to find salvation. Fortunately, once I got past the initial scenes, I realized this was not the case.

The story is pretty good, definitely borrowing bits and pieces from Twin Peaks. The voice-overs were done well, there were no weak performances for the most part.

You've won a fan in me Raw Fury. I highly recommend this game and will tell my friends about it! :)

82940408.review:
As someone who grew up with the point-and-click classics, I found this game delightful!

I'm reminded a lot of Gabriel Knight in terms of mood, music and art. The story is an interesting mystery piece that also takes me back to the Voodoo Murders of New Orleans. The puzzles are varied and not too tough to crack. The art is a bit blocky for the style, but does the job well, in addition to the nostalgia. The voice acting works, even though it's not Tim Curry we're listening to. The game took me about 7 hours to play through, and I did not really get stuck for long on a single problem.

The game engine is not perfect, and could use a bit of polish and ease of use, such as double-clicking to skip walking to an exit.

There are not many point-and-clicks made these days. Having worked on one myself, I know they are not the cash cows of the industry. Being able to play a good one, is a rare treat. If you're looking for that nostalgia of the days of the tentacles, I'm sure you can dig this one!

82712890.review:
Jan 21 edit: changed to a 'not recommended'. They are planning a new version of this game, so I cannot recommend buying this old edition. Original review follows...

TLDR: It's quite fun... I'd likely rate it about 6.5. If you want a little point and click diversion you could do far worse, just don't expect the earth in terms of puzzles or story.

A good homage to the old point and click adventures with plenty of nods to various influences. 

Puzzles are not too complicated, and only a couple I had to Google as they seemed rather abstract or not clear. And indeed if there is one fault it's sometimes clear what you're meant to do next.

It merges various plots - and goes certainly weirder than I expected. If was surprised to see this came out just before Stranger Things, as you'd certainly think Stranger Things was an influence.
 
The separate elements each are good but I'm not sure if there's enough cohesion to really tie them together in a truly satisfying way. Indeed the plot seems to stumble about towards the end and I felt many characters felt abandoned. I would have preferred more of a cohesive end.

The main character herself is a little stereotypical at times. Clearly a bit Buffy Summers, but tries a little *too* hard to be edgy. I suspect it was written by a man, as a lot of is a kind of male view of what a cool woman should be. She swears, she rides motorbikes, she smokes! She has no time for dodgy men or their nonsense! 

But really all in all, it's a fun little game. If you want to inhabit an interesting universe with future potential and have a not-too-difficult point and click adventure, you could do far worse than this.

82561687.review:
Kathy Rain is a mystery/suspense point'n'click adventure game with great value.

PROS:
+ Story. It's intriguing, keeps you wondering 'till the end. Has good character arcs, nice atmosphere and setting.
+ Pixel art: It's way above average, extra points for attention to detail and non-lazy work on animations.
+ Sound Design: Good voiceovers, good sfx and very compelling soundtrack.
+ Puzzle design: Not too easy, not too hard, and everything about them makes sense. (one small minus note on overused 'get the key-open the door' puzzles)
+ Value: I think it deserves its price for the playtime (about 4 hours long).

NEUTRAL:
~ Even the story is intriguing and all, it raises more questions than it answers. A sequel is hinted at the ending.
~ Some characters are close to being stereotypical.

CONS:
- I love AGS engine, and even this is one of the best using of it (if not the best), engine's limitation shows itself; some timing on animations, black right-left borders on widescreen etc.

FINAL:
[h1] 8/10 [/h1] It is a solid point'n'click adventure game with good art and an intriguing story. Must have for adventure fans.

82191500.review:
Until about half way through the game I would have recommended it. However once the credits finished I don't think I could recommend this game to anyone other than people who love Point & Click and can't get enough.

Firstly, the good things. Artwork, soundtrack, and voice acting is all great. Puzzles are fine overall - nothing too obtuse. The mainline story in the first half of the game is interesting too. It starts off as a nice little mystery and slowly builds bit by bit.

Now the bad. To start with, Kathy Rain herself. She seems to have been written as a cool rebel with an attitude - she smokes, rides a motorcycle, her side of her dorm room is a mess, and she can pick locks with paper clips - but she also has a messy past and is a afraid to open up! Unfortunately she just comes across as unlikeable. She's quite rude to a lot of the NPCs (not in a cool way, in a "No need for that." way), and it becomes difficult to really care or root for her as the story progresses. In fact I'm struggling to think of many reasons to like her as a character.

As for the second half of the story *SPOILERS* [spoiler] at first I thought it was maybe going to go down the route of some weird cosmic horror, which at first I was on board for, "Cool I suppose. I wasn't expecting this, but I'm up for the ride.", then it just seemed to get massively bogged down focusing on the unlikeable Kathy, the main story line just unravelled and stopped making sense, and it certainly didn't wrap up the story in a satisfying matter. [/spoiler] In short: The second half of the story just felt like a big, fat, MESS. After the credits rolled, I was left sat here thinking "What was that about?".

In conclusion: Good artwork. Good sounds. OK puzzles. Decent first half. Main character is lame. Second half of the main story is nonsense.

Kathy Rain returns to the scene of her early childhood for the funeral of her grandfather with whom she had cut ties for fifteen years. She will travel to her past and relive memories left behind. As the veil is lifted to uncover the mysteries of the past, we will get to know Kathy and understand her attitude.

Most of the puzzles are fairly easy to solve and some require a little thought. The main interest is in the story, rich in strong themes like heredity, mental illness, abandonment and abuse in an atmosphere between Twin Peaks and Silent Hill. The excellent soundtrack contributes to it.

I could recommend this story to casual or even non-gamers.

79015115.review:
I really enjoyed playing Kathy Rain.  If you like classic or retro style Point & Click Adventure games you’ll likely enjoy and appreciate this game.  I wouldn’t recommend it for those under 13 though simply because of the frequent cursing.  It does touch on some darker topics such as suicide and abortion but, doesn’t show much gore or anything regarding murders and deaths.

The story is pretty good, very interesting but could have been fleshed out a little more.  For example, they introduce a boy early on but the story around him is underdeveloped.  He seems like he should play a more important role but you seem him only briefly in a short cut scene and then as a minor plot device to move the ending forward.  The ending feels a little rushed and seems to be somewhat underdeveloped.

The premise of the story is that you find out your grandfather (who you’ve not seen for like 15 years) dies and you go his funeral and become interested in the mysterious cause of his long-term illness and eventual death.  As a journalism major you start investigating and it leads you to find out about several other deaths and illnesses and eventually leads you to some supernatural causes.  There are several intended plot twists but much of it was actually kind of predictable or at least partially predictable.  However, even if you can see what’s coming the story itself is interesting as it unfolds.

The characters in the story are for the most part well done.  I think there could have been a little more time fleshing out some of the characters and giving them more of a story arc.  Kathy Rain feels like she’s meant to have some major character development happening but it doesn’t feel like after everything happens that she’s actually worked through her past issues or shown much growth just accepted it enough to get through some tests and come out feeling largely unchanged.  I guess that this aspect of character development could have been much further developed and maybe it was intended to do so but the whole end feels a little rushed and maybe some of that was pared down to reach deadlines, budgets, or something along that line.  Some of the characters seem highly stereotyped but most I’d say are kind forgettable besides our main character.

The graphics of this game are done in a retro pixelated style common for 90’s games and retro styled games from the adventure games renaissance.  The pixelated graphics for the most part, are good.  Some odd sizing issues when the sprite has to move forward and backward on a scene but the left right mechanics are good.  The sprites are well drawn for their graphic size and the animations in general are smooth and have reasonably good walkpaths.  The backgrounds are well done and sufficiently display the environments and set the tone of the scenes.

The sound was good for this game.  Though the music is largely forgettable it did a good enough job of matching the tone and scene so that I never felt pulled out of the game by it.  It blended well to the setting; it just didn’t stand out as noticeable.  The voice recordings were well recorded, very professional sounding.  The voice acting was also really well done.  I was surprised by how well the voice actors did.  The conversations didn’t sound awkward or overly scripted and the actors were able to easily create natural sounding conversations.

There aren’t many puzzles in this game but, the few that are there are fairly logical and straightforward.  I did find the second part of the tomb puzzle near the end to be a little confusing and struggled with that for a while but most of the puzzles were moderately easy in my opinion.  Not so easy you don’t feel challenged at all but not so tough that you get overly frustrated with the game either.

The UI in this game is bare bones.  They tried to make the UI very simplistic.  This works in some ways but is frustrating (to me anyway) in others.  For example, in a typical P&C Adventure game you can select an item from your inventory the you see you’ve picked it up and you click it on something to try different reactions with various things in the inventory/environment.  Often you have multiple choices on your cursor to look, get, use, talk, etc…  which you then click on the item.  In this game however, you  click on the inventory item and then options appear around the item to look at it, think about it, use it, or combine it.  To use it in the environment around you, you must select combine and then click on the thing you want to use it with/on.  This feels like an extra step to me and I found that method of interacting to be a little annoying but, I think it’s just a personal preference.  It works fine but, it’s not my preference for interacting with the game.  The other thing I don’t really like is there is no access to the menu for saving, loading, changing options, etc… right in the screen or with a mouse-over spot somewhere on the screen.  You can access that menu by pressing esc but, I prefer to have access to it a little more obvious.  There is not worry about pixel hunting with this game as it shows hotspots by pressing the spacebar so if you hate pixel hunting then you’ll love this feature.

There are 20 achievements in this game.  5 of those unlock through story completion but the rest require special actions, repeated actions, or in some cases … alack of action.  All of the achievements are obtainable in 1 playthrough but unless you are using a guide I’m guessing many people would be missing a good half of the remaining 15 achievements.  Many are not something you would come across naturally.  Do pay attention to what Kathy says about things when she looks at or thinks about them.  Sometime she gives clues that indicate something you could do for an achievement.

I did my first playthrough in about 4.5 hours and then played half way through for a missing achievement in about 1.5 hours.  I’d say this game probably is a 4-6 hr game depending on your familiarity with P&C games and how long certain puzzles take you.  At. 4.5 hours it’s about $3.33/hr of gameplay.  I don’t think it has a huge amount of replay value though.  At that price point it is a little too pricey.  If however you can get it on sale, it’s well worth it.

77417678.review:
An atmospheric and intriguing story, similar in style to classic point-and-click adventure games, Kathy Rain is well worth a look from anyone familiar with the genre, and not a bad starting point for anybody who's curious. Although a little on the short side, every step pulls players further into the story. 

It does have its drawbacks. Kathy herself - sarcastic, cynical, even "edgy" - is not a heroine for everyone, although she does become more endearing as we learn more about her. The puzzles are, for the most part, fairly straightforward for seasoned adventurers, with solutions frequently telegraphed, but this does serve to keep the plot moving and interest alive for those less interested in point-and-click nostalgia. There is no moon logic, thankfully - that would be a nostalgic step too far - although you are asked to do some eyebrow-raisingly amoral things to progress.

 Like a lot of games which set up an impossible premise, it also struggles to deliver a satisfying conclusion to the mystery it creates. Faced with the choice between over-explaining  or remaining frustratingly cryptic, Kathy Rain leans slightly towards the latter and rushes through the ending, seemingly realising it has an unsolvable mystery on its hands and dealing with this by leaning heavily into the surreal. It's something of a cop-out, but the eerie atmosphere and experience as a whole outshine the hasty finish.

Technically speaking, the voicework is remarkably good for an independent developer. The art design is both beautiful, especially in the backgrounds, and a nice homage to old school adventure games of the 80s and 90s, a perfect choice for the game's setting. The aspect ratio is an unusual choice but not one which causes any issues.

Kathy Rain has its flaws, that much is undeniable. Personally, I find them excusable both for its atmosphere and as a first outing from the developer - a slightly longer game from a more experienced developer, with more time spent exploring the characters and resolving plot threads, would solve most of the issues it has. Approach it with that in mind and Kathy Rain is a compelling little game which will leave you wanting more.

Sometimes a touch of mystery or ambiguity just fits. But in this case, it was a bit of a disappointment compared to the rest of the game and it simply lost me in its attempt to become much deeper than it appeared at first. But, I have to say that the excellent dialogue and voice acting more than made up for it. Kathy's snark and sarcasm, while somewhat over the top at times, was refreshing and fun. The supporting characters around her complimented her personality perfectly too, even if she and Eileen were quite the stereotypical duo. Of course I also took delight in the retro graphics, especially since I'll always hold a nostalgia for old and pixelated 90s point-and-click games that were a big part of my childhood. But even if pixel sprites aren't really your scene, I think the overall story, script, and its eclectic cast of characters will still be enough to hook you in and keep you playing until the very end.

75411719.review:
Kathy Rain is a nice short cozy game that will definitely give you a nostalgic rush of the good ole graphics adventure games of yore. Considering that the game is the first attempt of a  small team of developers, I was suitably impressed and I recommend it  if you are a fan of point-click adventures with beautiful pixel graphics especially if it's on sale.
PROS
------
Gameplay: Gameplay was good. Story progression and buildup was well executed. Though I read some reviews complaining it was boring, I think on the contrary that the slow buildup is what creates the intriguing atmosphere of the game and gives it a nice 'twin peaks' vibe. I found the puzzles well thought out and neither too easy nor difficult. 

Setting: Kathy Rain goes back to her childhood town to find out more about her recently deceased grandfather. Major twin peaks vibe and I really liked the atmosphere of the game. So if you are a fan of the small-town mystery genre you will like this game

Buildup: The story is a mixed bag. The buildup was really good so I decided to put that in the pros but the ending was kind of anticlimactic. I would say the first 2/3 of the game really gets you hooked into the story and I found myself genuinely intrigued to find out more.

Kathy: I really liked the main character. Her voice acting was really good and I digged her snarky biker girl vibe (could say its bit of a 90s cliche but i personally liked the character). Her unlikely friendship with innocent christian girl eileen was fun to watch. I read some reviews saying that there isn't much character development but how much character development can you actually put when all the events in the game takes place in 4 days.

Music: The music is excellent! Really simple and has that 90's vibe with a modern feeling. Kudos to the music designer.

Artwork: I love pixel graphics and the artwork in this game looks and feels nice.

Cons
____
Ending: The ending could have better. Don't get me wrong its not garbage but after the excellent buildup of the first 2/3 of the game, the ending kind of putters out. Felt like there was a nice potential for lovecraftian element but its never fully explored as the game ends before Kathy can find out more about the lore. Who knows! maybe there will be a sequel!

75410093.review: An excellent, paranormal point-and-click adventure. It's probably a little short compared to most classic games. But it's also a great story. I look forward to the next one (there's a next one, right?!)

75036887.review:
Kathy Rain is fantastic. 

Mid-90's America was a strange place. It was a long, lazy summer where the world was pretty okay, but folks still had plenty of small troubles to handle. Kathy Rain really captures that sense of small drama and big impact. 

Kathy Rain herself is a troublemaker with a leather jacket, a zippo lighter, and a devil-may-care attitude. While she's got plenty to do in solving the mysteries which hide in Conwell Springs, I really appreciated how Kathy Rain (the game) does not shy away from confronting the traumas of Kathy Rain (the character). While she's got plenty of humor, attitude, wit, charm, and all the clever can-do spunk you'd expect, she's a character with depth, just as capable of being angry, confused, scared, or sad. She's neither strong nor weak. She's just a person who somehow keeps moving forward as best she can. Turns out, her best is pretty damn good. 

In terms of difficulty, the game hits a sweet spot in point-and-click adventures. Any number of games create fake difficulty by simply keeping you ignorant. Not so in Kathy Rain. Most of the puzzles make sense. You usually have a pretty clear idea of where you want to go and what you want to do, while still having to think about how you're going to get there.

The music, sound, and art are all pretty solid for what they're trying to achieve. They really nail the bit where you're on your bike, just cruising between zones and watching the countryside roll by. 

I won't say much about the plot, since I enjoyed it but don't want to spoil it for you. Suffice it to say that when your game is subtitled "A Detective is Born," your spunky 90's rebel chick is going to find a mystery. I wish you the best in solving it!

75025725.review:
Quick vague spoiler free review.

A point and click adventure with only a single incredibly small puzzle near the beginning and one near the end. The rest of the game is a slow walk and talk through a town to solve a mystery about an incident that happened to your late grandfather. The game isn't nearly long enough to create a compelling narrative and it is hard to feel any attachment to characters you talk to once or twice. There is a horror(or science fiction? I really didn't know what they were going for) element, that to me comes out of nowhere after the beginning of the game. Again, this element isn't explained in depth and the conclusion at the end of the game is very underwhelming. 

As far as the gameplay is concerned there aren't any bugs and I was never really confused on what to do or where to go. The gameworld is incredibly small and sparse of objects, usually you can get by with examining each object and then talking to a relevant person about it. That usually opens up a new place to go and then you repeat the process.

I give it a solid 5/10. I bought it on sale for a couple bucks and it was worth that price. The story is mediocre at best and doesn't stand with any of the fantastic indie point and clicks released in recent years or even close to the titans of the genre. Money and time could be much better spent trying those. However the game makes sense for the most part and the voice acting was fine. Music was well made and fit the atmosphere of the areas almost all of the time. It took me 5 hours to complete the game at a snails pace with a little bit of a replay to see if dialogue choices matter.[spoiler] It doesn't, all choices lead to same thing. [/spoiler] I don't recommend the game because there are much better stories out there to experience but if it's on sale and you really enjoy point and clicks with little to no puzzles then you could still do worse than giving this one a try.

74579575.review:
Oof. Good buildup, good art, and a generally promising start -- as long as you like retro point-and-click adventure games, anyway. But the ending really flubs it. The last area invokes a lot of the worst adventure game tropes, it gets very pixel hunt-y and unintuitive in a way that the rest of the game generally avoided. Worse, the story ends in a vague and unsatisfying way, without really paying off any of the themes it had been creating before that.

If you like mysteries, this one isn't resolved very well. If you like puzzles, they're too basic to really engage with. If you like characters, they're tempting at first but ultimately nobody except Kathy actually gets the screentime to develop. If you *really really* like 90s adventure game mechanics, though, go for it.

This is a good game, and it's worth your time. The plot is minimum but interesting and it moves at a decent speed. The maker/s of this game are very good at establishing mood, setting and tone, but the honest truth is that the characters are flat, and perhaps they are the weakest part of the game. (I don't consider character 'interests' to be good characterisation.) However, the high-quality voice acting gives an illusion that the characters are more detailed than they really are. The game is worth your time, but I can't tell you if it's worth your money. I enjoyed my time with the game and it's honestly one of the better point-and-click games I've played in a good while, but in saying that I paid only 1 euro for it in the Humble Bundle pack.

If you're interested in point-and-click games and like a good (albeit simple) story with great atmosphere and above decent puzzles, then give the game a go. But keep in mind that its price tag covers the production costs of the game--the gorgeous backgrounds, decent animation, the transitions between areas--and not necessarily its value-for-money cost. If money is no issue, buy and it enjoy it; otherwise, aim for a sale.

74509226.review:
Kathy Rain is exactly what adventure games should be: clever without being obtuse, and with an engaging story to match.

The puzzles manage to be challenging enough to solve without going into moon logic. I never felt the game is cheating by expecting a solution that makes no sense. There are plenty of clues of what you should do next and how to do it. This lets the story unfold without waiting for you to figure out the insane logic of the developer.

The story is fun. It borders on noir fantasy, but leaves enough room to make an argument that maybe there isn't anything fantastic at all, leaving it up to the player to decide if there actually was anything supernatural. I dug that approach.

It is short, but it's a good length for a game like this. You'll breeze though it in a day or two, never being frustrated by the puzzles and enjoying a nice story to boot.

74170202.review:
I get that it's supposed to be an authentic 90s experience, but it's so slow-paced and boring, and the puzzles get frustrating at points. Which, i suppose, is an authentic 90s experience. And while i was in the target market for this sort of game back in the days where this is set, i am not nostalgic for the teen angst that smothers this game. I can't speak for everyone, obviously, since this game is overall well reviewed, but Kathy's constant MTV-era snark and the overall edginess™ of the story and setting is stuff i grew out of years ago, and is more cringe-inducing than charming nowadays. It's like Daria without the self-awareness or social commentary.

Perhaps most annoying, though, were the points where i had the little mysteries figured out long before Kathy did, but couldn't follow through on the correct course of action without completing a few more fetch quests first, to make sure she gets it.

I also didn't think the conclusion was a satisfying wrap-up to the plot, or the character arcs. [SPOILERS] In particular Kathy's friend E, whose full name is escaping me right now. There seemed to be a lot of foreshadowing to that character either betraying Kathy, or becoming an integral part of her ultimate victory. In the end she was neither. She shows up at Grandma's house, causes another bit of character conflict, and is swiftly put into a coma to motivate our hero to...do what she was already going to do anyway. In the end, Kathy defeats the evil (FOR NOW, ELLIPSIS QUESTION MARK), her friend returns to normal, and Kathy is happy to have saved her. Literally none of their character conflicts mattered in any way.

Also, just a quick note as a personal defense of my pride in a matter that's largely irrelevant. Steam says i played this game for 18 hours, but it was probably more like five. I accidentally left it running all day while i was cleaning the house this weekend.

TL;DR: i'm not sure who this is for. Nostalgic 90s kids will (probably) find the tone cringey, and current edgy teens are (probably) not looking for 90s nostalgia. Game boring.

73661757.review:
[An aging adventure game fan is here, who started with text based games, so... had seen some.]

After a few recent releases that turned out to be (mediocre) visual novels disguised as point and click adventure games, I started being very careful with this genre label on Steam. Thank God (the crimson one or the other as you like) this game is faithful to its roots. It has - almost - everything that a point and click adventure has to have.

Most of all, the game has a great story. It starts very normal, then turns into a psychological-supernatural adventure. In a good way, I had flashes of The X-Files, Twin Peaks, Sanitarium at certain points of the story. But these are under the surface, nothing is pushed down to our throat by force. I enjoyed playing this through from the beginning till the end of the credits. And I'd easily watch it as a feature film or animated movie.

Liked
- Captivating story from the beginning to the end
- Believable and living characters
- Great, sometimes funny, sometimes suspense dialogues
- Easy to use inventory
- Easy and meaningful way of travelling 
- Not only the actions that make the story go forward are handled. As we try to do everything with everything and on everything, we can get some very funny reactions. And Kathy has a though on all items.
- The puns, and references, or just slight resemblances of books, movies, series, games, etc.
- The adult motif in the game (and I'm not talking about swearing or sexism)
- The subtle, blink-and-miss moments, e.g. the Crimson Man outside the house at he beginning of Day 4.

Could have been better
- Missing "double click on exit for fast pass" option
- The contrast between the portraits (during the discussions) and the pixelated version of the characters. Sometimes they seem to be a different person.
- The elderly character's portraits don't seem to be old.
- Despite using paint thinner in the chapel office picture make sense, this action has no unique reaction.
- Pretty much linear close to the end. There is only one possible thing to do, but it has to be done in two screens away all the time. Game design like this always drags me out from the story, as it is tiring and makes me start worrying about my time.

Not liked
- Promoting smoking (even with an achievement) Fair play to the warnings though.

73627369.review:
Kathy Rain is a great Adventure, Point and Click game, but now it’s time for the story.

It has been a long time since being in her home town, since Kathy rain saw her grandparents. But after the death of her grandfather Kathy comes home not just to open old and make new wounds, but to put the mystery of her grandfather's illness to bed.

So what is to like about the game. Well the story is really good with not just a lot of twists and turns, but a lot of heartfelt, touching and some scary moments in it. The mystery is really good with plenty of clues to keep you guessing.

The pixel Graphics/backgrounds were very nice and well detailed. The levels in the game were also fun to see and explore with some beautiful scenery you can look at. 

The characters in the game were very interesting especially the main character Kathy Rain who comes off as snarky and sassy but feels very human with the trauma she has to deal with.

The puzzles in the game were okay some could be a pain others not so much. The music in the game was good and some of the humor in the game was kind of funny. The voice acting is pretty solid like Kathy and her friend Eileen and the Grandma being one of the best acted.

So what is to dislike about the game, well honestly nothing it's pretty perfect. Well maybe some of the puzzles could get very annoying sometimes, but that is just a nitpick besides that this game is pretty perfect.

So Kathy Rain is a great Adventure, Point and Click game, with a really good story, very nice and well detailed the pixel Graphics/backgrounds, and very interesting characters. So if you’re looking for a good Adventure, Point and Click game this is for you.

73518186.review:
This is how modern 'old school' point and clicks should be done: 

+ Lots of different screens, all beautifully drawn. The characters and portraits also look and feel awesome imho.
+ Lots of 'hot spots'; almost everything you see on the screen can be looked at and commented on. The achievements encourage and reward you to check out everything, very satisfying.
+ Lots of different and interesting characters, each voice-acted very well 
- Except for the priest, maybe. He sounded a bit too robotic to me. 
+ Intriguing story, plenty of mystery and little details to solve. A bit cliché in the end, but nothing unforgivable.
+ The puzzles make perfect sense, not too hard to figure out.
- Except for one maybe (the one regarding a certain safe code, that was a bit moon logic to me). 
+ Also loved the music, great atmosphere overall. 

If you - like me - love the genre and like the story setup I can honestly think of no reasons not to play it, especially for the 89 cents I payed for it. Highly recommended.

Wonderful game! [8/10]

This game is a good p&c to play without a walkthrough. It's nicely detailed, very well voice acted, and an interesting story. 

[spoiler] The first two days are solid. The third day felt a bit like being an errand girl, trying new dialogue options on everyone. The fourth day I got a bit stuck after the safe, I didn't link the poem to the mausoleum. Doesn't fit a priest in my mind, but hey, maybe they had wealthy parents! [/spoiler] 

The game gets a bit less detailed at the end, but that's very welcome, as it's nice just to progress the story. Most achievements come naturally through thorough gameplay, but there are a few that require hints.

72237154.review:
This is a solid indie game in regard to its puzzles, art, and voice acting. The atmosphere is, especially, quite good. However, I was disappointed by the story. The initial set up reminded me a lot of Dark (the Netflix series), but the way its pieces connected and its events concluded did not satisfy compared to other titles in the genre.

In short (and hopefully without spoilers), the mysteries of the universe are never explained. We know that the bad guys are bad, but we don't learn their motives. Additionally, the game-ending events are motivated by circumstances that arise halfway through the game instead of being triggered by the first act. So despite the good dialog writing, the story itself is badly written IMO.

[h1]One of the better point and click games out there[/h1]

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
+ Beautiful backgrounds and great pixelart.
+ No pixel hunting required. Objects/areas of interests are labeled and can be easily interacted with.
+ Interesting story set in the 90's.
+ Great voice acting:
   I found myself clicking on random objects and trying to use them in silly ways just to hear what Kathy would say.

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]

71774576.review:
KATHY RAIN is a point-and-click adventure game in the manner of the old LucasArts/Sierra, but with more of a dramatic than comedic feel. If you already like point-and-click adventures, you'll probably enjoy this.
I like that Kathy has her own personality, so it made it easier for me to pick the more spirited choices of dialogue than I would normally do. I also liked the matter-of-fact Christianity hanging around the place. However, I'd like to point out that in a scene at a bar, there is some really *vile* language, like...terms I consider harsher than the F-word. It made sense in context and coming from that particular character, but I didn't like it myself. So be aware of that if you're more wholesome Eileen than a grrrl power Kathy type (or if you're buying this for a younger person).
I didn't feel like the ending meshed well with the rest of the story world, but I enjoyed spending time with these characters (but what happened to Nate??) and wouldn't say no to a sequel!
PS Works fine on Linux Mint with Proton!
PPS Forgot to mention how great the soundtrack is. Imagine the moody rock from SILENT HILLs 2 and 3 minus the pounding hellscapes. That's the Kathy Rain OST.

70645174.review:
A great point & click adventure game in the veins of old mystery classics of the genre, Kathy Rain is an impressive debut from developer Clifftop Games. 

Taking the role of a journalism student (the aformentioned Kathy), a biker girl with an attitude, you set off to discover the mystery behind the death of your grandfather and getting entagled in a much more sinister situation than you initially suspected, uncovering secrets and skeletons of the past. Kathy herself is a very interesting character, at first somewhat unlikeable, with attitude problems, yet so wonderfully written, a different protagonist than the usual goody-two-shoes, and as you uncover more of her past and her personal demons that haunt her it makes for a very intricate and believable, flawed but relatable character. The writing and narrative remains strong for most of the game, although because of the more surreal elements the story contains, with the most obvious inspirations being David Lynch and the cult show Twin Peaks it might not be for everyone.

Gameplay is another excellent aspect, with very interesting puzzles, that can range from simplistic to a couple of more complex head-scratchers , but never requiring "moon-logic", always clever and making sense (and I really loved the idea of the journalism notebook that adds one more layer of clues besides your traditional inventory) Overall, it's your typical point&click fare, with clear view of the environments, no need for pixel hunting.

Regarding the... pixels, be aware that this game is running in a specific older engine and has the aesthetic of an old-school adventure game. Do not go in expecting high fidelity/high res graphics and in all honesty, for most fans of the genre, little does it matter. What matters is that even in their low res glory, characters and environments look beautiful and vibrant, with a nice variety of locations and characters to talk to. 
Music is quite nice but perhaps a mixed bag, with the more "normal" tracks being serviceable, nice to lsiten to though not anything special, but I really loved the tracks when the story was taking a more mysterious and horror-esque approach, with distorted or slow atmospheric synth music (very reminiscent of the previously mentioned Twin Peaks for example).
It is also fully voiced with most of the actors giving a pretty good performance, and snarky Kathy herself being really fun to listen to. 

Kathy Rain is a really great addition for your point&click library and I was really happy to see that more studios besides fan-favorite Wadjet-Eye can deliver some high quality games that keep the genre alive and move forward. It's a game with great characters, intricate plot, nice puzzles and brooding atmosphere, that also knows when to have fun.

70462299.review: Kathy Rain was a great experience for a casual gamer like me. The story immerses you and takes you on a WILD ride. 70200448.review:
[b] Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay is one of the two strongest areas in Kathy Rain. It plays like a classic point and click adventure but doesn’t have any on the normal downsides. You won’t find any pixel hunting or nonsensical puzzles in this game. The tooltips that appear with items and the game's way of interacting with objects allows you to interact with a lot of things on the screen but helps the most important ones stand out. None of the puzzles that you’ll encounter require any sort of off the wall thinking either. They can all be solved with a little attention and perseverance, and if you seem to be stuck Kathy will help by dropping hint.

[b] Graphics [/b]
The game’s graphics are its second strong point. Taking cues from classic 90s point-and-click games like Full Throttle and Gabriel Knight the game boasts an impressive pixel art style. The locations in the game all look excellent and the dreary gloominess of the outdoor areas plays great against the more brightly lit and colorful indoor areas. Even the large character portraits shown during dialogue look great.

[b] Music/Sound [/b]
Music is one area that I feel that game falls short. It isn’t bad, just not very memorable or helpful in adding to the atmosphere of the game at all. There is even an achievement you get for letting the travel music loop and I still couldn’t hum that song for you. The voiceovers on the other hand are fantastic! I went into this game as I do with most games from smaller studios expecting the voice acting to not be well done, however, Kathy Rain does an excellent job. Kathy’s interactions with other characters and the dialogue she has with herself while examining and using items sound great and natural.

[b] Story/Writing [/b]
The story in Kathy Rain is a great mix of paranormal and mystery and handles them both very well. The way the paranormal aspects intertwines with the “real-life” mystery aspect is handled very well. It falls short in the last chapter however and leans too heavily into the paranormal aspect of the tale. I think it would have benefited from an extra chapter to help tie up both sides a little more smoothly. The writing on the other hand is great and all the interactions with Kathy and the other characters are fun and interesting. Every character has their own unique personality and Kathy herself is very memorable.



[b] Final Thoughts [/b]
Overall, I thought Kathy Rain was an excellent game and is exactly what the more current generation of point-and-click games should strive to be. With only a small handful of flaws that are easily ignored this game is a must-play for any point-and-click adventure fan. If this is what Clifftop Games gives us on their first outing, I look forward to seeing what they can do in the future.

70171321.review:
Overall a yes, this was a beautiful 90s-inspired retro P&C detective game with great writing and an interesting (albeit pretty weird) plot. I enjoyed the main character, who is smart and takes no shit from anybody. Sass for miles. Smokes like a chimney and rides a hog. The pixel art itself was fantastic and the voiceovers are quality. I don't feel like the puzzles were too obscure as far as P&Cs go, but there is no hint system in-game if you do get stuck. It's suggested during the game that a sequel may be in the future, which I would be interested in. I understand that there is also a mobile version.

I will put a minor warning label for anyone who is extremely sensitive about family trauma, Christian religion, and [spoiler]abortion[/spoiler] as the plot features all of this prominently.

The only trouble I had was with the technical aspects of the game. It is retro-inspired and so are all the video and menu options. Modern widescreen monitors will have black bars on either side. I experienced a bit of stuttering at times with this game and I'm not exactly sure why, but thankfully it was never unplayable for me.

70061623.review:
[i]'Only those who will risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go' - T S Eliot[/i]

Before I get into this review it's probably worth putting it out there the [strike]shopping list[/strike] few things that may rub some players the wrong way.  

[list]
    [*]Cussing - Kathy Rain's favourite colour is blue
    [*]Anti-Religious - Kathy Rain is yet to 'find God' though to be fair she is only starting out as a Detective
    [*]Smoking - Kathy Rain loved Jim Carrey in the Mask
    [*]Sexists - The only T(ea) you'll see Kathy Rain associated with is on a Scrabble board.
    [*]Biker Chick - Kathy Rain knows her way around a Chopper
    [*]Sassy - Kathy Rain has more comebacks than Rocky Balboa
    [*]Rebellious - Keep your teddy bears near a smoke alarm
    [*]PC world - Kathy Rain is as Politically Correct as Trump during his press conferences
    [*]Disabilities - Kathy Rain has a love of wheelchair racing
    [*]Self Defence - Kathy Rain has some electrifying moves
[/list]

Now that's out of the way... 

[b]Kathy Rain[/b] is a Journalist Major who discovers, through her [u]C[/u]harmingly [u]R[/u]esourceful, [u]E[/u]ver [u]E[/u]ager, [u]P[/u]uritanical [u]Y[/u]oung roommate that her Grandpa has died prompting Kathy to return to a hometown she hasn't seen since a child. 
Having reunited with her Grandma, Kathy finds her Grandpa's death suspicious & sets out to investigate what really happened which leads her through a maze of mysteries surrounding the Town and a plethora of puzzling discoveries that propel Kathy Rain towards a [i]mind blowing[/i] conclusion spread over a 5 day period. 

The story builds to a good pace and is intriguing enough to hold your interest throughout the 4 day period but come the final, fifth, day it went all [strike]Pete Tong[/strike] mystical with heavy David Lynch references (though they were subtle throughout when showing [u]The Red Man[/u]) and ended up having [i]Kathy Rain[/i] confront a dark episode from her past to resolve the mystery that, oddly, leaves some areas unanswered outside of Kathy & her family.  This isn't a deal breaker because earlier scenes in Day 4 do touch on some of the other uncovered character's mysteries but overall there are noticeable areas of the plot left aside such as [b]Nathan[/b] who [spoiler]disappears after Day 3[/spoiler]. 

The pixel art works brilliantly at reflecting the time period of the 90's with a lot of nostalgic, retro items being used in the detective work such as: a dictaphone, landline phones with no signs of Mobiles, retro computers alongside typewriters, gramophones instead of stereos, Aerial TV boxes and many more including reference to board games like Scrabble. Posters in their dorm room were also a great touch showing classic movies from the mid-late 90's.
I was surprised no music references were used but I appreciate licencing would've been an issue though the synthetic retro sound was excellent BGM as it wasn't too overpowering and helped prevent from distracting the game-play.
Adding to the sounds, there were good use of Sound Effects and I loved the VA as I find that always helps massively when it comes to immersion, every Voice Actor was equally superb which truly made the experience that much more enjoyable.

The puzzles are all varied and started off being not too challenging for the first 3 days then come the final 2 days they upped the ante and the puzzles got a lot more trickier to solve involving date manipulation & number coding. 
There were also moments where items would be required to help [i]Kathy Rain[/i] get out of predicaments which, again, started off straight forward for the first 3 days yet come the final two days it became more a case of thinking outside the box or a tedious case of elimination. 

There are a good variety of locations to travel to throughout the 5 days that are all easily accessible through selecting a thumbnail image of the location while [i]Kathy Rain[/i] is hitting the road on her Chopper. When all locations are exhausted they show as greyed out making it a much easier experience if you're caught up in where to go/what to do next. 
During the locations there are familiar welcomes from characters alongside changing scripts as the plot progresses while a lot of [i]Kathy Rain's[/i] humour is clear throughout it also wonderfully portrays other characters personalities too making them easy to invest in when seeing their reactions to [i]Kathy Rain's[/i] multi-choice options for character interaction.

There are achievements throughout though I found, again spot the recurring theme, more was involved within the 3 days compared to the final 2 days; there were a variety of interactions to discover through the 3 days that unlocked Achievements yet the final 2 days had none only the completion of that day. This was a bit surprising as I felt there could've been Achievements used in the last 2 days particularly to unlock when you solve the tougher puzzles so I get the vibe that the final 2 days were centred around rounding up the story when it couldn't hurt to have continued the involvements being seen in the 3 days prior.  It kind of left a bad taste of feeling rushed towards the ending and wanting to get it all over & done with for the Devs as it was unbalanced compared to the other 3/5 of the game. 

The price can seem a bit high for a PnC pixelated mystery so it may be worth looking out for a discount if you can't justify the price tag compared to other games on your wish-list but I think it is fair to say this is done to a high standard and is a very enjoyable game full of nostalgia, mystery and edgy humour.

69973809.review:
As a long-time adventure game fan, I was pleasantly surprised by Kathy Rain. Mechanically, it is typical of its genre -- largely devoid of mechanics that might considered unique. However, I felt that its use of the standard conceits was very respectable, and I think I'd say the same for its bounty of nods to its inspirational source material (Twin Peaks, if it hadn't passed in front of yours yet). Art and voice-acting are better than average across the board, but I feel like the real beauty of both elements is that they match the time period so well -- it really looks and feels like a game I would have played back in '95, in a positive sense. Very good for helping set the tone.
When it comes to point-and-click adventure games, though, the thing that most separates the good from the mediocre for me are the puzzles. It is very tricky to design puzzles in such a way that they are both sufficiently hinted in the context of the game itself and still challenging enough that the hints don't make the solution immediately obvious. I'm happy to say that a handful of puzzles actually took me a few attempts or traveling around to find the solution, and I only needed to check online for spoilers a few times (twice were just because I completely forgot about certain mechanics, which was my bad. Only once was a puzzle obscure enough that I needed the solution reasoning explained, and even then I just felt like an idiot because it was kind of obvious in retrospect).
Plot-wise, I think the intro was nice and interesting and the middle portion was great while the final portion was actually very impressive right up until it was finished, almost abruptly. The story flows well, I think, and most of the characters were quite likable. There were a few instances of controversial subject matter, but I feel that they were handled quite tastefully.
I know that it's been a while and the developer has made Whispers of a Machine since then, but I can definitely say that I would love a Kathy Rain sequel if they ever get around to it! There is a lot of potential there and I'd love to continue following the quirky characters introduced here.

69973070.review: A very fun point&clicker with an interesting story and characters, and a Twin Peaks vibe. I particularly liked the fact that the game gives some subtle hints to the more obscure puzzles, so it was a fun ride with few roadblocks. Recommended.

69961735.review:
En Kathy Rain, conoceremos a una joven estudiante cuyo nombre se le da título al juego. Kathy, acaba de enterarse del fallecimiento de su abuelo, al que hace varios años que no ve por motivos personales, por lo que decide viajar al pueblo donde se crió, para asistir al funeral y pasar un tiempo con sus familiares. Aunque esperaba encontrar una simple visita rutinaria, sin comerlo ni beberlo termina involucrada en una trama cada vez más oscura y enrevesada, en la que tendrá que enfrentarse a su propio pasado y a varios secretos que salen a la luz.

Nos encontramos ante una aventura gráfica tradicional, de las de Point and click y combinar objetos de toda la vida.

El gran atractivo reside en su historia, ambientada a mediados de los 90, la cual al principio comienza de forma realista ,pero poco a poco, empieza a girar hacia una vertiente más surrealista. Tambien ,a destacar del juego sus graficos pixel art.

Por el lado negativo,.el juego viene con un pequeno bug....y es que, aunque cambiemos el idioma original que viene en ingles, al español...cada vez que se vuelve a iniciar el juego,vuelve a estar en ingles...eso si,el idioma es solo para los textos ya que los audios son totalmente  en ingles.Los puzzles no son dificiles...aunque haya un par de puñeteros....eso si,te tocara dar varias vueltas hasta que encuentres el escenario donde vale ese objeto(al menos, cuando haya varias localizaciones)

68976374.review: A wonderfully bizarre lo-res 90's throwback. I expected a down and dirty mystery, and I got that more or less. It veers wildly towards the end, but it just about keeps it together. Several threads are left unwoven, and others are only slightly tugged at, but the piece as a whole left me thinking of what's to come next from Clifftop Games and Kathy Rain. The voice acting is top notch and most of the characters are fully fleshed out. A few puzzles miss the mark, especially if you don't live in the USA, but the majority are perfectly logical. The lo-res graphics give it the throwback feel it aims for, and is helped by the 90's setting with some pop-culture references thrown in for good measure.

68736104.review:
Mehhh. I'm a big fan of point and click adentures, so I appreciate what this one was going for, but it missed the mark for me. The story was intriguing at first, but it went nowhere. The characters were generic, one dimensional, and forgettable.  The tone was all over the place. The content of the dialogue was like a rollercoaster ride from G to NC-17, and I have no problem with either, but here, whenever a character called someone a  b***h or a c**t it felt random and forced. The music, while sometimes good, often felt ill suited to the atmosphere and/or era. And as a modern game, couldn't they have streamlined it a little? Like, when I quadruple click on the exit, do I really need to watch Kathy slowly walk all the way across the room to leave the location? UGH. 

Anyways, I don't mean to sound overly negative. I appreciate the effort, and I love that they attempted to make a paranormal murder mystery set in the 1990's...but it was a frustrating playthrough for me.

5/10

(Btw the 33 hours playtime is greatly exaggerated. I fell asleep countless times while playing it...although I tend to do that regardless of my enjoyment of the game)

68701211.review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6142328/][b]Like this Review? Follow The Cpt Froggy Club Curator Page for plenty more![/b][/url][/quote]


While Attending College as a journalism major, Kathy Rain gets news from her roommate that her grandfather has passed away and that his funeral is the following day. Returning to the town of Conwell Springs where she grew up so many years ago, she attends the funeral, after which she rekindles a relationship with her grandmother. There is much to catch up on after a decade and a half away; with everything she learns her inner detective is enticed by the mystery of what happened to her grandfather. She begins her own investigation.  As she explores the town and meets its residents you will uncover your grandfather's past and the town's hidden secrets. There are ominous forces at play, and piecing the truth will be an adventure you will not soon forget.

Released on May 5, 2015, by the developer Clifftop Games and Published by Raw Fury, it is tagged as Point & Click, Adventure, Pixel Graphics, Detective; I have added no additional tags. It features an incredible story that is not easy to piece together; you will be challenged to think outside the box. The voice acting is nothing short of exceptional and very enjoyable with over 4000 lines of dialogue. The gorgeous pixel art is top-notch; meticulous work went into its design and this shines through as you play with 40 hand-drawn environments to explore as you piece together the clues. An original soundtrack also accompanies the title.

The only thing I didn't like about the title was the hint system; it really didn't work much as a hint system and was not very useful. I would have liked to have more options to control the graphic and volume settings.

I must say this has been quite an impressive title, and I have had a blast so far in gameplay. As I near the end of the game I kind of hate to see it end, and have been savoring it trying to prolong it as much as I can. The Atmosphere in the game has kept me locked to my screen hours at a time. The dynamics of the title are unique for a point and click, and I have had a riot figuring them out as I play. I think I loved the cut scenes of her riding her motorcycle the most; a very different way to approach moving between levels. I have enjoyed every aspect of the game; the artwork is just OMG, and I often found myself just exploring the scenes. The voice acting - what can I say, I had to yell at the family to hush a couple of times because they were too loud. I would instantly buy a part two, just to be able to spend a little more time with Kathy Rain. That is kind of creepy I know, but what a character they created. 

Kathy Rain: A Young Journalist Journeys to Discover the Truth of her Grandfather’s Death.

Pro's
+ Fantastic Pixel Graphics
+ Outstanding Voice Acting
+ Wild Story Line
+ Steam Trading Cards
+ Steam Achievements 

Cons 
- Hint System Could use Work
- Light on Settings

9/10
Key provided by the developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!
