68649516.review:
Kathy Rain is a point-and-click adventure game reminiscent of old-school classics by LucasArts and Sierra Games, or recent WadjetEye games. It is also the first video game developed by Clifftop Games, and one that has been on my radar for a long time since it won lots of accolades at The Aggie Awards 2016 and my peers praised it a lot.

The story is set in the ‘90s and follows, you guessed it, Kathy Rain, a journalism student with a rebellious attitude who travels to her hometown to witness her grandfather put to rest. On this special occasion, Kathy reunites with her widowed grandmother who informs her that her grandfather was in a vegetative state for almost all of her time away after he investigated the suspicious drowning of a teenage girl back in the day. Loaded by guilt and a desire to fix the past, Kathy takes it upon herself to close this unsolved case. 

With this premise, one of the first things that surprised me was how quickly the story picks up and unfolds along the way. Some adventure games tend to be a slow burner with their exposition dump in the beginning, but the same cannot be said about Kathy Rain. This is not a praise nor a criticism, but rather an observation. Kathy jumps on the case straightaway, without hesitations nor any external distractions. Off she goes! Nonetheless, the overall story should keep you invested until the end, with some very good plot twists, but there is a stark change in its tone and atmosphere near the end as events turn supernatural, bleak and a tad metaphorical with its religious undertones. However, the justification of this change is in the eye of the beholder since, without any spoilers, I personally thought it went in the direction foreshadowed early on in the game, for the most part.

Whilst the narrative holds up strongly throughout the game, I do have some criticisms directed at it, though. Firstly, it is very predictable who one of the main culprits is in the story, almost right from the first encounter. Additionally, to my disappointment, some explanations in the final two acts remain vague at best and some mysteries are still left unsolved, especially since the story features an enigmatic boogieman character who is clearly pulling the strings. Lastly, there is a hot topic which the game touches upon very briefly regarding Kathy’s past which I feel it does not add much to the story and probably should have been left out as it might rub some people the wrong way. Ultimately, Kathy does close the case regarding her grandfather successfully (and thus a detective is born!), but the game concludes with an open-ending for that sequel bait. Gratefully, I am actually in favour for more Kathy Rain adventures. When will we see them, no one knows at this point.

The general gameplay in Kathy Rain uses traditional point-and-click mechanics where you talk to characters to unlock new topics of discussion, obtain and use items found in environments, and solve brain teasing puzzles, to advance the plot. In all fairness, Gabriel Knight and Cognition were a lot on my mind whilst playing Kathy Rain, since both gave similar detective vibes and most likely were inspirations to this game. Heck, even the Blackwell series. Depending how fast you solve the puzzles, Kathy Rain is more or less a short game, clocking somewhere between four to seven hours. Since the story did keep me hooked, this might have the side effect of making you want more, thus making its short length a letdown in someone’s books; which, sadly, it did for me. Thankfully, the puzzles, which are not abundant, are fairly straightforward and logical in most instances, give or take one or two. Some are fairly clever I must add, whilst others are a bit of a trial-and-error.

Visually, Kathy Rain’s stylised retro look, akin to point-and-click adventure games built on the AGS engine, is solid and consistent, to a point where you might even mistaken it for a recent WadjetEye game. The environments are vivid and aesthetically pleasing, even if they become quite sombre near the end. Whilst there is not a huge lot of interactivity with said environments, they pack a good amount detail without leading to the dreadful pixel-hunting. Personally, I felt there is a fair bit of backtracking between its nine available locations in the story for my tastes, which is why to some it might feel like the world is very confined, which it is to some degree.

Another thing that feels somewhat confined is the cast of characters, which frankly is not immense, but they sure are fun and have distinctive personalities. I will not be dissecting each one of them for this review, but I can say that Kathy, as the main protagonist, is undoubtedly memorable. To me, her dialogues feel natural, as I recall, and I am full of joy to see she did not fall in the trap of feeling forced just because she is a female protagonist. In spite of her tough attitude, mixed with some rudeness for good measure, and a somewhat edgy, trademark-ish, appearance for her time period, she does show her human side enough to sympathise with her. There is also clear character development when she starts questioning her past and life choices in the second half of the game. Given more time to grow, Kathy has the potential to rank up to the greats such as April Ryan (The Longest Journey), Kate Walker (Syberia), Rosa Blackwell (Blackwell) and Erica Reed (Cognition), to name a few.

Sometimes the voice acting can be shoddy in certain adventure games due to their budget, but rest assure that Kathy Rain’s is definitely in the good tier. My experience and immersion were not ruined by anyone as far as I remember, but, of course, your mileage may vary. Initially, I thought the soundtrack is decent at best, but after a second thought, the soundtrack is unfortunately forgettable. It hardly grabbed my attention, but I will say that it fit certain scenes fine when setting up the atmosphere at least.

In conclusion, I admit that I went in with very high expectations due to the hype surrounding it, and I am thankful to report that Kathy Rain is a very good and enjoyable game for its genre, so fans of this genre should definitely pick it up at some point. I would not go as far as calling it one of the greatest point-and-click adventure games ever made as some may suggest, but I definitely look forward to seeing more adventures with Kathy in the near future. For their first game, Clifftop Games did a fantastic job in building a solid foundation for a potentially new amazing franchise in the point-and-click adventure genre, which is why I may let some of its flaws that I mentioned slide this time around.

68473342.review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 5.3h (based on steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (15 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Developer Response:[/b] Yes (~24h, on selected threads).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[i]Kathy Rain[/i] is a point-and-click game about a girl who is trying to find out what happened to her recently deceased grandfather. The story is separated into 5 in-game days.

Pros:
- Voice dubbing in all dialogues
- Some dialogue choices give a different response to the conversations

Cons:
- No hints in case you're stuck
- Some mysteries aren't fully explained

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]It's a decent point-and-click game that can last for ~5 hours. If you like point-and-click games, you can buy this at a discount.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game uses a mix of 2D sprite graphics with an over zoomed background and portrait images that make them look pixelated. It might be annoying at first because the background might look better in full resolution, but you'll get used to it.

Leaving the backgrounds aside, the sprites look fine. I like how the sprite animations aren't just limited to walking; they also cover some parts when the character is expressing her emotions such as crying and smoking.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Just like other point-and-click games, this game focuses on its story. You'll mostly ask people around to gather clues and unlock more conversations. There are even times when you'll have to choose between several options. I'm not sure if there is an option that will change the storyline that much, but all of the options that I chose only change the responses a bit and add a bit of information about the characters.

However, despite all that, most of the mystery remains unsolved. I'm not sure if the game is doing it on purpose for a sequel material, but it bugs me because I still have a lot of questions unanswered after I finished the game, especially in the last 2 days where more questions are popping out.

There are also times when most of the things are unexplained and people are talking as if I'm supposed to know it beforehand. I even thought that this game is a sequel to another game because of this.

[h1]The game[/h1]
[b]Exploration[/b]
The game has several areas to explore that can be done by clicking through the images in the "overworld" screen. You can hover your cursor around to see any interactable objects and there will be an option to look, think, and take action with the item if it's possible to do so. Actually, looking and thinking isn't that different; they just give a different text for you to read.

Sometimes, there is an important dialogue that I accidentally skipped because I clicked somewhere in the map to inspect an item when the dialogue suddenly popped out. There is also no hint button or whatsoever that can help you with this. The game also never tells you what to do next so it can be troublesome if you don't play the game in one sitting since you'll have no idea what to do.

[b]Items[/b]
There are a lot of items that you can pick up. It's obvious as to what items to use in the first few days although I can't say the same for the last few days. Luckily, the game helps a bit by discarding unused items from your inventory as the story progresses.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
This game doesn't have a lot of puzzles. However, I could never solve it whenever one showed up. I ended up reading a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=670789337]guide[/url] a lot just to solve this.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's an okay point-and-click game with no hints and difficult puzzles. It's mostly focused on its story even though some parts are a bit vague. If you're into making theories, you'll have a blast with it.

68422756.review:
I 50% love this game and 50% don't love this game. Getting it at an at least 50% sale price would seem fair since the creators only seem to have put half effort in it. 

The first half of the game is AMAZING. I love the 90's feel of it. The computer in the dorm, the landline phones, the tape player. The voice-acting is mostly pretty good (not you, grandma) and I love the way it sets up the mystery and how you investigate. Good old point-and-click humour too.  But halfway through the story the writers just... Seemed to have given up.

The ending feels incredibly rushed. It completely changes the whole feeling of the game DRASTICALLY with the supernatural touch. [spoiler] I was half hoping we would end up debunking it. The whole game sets up Kathy to be very atheistic so it would fit with her character. [/spoiler]

Not gonna lie, I don't find Kathy a likable protagonist even. She's rude and a cliché hard-ass. The times where they would make her emotional felt forced. [spoiler] The abandoning dad thing is alright, but the fact that she seems to be a clone of him with the whole tough bikerthing also seems cliché. The abortion business was absolutely unnecessary. And for a subject that loaded it was as quickly brushed aside as the whole pregnancy itself. [/spoiler] I also find it hard to put an age on her. She is in college, but rides a motorbike and behaves like an adult?

I also played the other game from this creator and story-wise it ended the same. Amazing introduction, made me excited to explore the world, only for it to be finished as if they ran out of time or inspiration. It's a shame, because there is immense potential.

Still I wouldn't recommend skipping this game as it definitely gave me a good 3,5 hours of fun and hopefully if we buy more of this creator they get the chance to make more like this (but with improved storywriting).

68113600.review:
Definitely would recommend if you enjoyed the Blackwell P&C games and would consider this game to be very close to on-par. 
The graphics, for what they are, are visually beautiful and really help to set moods as they change through the course of the game. The main character appears to be a tad lifeless at the start, but as the game progresses she opens up more and what came across as a bland personality definitely reveals itself as a wall for other people to protect herself.
Over 90% of the puzzles were straightforward enough in that you wouldn't be left boggling over them for more than a few minutes, and the answers were usually right in front of you. However, there are one or two less intuitive ones that could really leave you stumped.
The only real con I could give this game is with the progression of the story plot from (spoiler) [spoiler] getting to the bottom of a death to ending up balls deep in the supernatural [/spoiler] but it wasn't badly done per say, just very unexpected.
The last thing I would say is that the story plot does possess at least two potential triggers with visual (and graphic) representation (spoilers) [spoiler] which is suicide and abortion [/spoiler] so this game might not be you if those topics are likely to cause you any discomfort. 

Overall, I really enjoyed it and definitely found it emotion-provoking, fun to progress through and will likely do another run for the rest of the achievements.

Rant:
A casual game with colorful graphics and voice-acting. Likable characters and decent story.
I have seen people say this game has set itself up for a sequel. And while it's true there are questions left unanswered by the end of the game, I don't think a sequel is necessary. One can derive a lot simply by observing the subtext, and I like the fact the story doesn't spoon-feed all the backstory. Speculation is part of the fun.

Truthfully I had troubles starting the game as I'm one that struggles with pixel graphics with the advancement we've made in visuals. I know it's part of an art form, but doesn't mean it's everyone's style. This said, looking past that the game has an interesting story, and is intriguing. 
It's a point and click, and with that do note that it's best to [b] click everything! [/b]
The puzzles aren't to challenging, and some do require a lot of back and forth.

It's potato computer friendly, great voice acting, a short game if you do it one sitting -- and can easily 100% the achievements if that's something you're interested in.

66366166.review:
A classic style adventure game, both in art, and sensibilities. It's very much a throwback to the SCUMM era of games, but reminds me most strongly of Gabriel Knight. It features a moody 90's protagonist both poking around police stations, bars, graveyards, lakes and private residences. Without spoilers you might want to know that things get rather Twin Peaks. Some folks have expected a very grounded detective game and been disappointed. 

The story is engaging, the acting is solid, the characters are vivid. The puzzles are pretty sensible without any moon logic or much pixel hunting. Pacing and length are appropriate for this type of game, I finish in about 8 hours. The nostalgia appeal is enormous, but the game taken on it's own is solid enough to be appreciated by people who didn't grow up with games like this.

66253997.review:
I loved this game! Especially as an adventure point and click. It doesn't embrace the many sins of the genre: the game is not hardcore pixel-hunting, and all the puzzles are logical (with only one exception - the mausoleum puzzle was a bit too vague).
The graphics are amazing and I loved how smooth the 3D parts (the backgrounds' base) were, and how well they blended with 2D ones (character sprites, some elements of the backround). Better than in the actual 90s! It helped to create that special 90s feel, though. The atmosphere here is thick as well as the mysteries we have to encounter.
The voice acting was on point, it depicted the characters very well, so did their amazing detailed portraits. The music was eerie when needed to be and relaxing when needed to be. It matched the graphics perfectly. The embodiment of said perfection is the riding scene. I do want to watch it for 10 hours straight, it's SO good.
Sassy Kathy is a likable protagonist and snark isn't all the character she has. She is imperfect, like any person, and she is very humane and human in her behavior. I liked the fact that we could choose some of her reacions and replies and thus tweak her a little.
The plot was well-structured and spiraled into climax towards the end like every good drama should. The ending hasn't answered all the questions but it didn't feel frustrating. It left the player wanting for more. It would be a great series!

Aside from this, I enjoy mysteries although rarely play mystery games. Go find the free game Metaphobia on Steam and play that first or instead.

Kathy Rain is OK, it's better than the Blackwell games in my opinion but also shares a lot their faults. Kathy Rain as a character sucks, she is tedious and cliched, as are all the characters in this game, I understand that this game is a love letter to the 90's but c'mon have the balls to break the mould and do something interesting and innovative. The story plods along and is occasionally broken up by simple puzzles which usually means do the thing you were told to do or do the thing you said you would do.

Something that seriously irritates me is that every time someone talks there is a close up of their face but it has obviously been made by a different artist as it looks like a completely different person just with the same hair colour. As an example look at the pictures above and tell me if Kathy is a tiny anorexic emo white girl with small dark eyes and a piercing or is full figured, strong with big pouty lips and has bright blue eye makeup? I cannot believe two artists working on the same game were not allowed to look at each others work in order to give characters consistency, for me it just shows a lack of love or care.

Metaphobia is a free game and easily as good as Kathy Rain as it is incredibly similar in terms of game play, metaphobia is less cheesy 90's but Kathy Rain is longer and has a better ending. If you enjoyed Metaphobia and want more of something similar then buy Kathy Rain, if not then I have hopefully I just saved you £10.99

I picked up this game because of the graphics. Indeed it has a very nice and comfy VGA look to it and it's very pleasant.

If that was not enough the story is peppered with SJW politics. Listen, I know the game is aimed at females primarily, but do we really have to make every male character either dumb, inefficient or just evil?

There are a rather limited number of  locations in the game and the back and forth between them (on the bike) becomes very tedious after a while.

Like I said most of the time, the gameplay just consists in going through all the topics in your notebook with every character youcan speak to. Except toward the end of the game where you're faced with puzzles that you can absolutely not solve without the help of a walkthrough.

63693269.review:
I came at Kathy Rain from the wrong direction - after playing Whispers of a Machine. WOAM is a far better game: more innovative, tighter pathing, more logical puzzles, more interesting setting.

That said, Kathy Rain is worth your time. The mid-90s setting is hilarious for those of us who grew up then, especially the anachronisms (Kathy looks like a cross between a stock metalhead from an 80s fighting game and an aughts Scene Girl). The lack of analog cell phone communication or even pagers is pretty funny, since everyone I knew had at least one of those by '95. I'd like to see more of this bizarre alt-90s in future games, and KR leaves plenty of room for sequels. Oh, and the voice acting is pretty spectacular for such a small production.

Criticisms,  I have a few. KR gets a bit hefty on the moon logic toward the second half of the game, but this is standard fare for the titles of the time that this is referencing. The game could have done with two or three more locations with unique settings to give its later scenes some gravitas. There was way too much re-treading.

Good stuff. Looking forward to the inevitable sequels.

62808653.review:
This is tough. It ticks all the pixely p&c adventure boxes. But only ticks, it doesn't excel at anything. It's competent, doesn't have ridiculous leaps of logic, being able to deadlock and just generally everything sort of fits. It could have been bad, but it's at least decent. The theme and ending are just a mess, everything happens too quickly and things aren't even explained well. Art is nice, but often inconsistent, there are so few locations, and almost all the puzzle-solve payoff animations/action are skipped. Gameplay is decent, but it has some of that clunky early p&c feel. The religious themes also put me off a lot, even if there wasn't much of them. There was a lot of cool stuff, but that's mostly what it is -- a string of cool stuff. Grab it on a sale if you are a die-hard p&c fan and have to play all the decent ones. But this just didn't quite strike it with me. It didn't go all the way on many concepts, even if it boldly stepped in the right directions. I feel sad giving this a negative review, but it just barely misses the recommendation mark. There are a lot of superior pixely p&c games out there, so this one's really there if you have run out of games to play.

Also, it's not 2000 and the game should really have proper resolution support and stretching instead of messing with full screen. And no anytime pause, which means you could miss things. Also horrible alt+tabbing bugs.

61963034.review:
I have a lot of issues with this game, most specifically the titular character, Kathy, the plot and the puzzles. This game tries very hard to be story and character driven, and it really doesn't work. 

Let's start with Kathy. She is your typical "I'm the bad girl/Not like other girls" trope, with an extra side of mean. Which made her super uninteresting. I was more interested in Eileen(Kathy's roommate)  who had way more of a real personality than Kathy did. I also felt awful for Goober, who seemed to constantly be getting the short end of the stick, even getting stun-gunned by Kathy herself at one point in the game. 

Which brings me to my next point, the story. Good god...Um. In a story driven game, you think the main focus would have been story? You get to the final day, you play through it and the game just kind of ends? This whole thing with her mom and dad was set up, briefly touched upon and then never talked about again. She was literally in the same mental institution as her mom, and didn't even bother to say hi..Also, we never learned about what happened to her father? He's in Mexico! Probably! Maybe? I dunno. If it wasn't so important to Kathy's character I wouldn't bring it up. 

Now, finally..the puzzles. They're way too easy? I really only got stuck on the one in the cemetery towards the end. I was expecting zany puzzles with zany solutions? And the puzzles were pretty tame and the solutions (Besides literally tazing someone) were even tamer. 

I recommend Kathy Rain if you're looking for easy achievements and a game that you only really play once and  then uninstall, forever doomed to your steam library.

61454464.review: A solid little retro graphic adventure in the old LucasArts mold.  Gameplay wise it takes most of its cues from the likes of Full Throttle and wears it's influences on its sleeve - Kathy rides around on a custom Corley for instance.  Story and tone remind me a lot of the first Gabriel Knight - a mundane mystery that dips further into the supernatural as things progress.  The puzzles are a bit of a weak point - most are pretty straight forward inventory and dialogue based affairs with only one moderately tricky three part riddle towards the very end.  For the most part though, if you talk to everyone and click / pick up everything like any adventure gamer, you'll probably breeze through most of the game without any issues.  On the whole, a solid pick up for anyone who likes 90s style adventure games.

61169164.review:
Although I enjoyed the game, I had much higher expectations about it. 
The beginning of the game gets you hooked on right away, the plot thickens as you get further, all the characters seem genuine and engaging. I personally like the main character a lot, Kathy Rain is an example of a well-written female protagonist. And also she's cool, you know, the thing an edgy goof like me appreciate on a deeply spiritual level. 
So at first, I thought the only thing I would nag about would be not so great voice acting. Like it's not a Phantasmagoria level of bad acting, but it's still pretty far from ideal. There is only one character whos voice acting I think is pretty good and it's the Crimson Ones. Others are not so great, and Kathy's grandma sounds like she doesn't give a single f. about her deceased husband. 
But unfortunately, the game has one more flaw, and this one is pretty big. The ending is kinda... meh, whatever.  And it's not about the mystical part of the game, I personally loved the atmosphere of David Lynch's films surrounding it, it's just the ending feels bland. Another thing is there are so many subplots and plot-twists that appeared alongside the main story, that in the end, they all feel rushed and underdeveloped. I won't spoiler anything in this review, find out it yourself if you're willing. 
Still, despite being somewhat disappointed about the ending, I can't say that the game is bad. It's definitely not. And you should play it. It's an interesting little quest for your evening. Just don't expect too much from it.

60862913.review:
[h1]The story of a young journalistic student[/h1]

Kathy Rain is a game in which we control a young woman with the same name as the game title. Our goal is to solve the mystery of the death of the main character's grandfather. To do that, we will have to conduct an investigation... 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Kathy Rain is a classic point&click adventure game played in the 90s.. All we need in the game is a mouse. At our disposal is a bag of equipment, which is a bag with various things. At the beginning we only get a notebook, lighter and cigarettes. In addition, during the game, along with the progress we unlock new locations. There is no level or skill system in the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The graphics are pixel-shaped. It is not a disadvantage of the game, of course, but on the contrary, it is an advantage. The graphics introduce an interesting atmosphere and remind the times of the first games, which looked similar. The locations are neatly made, although they are too small for me.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

The music in the game is calm, but in some situations it changes dramatically depending on the situation our character is in. The vocal actors are also worth praising, as they have done a good job and all the dialogues are nice to listen to.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

In general, Kathy Rain is a good game, pleasant, but I think it's too short. The disadvantages of the game are also small locations and puzzles, which are logical but extremely simple. Of course there are more difficult puzzles that require a moment's thinking, but there are few of them. Moreover, the storyline is really good until the end, which is a bit weak. Nevertheless, I recommend buying this game to anyone who likes adventure games and has little time to play. It took me only 3 hours to complete this production.
[b]
✔️Game climate
✔️The plot (beyond the end)
✔️Sound
✔️Graphics
✔️Interesting characters

❌Small locations
❌Logical, but too simple puzzles

[i]Time of completion:  3-4 hours[/i]

[b][u]Rating: 7.5/10[/u][/b]

59925826.review:
Worth playing, though you might wait for a moderate discount. One big caveat: things get pretty dark and traumatic towards the end the game, so it may not be for everyone, and it's [b]definitely not for kids[/b]. This isn't a slightly edgy ghost story, it's messed up.

About ~5h of gameplay if you know your way around the P&C genre. The game is split into 5 "days," and some are more complicated than others. Basic gameplay focuses not so much on combining items to solve puzzles (though there is that) but more on detective work in the style of the [i]Blackwell[/i] series: collect topics in your notebook, talk to folks, work out stuff, go back to talk to folks again, etc. The game makes good use of travel, phone calls, and some 90s-era "high-tech" stuff to add some variety, and it all adds up to a well-built and unique title, with good logic behind all the puzzles.

The overall story got  pretty weird and convoluted, but (a) as a whole it sets up an interesting world that I wouldn't mind revisiting if a sequel came around, and (b) once you get through Day 1 the story is relatively fast-paced. It ain't entirely family friendly, with some morbid themes that approach "psychological horror" vibes, some cusses, etc. Some characters are a bit one-dimensional, and some figure in plot-points in ways that probably aren't entirely PC by today's standards. 

Voicework, pixel art, soundtrack are all swell. Everything ran smoothly on Windows 10.

58304968.review:
Rating: ★★★☆☆

(Can add a star if you're a hardcore Point and Click fan)

============

Review:

Kathy Rain is a good point and click game with a retro look but better UI than the oldies.

I really like the retro look of the game - graphically it's good for what it is. The pixel graphics look nice enough, especially the character portraits and the different locations look nice.

The sounds of the game are fairly limited, but you don't really need many sound effects in a game like this. They do their job just fine - nothing to complain here.

All conversations are voice acted, but the voice acting quality isn't consistent. 

Some voice actors are great, some not so great - the quality can even differ between lines, the same characters voice can be good at times and bad at other times.

The music of the game is good. It fits the detective theme well and creates a nice atmosphere - nothing exceptional, but it works well.

============

I found the story of the game very interesting. Basically Kathy returns to her home town after her grandfather passes away.

She learns things about the past and begins to investigate what led to her grandfathers death. At first it feels relatively realistic, but later on some fantasy elements will appear. Overall, it's a very interesting detective story.

The characters of the game are well designed - there aren't too many of them, but those few that are in the game are quite memorable. I especially liked Kathy's character design - she's a bit of a bad girl but still sensible.

The puzzles of the game are challenging - as they should be. The whole point of games of this genre are the puzzles and the story. Honestly I had to spoil one puzzle because I got stuck for much longer than I expected. =D

============

The game length is about what you expect from a point and click game. I suppose it could be doable in maybe 6 hours if you skip some conversations and don't get stuck and all. But I listened to every conversation and got stuck pretty bad a few times so it took me around 9 hours to finish the game.

I think the length is great - honestly I wouldn't want to spend 20+ hours in a point and click game anyway - so it's pretty close to optimal in my opinion.

But the price does not match the length. It's probably not worth the full price, which is 15€ while I'm writing this review. It's a bit too steep price for such a short game in my opinion.

But I bought it for a few euros during a sale - and it's definitely worth that.

It's a good game - so if you like point and click games, grab it from a sale. 

============

Summary:

The Good 👍
+ Nice pixel graphics
+ Very interesting story
+ Memorable characters
+ Challenging puzzles

The Bad 👎
- Inconsistent voice acting quality
- Price/Length (when not on sale)

57837751.review:
The game has you playing as a girl named Kathy Rain <Shocker> who goes to her old childhood home town after her grandfather dies. Something happened to him before he died that placed him in a catatonic state and you need to figure out what.

The thing that stood out to me is that the game is fully voice acted which is something we don’t see all too often in point and click games. The voice actors for the most part do a really good job. The main character Kathy Rain is actually pretty likable. She’s playfully sarcastic but never so much that she seems like a passive aggressive bitch.

The puzzles are also fun and never feel too hard. I would put Kathy Rain’s puzzles on the easy side but none of the answers ever felt absurd when I figured them out. Something the point and click genre is known for. I did need to look at a guide to find the solution to one puzzle but I say that was more on me then the game. As soon as I understood what the answer was I thought “Oh yea! That makes sense!”

I do have a few negatives.

The default audio balancing is bad. The games music (while fine) is louder than the voice acting which sometimes causes certain scenes to be a mish mash of noise. You can change the voice and music volume in the options menu. Some games have more dynamic audio options with a master volume slider. So that way the music can sit comfortably in the background in certain quieter moments to help set a tone and swell during others to underscore the moment. Kathy Rain could benefit from this.

I do have some problems with the story as well. The game has a pretty interesting 90s detective story with a kind of disjointed feeling ending. The description of the game says that the main character Kathy is quote “a strong-willed journalism major who has to come to terms with her own troubled past” She has not “come to terms with her troubled past” because she spends the ending of the game doing exactly that. The ending of the game felt way to supernatural for the mostly down to earth tone of the game, making it feel disjointed from the rest of the experience. It feels as though the ending was only there as a way to give players more last minute character development from Kathy and to quickly resolve the games plot because of how disjointed it feels. The supernatural elements are also never properly explained. So it almost feels like the game ended on a cliffhanger to hopefully continue the story in a sequel of some kind.

The game was ultimately fun despite its poorly set up ending. It took me about 7hrs to beat and I recommend it. If your not a big fan of point and click games I recommend getting it on a sale. GG

56033329.review:
Kathy Rain is a great example of a game that borrows many parts from the "classic" adventure game format of the late 90s/early 2000s, but rises above some of the more infamous characteristics of the genre. For example, the inventory puzzles are logical and easy to comprehend. For the vast majority of the game, it's very easy to figure out how to progress. I never felt like the game tried to artificially prolong its length. You keep finding new content, new characters, new areas, new parts of the grander story. It stays fresh, maybe a bit short, but sweet. 

Another, a bit more subjective improvement, is the dialogue system. From time to time, you have a traditional dialogue tree, enriched by occasional opportunities to express your character's feeling in a way that you find most suitable, but there's also a new system, which works great - it involves a notepad with a list of important "topics", and having an option to present many items from your inventory to the NPCs. Thanks to these mechanisms, the less important dialogues or dialogue branches are played through very fast. And if you feel stuck, you can click through everything, just in case.

There are many objects that you can interact with just for the sake of it. In some adventure games it can get annoying, since a character tends to just name an object which you've clicked, without expanding your knowledge. But again, not in Kathy Rain! The "unimportant" items add to worldbuilding, or allow you to better understand how your character perceives her surroundings.

The visuals are imitating pixel art, but as far as I can tell, it's only a costume. Character portraits and backgrounds often use thousands of colors at once, a chaotic soup of pixels, which blend with each other in a sometimes jarring way. I'm not sure if that was the best combination of choices, but if the screenshots look fine to you, you won't be bothered. The music can get a bit dark, but usually stays in the background, and while fine, it isn't that memorable. Even if a couple of areas use the same theme, it's not distracting.

I'm not a great voice acting judge, but as far as I can tell, it was fantastic. Arielle Siegel is a great lead, and can definitely sell an edgy teen from the 90s. I'm surprised that pretty much the entire cast of characters was white, and I must admit that their portraits, while great, blend together in my memory. 

I have only two issues with the game. The first one, I believe, is a significant problem - there's no button that would allow you to skip through animations. CTRL, space, escape, mouse buttons... Nothing does anything. Sometimes, your character walks like a turtle, and if you don't know where to look for another clue, you'll have to see how Kathy walks around, closes doors, knocks, leaves or enters a scene, sits down... I've played adventure games that allow you to skip such annoyances, and I'd love to have at least an option to do it here. Especially since there are cutscenes which you can't pause, and you know, sometimes you have to open the door to the mailman.

The second one is very subjective - I'm not a great fan of the story structure, the (IMO) very tired "we start in our world, but slowly spin into the land of symbols, and let the protagonist face their traumas through metaphorical events." While the Kathy's personality and personal background are very well-developed and theme-heavy, it's very difficult for me to care about the plot when the game starts introducing dream sequences, visions, "yes, it doesn't make logical sense, but it's a dream!" encounters, spiritual themes without fair exploration, magical plants and illnesses. I much prefer the opening chapters of the story, which are mostly based in reality and even involve using retro-technology, like phones and an anachronistically powerful computer, with silly hacking software.

When the game stops making use of research, detective work and reasoning, and instead offers you a realm of wonder and supernatural threats (and Kathy just goes with it, I mean, who cares that gods and magic exists!), I just can't help but think... I've been here, done that. So many, many times. 

Playing this game as a teen must be absolutely awesome, though. And the dialogues often feel natural, giving you exposition in a very respectable manner, allowing you to process information through visuals and hints, rather than making avalanches of "let me tell you all the entire story of my life." Also, I'm not a big fan of full-comedy games, and unlike many adventure tittles, this one keeps the puns rather short. The humor adds to the characters and supports pacing, but doesn't try to overtake the spotlight.

Very strong 8/10.

55624749.review:
[quote=Wasterbull] Indie Game [/quote]

[i]Una joya de Point & Click que homenajea a los clásicos de 90s[/i]

[h1] SINOPSIS[/h1]
[h1][code][i]En la época de los 90s, Kathy Rain, una estudiante de periodismo bastante ruda y con pasado problemático se entera de la muerte de su abuelo y debe asistir al funeral en su ciudad natal Conwell Springs. Al llegar, empieza a descubrir cosas extrañas y llenas de misterios, así comenzando una gran pero peligrosa aventura.[/i][/code][/h1]

  
[h1] GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Es fácil de jugar debido que es un Point & Click, solamente mouse y de vez en cuando usas teclados para escribir números o palabras para ciertos puzzles. Por lo general, es cómodo y te mueves bastante, haces clic a los objetos o charlas con la persona. La meta es interrogar e investigar para hallar más respuestas y soluciones.

Tiene opción de guardado por si te perdiste algún logro o volver al punto para repasar las cosas y seguir adelante en la historia.

Me gusta que sea simple y al mismo tiempo cómodo de jugar. Al menos su duración es bastante buena, puedes jugar tranquilo (así alargas la duración del juego como en mi caso) o leer rápido los diálogos y acortar la duración del juego, cosa que es ventajosa para aquellos que se perdieron logros claves que sólo se consiguen en cada nivel. Fuera de eso, es fácil de completar y buenos puzzles, te hace investigar como en Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney pero con cierta vibra de los clásicos de los 90s. Claramente un digno homenaje.

[h1] GRAFICA[/h1]
El estilo artístico, como dije antes, un homenaje a los juegos como Monkey Island y entre tantos juegazos. Encaja perfecto, buenas paletas de colores y sin ser cargadas. Hicieron un gran trabajo.

[h1] MUSICA[/h1]
Me gustan especialmente los diálogos, así tiene más vida el juego y buena ambientación. Hicieron un excelente trabajo.

[h1] OPINION SOBRE EL JUEGO [/h1]
Cuando aproveche de conseguir el juego gratis, me llevé una grata sorpresa de que el juego fuera tan bueno. Debo admitir que lo disfruté y a pesar de ser corto, fue genial y me mantuvo pegado para poder terminar el juego 100%. Creo que su trama es interesante, al menos, tiene un desarrollo de historia, nada random como suele suceder con demás juegos y se nota que le pusieron mucho empeño para que sea algo más que un simple juego de Point & Click, con gusto lo jugaría de nuevo si es que tiene secuela. Estoy realmente satisfecho, es una joya realmente infravalorada y todos los que aman dicho genero, deberían darle la oportunidad y realmente vale la pena.

[h1] PUNTUACION FINAL: 8/10 [/h1]

[h1] PRO + [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Destaca bastante por contener buen humor y estar ambientado en los 90s.[/list]
    [*] Buen historia y personajes llamativos.[/list]
    [*] 20 logros fáciles de completar el 100% y así añadir otro juego completado.[/list]

[h1] CONTRA - [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Nada malo que decir[/list]

[code]Lo conseguí gratis, con gusto lo hubiera comprado y muy agradecido de haberlo jugado. Totalmente recomendable.[/code]

55576049.review:
I can easily recommend Kathy Rain to anyone who wants to get into the point and click genre. The puzzles are quite easy on most occasions, and they almost always make logical sense, meaning that my trips to a walkthrough were extremely infrequent. Granted, they can occasionally dip into being too easy, with too many hints as to what you're supposed to do, but that's a nitpick. The visuals are an excellent upgrade from the look of many Sierra games of the mid to late 90's, and the game looks gorgeous. Using the UI is smooth as butter, with clear commands and very easy access to your inventory. The music is also fantastic, each track having its own identity, ranging from creepy, to comforting, to calming, to beautifully sad. The voice acting is all and all solid, as well, if a bit cheesy at times.

The story, probably the game's main draw outside of its throwback point and click stylings, is all and all also pretty good, with some exceptions. It's an intriguing mystery, however, some of the details are a bit hard to follow, and the resolution feels sudden, as if the game's buildup up to that point was abruptly cut off. However, I can say that I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Kathy Rain, and for anyone who wants to get into point and click games without having to keep a walkthrough grafted to their eyes, this is a great choice. Although, it does deal with extremely dark, mature subject matter. Would not recommend this to younger players.

55198463.review:
Recommendation: Meh 5/10

Steam gave this adventure point and click game away for free, and I wasn’t about to turn it down even though I wouldn’t have bought it originally.

Kathy Rain follows the story of, well, our heroine Kathy Rain. She’s in university, acting out as a goth chain smoker, in a dorm with a more conservative religious type. Anyway, Miss Religious is apparently Miss socialite, and comes across a news articles about a dead person, Joseph Rain. Turns out, it’s Kathy’s grandad, so off she goes on her motorbike back to her hometown to attend the funeral and re-connect with her estranged family. (I wouldn't mind being able to afford a motorbike, chain smoking and University fees in this day and age... >_>)

From there, she dives down the rabbit hole investigating events from many years back surrounding her father, the local community and the war.

I have to say, initially I was rather weary of the game, the initial dialogue was a bit cringy and the art style has Kathy, our resident goth as a bit 1980’s with the hair to match despite being in 1995. Still, once the investigation got under way I actually got into the game and started enjoying some of the conversations going on.

The game is short and very snappy for a point and click adventure and the base mystery is interesting enough that I wanted to know what happened and how it happened. Kathy is likeable in her own weird way, it’s a solid game, I didn’t have any technical hiccups or issues.

But, the story veers into the unusual, psychotic religious mumbo-jumbo. It’s pretty ‘out there’, it’s a bit of mind screw, so if you like that sort of thing go for it, but for me the final two acts essentially knock the game down from decent to simply average.

For a free game I couldn’t really complain, would I advise buying it? Only if you’re a fan of the genre really.

This looks, feels, sounds and plays like a classic game adventure from the 90s. And of course, it's great like those classic point and click games from the end of the century. Graphically, it really is like last centuries games, which for me it's a plus and feels nostalgic, leaving your mind to imagine and fill the dots (in this case, the pixels), but I believe the graphics may scare away most people from the younger generations. The music is very nice, and the voices are very well done. The puzzles are also well designed, not being too difficult but you'll feel pleasure when you can solve most of them. The story is ok and the characters enhance it a long away. It's a bit dark, and involve things like murder, suicide, and facing your inner demons. Basically, a game for an older audience. The game is not too short, but you can easily finish it in a week and it's easy to unlock every achievement (just save at the beginning of each game day: in case you miss one you won't need to start all over again).

So, I strongly recommend this to any fan of the old point and click games (from Sierra or Lucas Arts, this actually reminds me a lot of Full Throttle). You'll love this. But if the graphics scare you and you're not a big fan of point and click adventures, this game might not be for you.

54922149.review:
It's hard to say anything about this game without spoiling anything. The artstyle is very nice, the music is great, gameplay-wise it's a very typical point'n'click story-based puzzle game the likes of Broken Sword and others. And I'm really glad the game has a bunch of decently cast voice actors for once, I've stumbled on too many indie titles where the recording's been done with a low quality mic by three dudes trying to imitate three voices each, none of which having any voice acting experience whatsoever.

The setting has initially been a little bit on the unwanted side if I'm completely honest. The main character feels incredibly angsty, self-oriented and hypocritical. Over time the focus drops from Kathy being fed up with everyone around her having a different lifestyle than her and whatever else she could be fed up with and you get to the good part of the game where mysteries keep unfolding and questions arise. The edge of Kathy's character eventually dulls and she becomes a bit more of a real and interesting person as the investigation progresses. The game itself is not scary, but there has been an eerie feeling hovering over my head all the time throughout the experience, as if something were to completely turn things around at any moment. The few moments it did, however, were not very impactful, at least in the horror sense, but for better or worse it's not the focus of the game and it doesn't happen often, so you're mostly left with the feeling of tension and anticipation, which is good.

The story goes places I surely did not expect at first, and having finished the game I want to say I'm unsatisfied how little was actually explained at the end of the day with the ever complex plot lines intertwining in this more and more surreal experience.  You could argue that the unpredictable elements might actually hamper the experience of the investigation based game where you can't get rewarded for paying attention because everything you learn goes out the window at some point. Nothing is set in stone, most of the game's ending is left in the air for the player to interpret, and I've seen some pretty crazy and, as per usual in those circumstances, unfortunately inacurrate and, sadly, easily debunkable theories as to whether or not the whole story was a metaphor of Kathy's mental health problems and not the actual set of events, blah, blah, blah, but it's very contradicting to what we see in the game. I just wish the game left the playerbase a bit less directionless.

That being said, the game is still intruiging through and through, and uncovering the secrets and answering the questions, even if they lead to more questions at the end of the day, is still very enjoyable. As a matter of fact I'm pretty sure the actual events of the game are well set in place, it's just the game ends before you get to truly understand what happens, as we're restricted in our perspective to Kathy's character. The plot makes sense for sure, it's just the sense is hidden by characters we know little about.

Despite a very surreal ending, the story begins as a very predictable chain of tropes. While some characters are believable, many of them fit into a very predictable archetype, all the way down to their speech patterns. And let me just say I was not at all surprised with the revelation of certain character's dark secrets, even from practically the very start of the game already feeling like the game is trying way too much to hint at something being wrong with certain people.

The good and the bad of the "gameplay" part of the experience all comes down to the multiinteractivity with the clues and objects, and the need to backtrack constantly between locations because of it. Every time something gets uncovered as a clue to the next step, you can, and often you should, go back to every place of interest and discuss the new item/clue with all the NPCs in the game. On one hand it's awesome, because it shows how nicely everything intertwines in the story and how many things can be uncovered not by one NPC having the answer, but about 3 other people hinting at something with different pieces of information they have depending on their perspective. On the other, the game requires a significant amount of time in-between the NPCs to be spent looking for this information among them, leading you to visit every location MORE than 5 times a day, and almost always just to gather scraps and backtrack again in a minute once you uncover a newly found object of interest. Technically it's not super awful, especially with as few locations as you have in the game, but a thought did cross my mind that I'm spending most of the day  on my harley passing by the grandma's house to say hi to her and ask about one person or the other that she might recall a little and so on and so forth. It also doesn't help that sometimes a couple of the interactible elements are barely discernible or very easy to ignore on the map, so you might skip them the first way around.

As far as the puzzle elements go, most of them were fine, some of them were interesting or clever, but I did stumble upon a few puzzles that were a bit of a stretch in logic, or were pretty unintuitive. That especially applies to the surreal ending. And yeah, it was to be expected - it's surreal after all, but I think it's a pretty bad idea to put surreal/supernatural elements in puzzle games that are to be based on the foundations of logic and expected consequences, because most of the time the problem-solving puzzle becomes more of a gameplay-extending trial and error, where you have nothing to base the results on so you just have to try everything available.

In the end, I'll give this a 7/10. The game plays nicely, has a cool vibe, the audio and visual elements are fine, the characters are neatly developed and the story is really intruiging all the way through. Although I'd say the game loses itself a bit in its overtly convoluted mystery and there are definitely things to get frustrated with here and there, at the end of the day it wasn't a bad experience, and it was, in fact, a game worth playing. I only wish that there was a better explanation of the story, as it deserves more than to be left as an open-ended "make up your own answer" kind of mystery.

54615138.review:
At the first glance Kathy Rain looks like a poor attempt to exploit people's love of classic adventures of the 90s. The game has pixel graphics, circular item interaction menu, horizontal inventory, etc. And all those retro things don't work that well for obvious reasons: for starters, 320x200 resolution doesn't look any good on 1440p 32" monitor.

However, once you are 15 minutes into the game, you get totally hooked by intriguing story, cleverly written dialogues and dry sense of humor. The more you play, the more you feel that the game creators were inspired by classic adventures like Broken Sword, Full Throttle and even Sanitarium. What's even better, Kathy Rain doesn't have universally hated things like pixel hunting and illogical puzzles, so in this aspect the game resembles modern adventures. Still, it's far from walking simulator/interactive movie, and is a must play for every adventure/puzzle fan.

An absolutely BRILLIANT game. Well, for a good portion. Can I just say that this game has amazingly done puzzles? Like, none of them are brain dead easy, but MOST aren't DISCWORLD levels of illogical. The pacing worked very well as it made me feel like a genuine detective and I'd say a good 80% of the game is absolutely stellar. 

However, this game has 2 points of complaint. 

1) Computer puzzles, get a guide for the puzzles involving a computer. Im not joking when I say you wont get it.

2) the "red man" and the endgame portion. It's such a tonal and gameplay shift that it feels like I just started playing a certain Harlan Ellison game.

54575181.review:
This one is really hard. I liked a lot about it. Kathy herself is fun to play up to a point. Her roommate is also a solid character, and the interplay between the two of them could have been a lot better than it was. There are strong hints that this is the first game in a series, and that Kathy and Eileen will be a team. I think that could be really cool.

Ultimately, though, there just wasn't all that much to recommend the game. The puzzle design isn't stellar, at all, and there are a lot of places where you can easily get stuck while the game waits for you to do some specific thing to trigger the end of the day or some other event that doesn't seem directly related. There's a lot of gating to the puzzles that feels arbitrary and which you can easily get hung up on. There are a lot of times when, as a player, I wanted to pursue lead X, but the game doesn't want you to look at that until tomorrow, so you have to do unrelated tasks Y, Z, A, and B in order to get access to that. 

Perhaps most disappointing for the experience, though, is that there's very little latitude to role-play Kathy. On several occasions you have to do things that I just plain didn't want to do, and which felt optional -- a different approach to a puzzle, say. Upon looking up a walkthrough it always turned out that, no, you have to do that or the game won't move forward.

The final sequence has a satisfying set of not-too-hard but reasonable and logical puzzles that wind it up on a positive note, gameplay wise, but it's all marred by some weird moral messages right at the end. Also, there are elements to the story that really don't seem to hang together well, or which seemed tacked on at the last moment.

I love point-and-click adventure games, and point-and-click detective/mystery games with a snarky woman lead are pretty much the best. But this fell short. (Not to mention that it really did 'fall short' time-wise as well.) I can't really say I'm left feeling like I need to recommend this to my friends. However, if it's really your bag and you can get it very inexpensively, it's a diverting way to spend an afternoon.

54369008.review:
Kathy Rain is a point-and-click adventure game set in the 90's. You play as Kathy, a teenager who has undergone many family-related problems during her childhood. Kathy finds out that her grandfather has recently passed away, but upon hearing the bizarre circumstances around his death, Kathy decides to reunite with her estranged family in order to investigate.

The puzzles in Kathy Rain are fairly logical for the most part, barring a couple of obscure ones towards the end. The story is intriguing, and it will have you trying to piece together the mystery for yourself as it draws to its conclusion. Interactions between characters showcase a wide range of emotions, often through the use of thought-provoking social commentary. The quality of voice acting also contributes to the effectiveness of this. Dialogue is conveyed in a realistic manner that is both down to earth and to the point.

One thing to note with Kathy Rain, the length of the game is quite short. It can be completed in one sitting if you focus on pushing the main plot line.

54230971.review:
I received this game free with Twitch Prime.

If you enjoy point-and-click adventures and don't mind pixel graphics, this game is worth your time. At 5 hours play time for me, it's quite short though.

The characters are interesting and relateable. The story is ok for the length, but the motivations and nature of the antagonists remains somewhat unclear. I wasn't a big fan of the art (it's fine as pixel art goes), but the voice acting is outstanding for a work of this type. The puzzles are mostly simple enough to figure out, but if you do get stumped, there's no in-game way to recover and you may need to consult a guide. There was only one instance where I knew what to do but it took some fiddling to figure out the specific way the game wanted me do it. For the curious, it involves chains and is about the last thing you do in the game.

A small criticism would be that the 90's motif is handled roughly at times. For example, there's a section where voice and image analysis software is used. Having a computer automatically spot a pattern in a scanned image would be quite unusual though at least plausible, but automated voice analysis was virtually impossible at a home level in that era. Also, having been a computer-oriented nerdy student at the time myself, it stretches credulity a bit that a punk-rock motorcycle-riding journalism major in 1995 would have been at all comfortable using that software by herself the first time she saw it while not describing herself as a geek. Keep in mind, Windows '95 had only just launched so anyone knowing their way around x86s would have had to be proficient in Windows 3.x and probably DOS, and Macs weren't much more user friendly.

Beyond that, it's not clear how and why the police conveniently show up at a particular time in the story. This would be the one thing I'd call an actual plot hole, but it's minor and not at all plot-critical.

Finally, the devs have made politics an issue in interviews saying this is intended to be a feminist game. I'm not a fan of devs operating with political agendas, but this is about as well as I've seen it done. The main character is a bit of a Mary Sue, but not much more than most adventure game protagonists. The only scene which suffered from it is where she lays out a biker with a stun gun as it's neither plot-relevant nor necessary for character development. It's just a chance to show off that she's a strong woman who don't need no man. On the other hand, at least she didn't lay him out with her bare hands.

My beef here isn't that she's a strong female character. It's that creators seem to think women can only be strong if they are in physical conflict with men and it's both overdone and lacks verisimilitude. If the devs felt the confrontation necessary at all (which it's not), I'd rather have seen it handled the way one might like their real life daughter to handle it, which I doubt means with physical violence if there are other means at hand. In this case, she could have asked the man if he regularly assaults the daughters of his fellow gang members, or called for assistance from other members. It's intelligence, not weakness, for a 140 lb woman to avoid physical conflict with a 250 lb man.

53829683.review:
I don't have anything negative to comment about the technical side of things, or graphics, or puzzle logic, and hence why the game receives a "Thumbs Up". That being said, I didn't like it and I don't think it appeals to a wide audience at all.

The game's fairly short (only took me 6 hours to beat), there's no moon logic and all the actions are fairly clear, so if you're new to the genre, this one is as good an introduction as any other. The plot positions itself as a detective story, and sure enough things start that way. The game even has a promising line "A Detective is Born" right there in the title! Which just makes the consequent emergence of mystic elements and inexplicable occult rites all the weirder, if not utterly out of place. Kathy Rain could've easily maintained the strict and grounded investigative tone throughout its entire brief story, but apparently it just wasn't good enough.

But the biggest offender that put me off was the protagonist herself. On the Steam forums I stumbled upon a rhetoric that Kathy Rain is a "girly" quest (whatever that might mean), and while I don't know exactly how to interpret that statement, it makes me believe that there's a grain of truth in it - maybe those who share certain qualities and characteristics with the main heroine will find it more to their liking. As for me... I could overlook the disgusting habit of incessant smoking - after all, Solid Snake never leaves the base without a pack of his trusty slug repellents, so who am I to judge? Could probably forgive the unnecessarily sassy attitude - even though it teeters on the brink of turning into an asshole to perfect strangers. Could maybe find a place in my heart for the whole "rebellious young woman with daddy issues behaves like a silly teen" shtick, even though any reasonable adult should honestly know better than that. 

But when Kathy wilfully misses her University classes, that's where I draw the line. How can one be so entitled as to skip a whole week of studies for no good reason or explanation other than "Nah!," especially considering that to become a true journalist is her current major goal in life? How can one be so arrogant when there are thousands and millions of other people who would love to get an education, a breakthrough in their otherwise hopeless lives, but can't, because an immature, self-important (wo)man-child Kathy Rain took the only spot in the academic roster? I cannot bring myself to respect her character, and the more I played, the harder it became to stay interested.

I suppose that the little rant above actually speaks volumes of the game's portrayal of characters - if it managed to evoke genuine disgust, then the writers did something right. And of course, your mileage may vary and maybe you'll find more positive traits in Kathy than I could. After all, it's not like she's an evil person or a criminal - in fact, vice versa, when it comes to friends, she shows herself to be selfless, decisive and more courageous than I could ever be. Still, clearly our values lie in different dimensions entirely.

Either way, I got the game for free as part of a giveaway, so I can't complain about the money spent. Time, however, is a different beast, and if you really enjoy point & click quests and maybe look for an awesome female protagonist, look no further than Heroine's Quest: The Herald of Ragnarok on Steam. It's free, it's awesome, it's replayable and, frankly, despite being set in a fantasy world, it makes more sense than Kathy Rain. Or, if mystery and cosmic horrors are more up your alley, play Fran Bow - it's about as difficult as Kathy Rain, but also more intriguing and incomparably "higher-tier" in terms of production value.

53786642.review:
[h1]More interesting reviews on [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33843777//] Fenol Baron Approves Curator Page[/url] [/h1]

A good story is the basis of any good adventure quest, something that builds on all the other components. And with great confidence I can say that the story told in the game “Kathy Rain” is very informative and fascinating. A large share of the detective, oppressive mysterious mystical atmosphere against the background of the pastoral serenity of a small town, the tangible influence of David Lynch and his Twin Peaks, the understanding of the correct disclosure of the internal component of the characters - all this is mixed into something very interesting and nontrivial. The journalist Kathy Rain arrives in his grandfather's funeral hometown and almost immediately finds evidence that some strange unexplainable things happened in his past that led him to a wheelchair for 15 years, and almost all residents can hear the sound of bones skeletons of the closets. Kathy's personality is also very ambiguous, it is plagued by internal demons, tearing it from the inside, constantly poisoning its present existence. History perfectly conveys the feeling of an impending threat, which is still somewhere beyond the horizon, but inexorably approaching; competently playing with plot nuances, without revealing all of their cards, but constantly throwing new and new hints to the player. This scheme works fine to the very end credits, at the sight of which you get the feeling that you have read a good book.

In addition to the story, it is worth noting the work with the characters. They look and sound so human, that you believe in their emotions and actions. In situational dialogues, some minor spiritual things are constantly flashed that make them as close to reality as possible, humanize the figures on the screen, make them even relatives to some extent, and the roommate Cathy in the room is an incredible redhead charm. Puzzles as much as possible tied to the story and look very relevant in those situations where you are faced with them. Although there are few of them, but their complexity is VERY decent, so you have to seriously work on their solution. I didn’t really like the riddle with the poem (although usually I love the decoding of the messages), but here it was too wise and foggy, as it seems to me. The picture is also quite normal for this game engine, there are some incredibly beautiful locations (mostly related to nature), but in general there are no surprises in this regard, and the game is not about graphics, but about the plot and involvement in it.

“Kathy Rain” is a great example of the fact that high-quality history and the ability to work with the emotions of a player mean much more than a picture for millions of dollars and an incredible promotion. Very delicate, lively and exciting adventure, long-lasting in memory, a wonderful job.

53460275.review:
You like point and click mystery game? This game is for you.
You like a good mystery game with immersive story? Then this game is might not for you.

Warning! The following writing includes a minor game spoiler and filled with my own subjective and objective opinions. So it might be a little bit biased

The synopsis of the game is basically, you start as Kathy Rain, an apathetic college girl that have to solve the mystery of her grandfather disappearance before her grandfather died.

Firstly I want to point that this game initial puzzle and story is really tight-gripping. Everything starts very smoothly, the pacing, the plot points, the puzzle solving, everything is really good, until near the end of the final chapter, the story suddenly takes a huge blow. All of the logical and immersive story suddenly mixed up with some supernatural plots nonsense that introduced later by nearly at the end of the story. 

It can be my fault if I don't really understand the plots fully or don't understand the underlying psychological metaphors of this game, but again the way the plot changing is kind of breaking the immersive story that this game build early in the first three chapters.

Aside from my mixed feeling about the game story. The other aspects of the game is a top notch. While the plots is unsatisfying, the writing of the game dialogue is really damn good, I really enjoy all of the game characters dialogue (or monologue).

Another points go for engaging puzzle solving, good-looking pixel art, atmospheric soundtrack, and damn the voice acting in this game is really good. 

Also, this game is kind of short around 3-5 hours of playtime, so it's either good or bad for some players

Story : 6/10 Could be better
Graphic : 8/10 pixelated graphics done right
Music : 8/10 very atmospheric

Verdict:
The game is still fun and enjoyable if you don't take the story seriously.

53213710.review:
[h1] Story Rich, Fun puzzles, Relaxing Music and a PIXELATED ART-STYLE [/h1]

I got this game for free when it was free to get for a limited time on Steam.. I didn't think that it's a good game by any means but my friend told me that the game is great and I should play it.. and damn how I loved it.

The game is set in the 90's, you play as a girl called Kathy Rain who faced REAL family problems in her childhood, and you noticed a strange death incident happened to your Grandfather years ago..  you planned to get to the bottom of the story and find out what the hell happened to him.

The game has a very unique-pixelated art-style that fits just fine into the game in my POV, the game has a full dialogue voice actors.. there are people who did the same voice acting for more than a character and that didn't go strange at all.
every character and level are memorable.. that's affected by how well the developers designed the levels and how good and natural the character are.. it is still a fucking pixelated game dude.. [u] and we can see now how this game is a perfect example for how the graphics/artstyle don't change the quality of the game.. it just make it more beautiful. [/u]

The story telling is one of the best story telling I've ever seen in an indie game.. and the puzzles are fun and reasonable.
There are sometimes I got a little overwhelmed by a puzzle solving chapter when I used a guide or two but that doesn't ruin the game's atmosphere or anything.

[h1] I definitely recommend you to play this.. that's a great work the developers did because it's the first game they worked on ever. [/h1]

[b]Terrible voice acting of the tryhard variety. Contrived and amateurish dialogue. Weak and erratic story.[/b] 

One of those games you are deceived into buying simply because of the positive reviews and attractive screenshots until you realize that it has no real depth. Luckily I got it for free. 

Kathy Rain as a character is heavily based on fourth-wave feminism. I had to mute the game after 15 minutes of her annoying valley-girl voice and cringy wannabe-tough punchlines. It turns out the voice actress is a SJW and a [i]comedian[/i]. 

Even if Clifftop Games is just getting started as an indie studio, they're already heading in the wrong direction. Rather than incorporating libtard ideals into the plot, the plot itself seems to have been conceived in a manner that would encompass those ideals. 

The priest, young cop, and sheriff were all thrown in the script, not to serve a real purpose, but so that the writer could take a cheap shot at organized religion and law enforcement. Kathy Rain is an obnoxious c-u-n-t to everybody she comes across (all of them white males) except for 3 types of people besides her grandma: a single mother, a disabled guy, and a Mexican gangster (because he's a minority). 

All of your dialogue choices deliver the same message and b-i-t-c-h-y tone but are worded differently in a poor attempt at providing such a dumb heroine with nuance.

Disclaimer: I snagged this game during the 24h window when it was offered for free here on Steam.

A new breath of life into Point and Click adventure games, with a pinch of added salt to it (i.e., don't let your kids play it unless you are ready to explain to them what certain slang words mean...). Given that I have not played much of this genre since King's Quest, I can't comment on how it stacks up to what else is "currently" available. But I can tell you this, I certainly had fun playing it! The game does not seem as slow as the older games did way back when, but all the feel of the older games is still present. From the extremely pixelated characters that you have to squint to make them look like the close up portrait used when they are talking, to the midi soundtrack, everything here was a throwback. 

Note: if you don't want to use a Guide for getting all of the achievements, I will give you a little hint: try all of your inventory on everything you encounter, even if just for shiggles. Kathy will let you know if that is not something she wants to do / have time for, so you don't have to fear derailing your progress.

Enjoy!

52506816.review:
Kathy Rain is a point and click mystery adventure from Swedish developer, Clifftop Games.

Set in the mid-1990s, we follow inquisitive journalist student, Kathy Rain, as she heads to her grandfather’s funeral. Armed with a stun gun, pack of cigarettes, and a Zippo lighter from her dad, Kathy starts investigating the mysterious circumstances around the last years of her grandfather’s life.

As a main character, Kathy Rain is an awesome female protagonist who is totally bad-ass, with a take-no-shit, too cool for school attitude. I instantly liked her and was happy to share her journey into small town mystery.

While attending her grandfather’s funeral, Kathy reunites with her grandmother who she hasn’t seen since she was a child. Her grandmother isn’t surprised in the least by her reappearance after all these years and welcomes her with open arms. The two reminisce and catch up on the last 15 years.

Kathy learns that her grandfather hadn’t been the same since being found in the forest over a decade earlier, barely speaking a word to anyone. And she believes that something happened to him in the forest and is determined to find out what.

Her investigation begins with the only clues her grandmother can offer – checking out the old Air Force base her grandfather was stationed at in his youth.

Kathy Rain’s mystery hooked me and I wanted to know what was happening in this small town with crazy occurrences, disappearances, and an eccentric billionaire.

Why were people heading into the forest and coming back affected as they were? Or not coming back at all? What significance was the tragic life of the young artist who drowned herself? And who was buying – and stealing – her artwork?

This was a really enjoyable indie game that had me hooked from the word go. Plus, it was challenging enough that I had to keep exploring to figure out the right path to continue… it wasn’t always obvious what you had to do.

Honestly, I do think that the story let the game down a little bit. Surface level was fine, but I want more. Deeper answers and explanations to everything alluded to throughout the game.

Read my full review: https://geekherring.com/2019/06/09/kathy-rain-review/

51759094.review:
If you enjoy a lot of the older point-and-click adventures or are familiar with any other modern true-to-form releases, this title should be in your collection. It's not perfect but I would absolutely play sequels.

The best things? The voice acting is superb. The quality of the recording and the skill of the actors, to the inflection of emotions and direction, can be felt. The puzzles don't feel contrived to add content nor are they overtly difficult. I only got partially stuck a few times but it didn't slow the pace down very much. Puzzles were well thought out and spaced between investigation segments appropriately. The characters are well written, most with a deep background, and everyone you meet has a purpose to the story. or your goals You feel like a rookie journalist, not a random protagonist thrown in to fill a story gap, and you have ties to the core plot. The length was appropriate, not adding fluff to extend the duration, and everything you do felt like it fit the situation.

The down side? I thought that the story falls off midway. I was absolutely engrossed in the story line from the get go and I wanted to know so much about her relationship with her grandfather and the rest of her family. I found myself losing interest once things move from discovering/understanding past events to dealing with the unusual sci-fi backstory. I commend the creator for writing and programming, so maybe expectations shouldn't be so grand. There wasn't a lot of 'item combination', possibly only twice, so this feature felt shoehorned in to meet genre requirements. The soundtrack was repetitive and some tracks do not fit the atmosphere. Also, the game doesn't appear to run in 4k resolution, even after tweaking all the config settings. It ran perfectly once windowed.

Therefore I'd say that the cost on sale was a serious win at about 6-8 hours playtime.

51514853.review:
PROS:
- Great music, especially the main theme
- Immersive, which solid voice acting helps to build on (Arielle Siegel!)
- Consistent eerie mood and pacing
- Puzzles are logical & aren't too hard nor too easy
- Unique Story

CONS:
- Unanswered questions is a massive con. We barely learned anything about the Crimson Man let alone what the Old God supporters truly want.
- Rushed ending, similar to above
- Far too short

Normally I'm not one to desire sequels - when a game or movie ends well, it's best to be left alone. But in this case, I think KS can really benefit from a sequel that explores the Crimson Man & his supporters more. Perhaps they aren't destroyed entirely (I mean, surely only burning the red flowers isn't enough?) and Eileen and KS can investigate this.

That aside, the pros outweight the cons for this game so I'd recommend it.
