51265746.review:
I liked Kathy Rain. It's been a long time since I've played any point-and-click games. I recall playing the genre when I was younger and Kathy Rain was such a nice game to recall old times. The oldish, 90's graphics and atmosphere sure help with that too.

It took me about 5-6 hours to finish the game in total although I admit I walked by a walkthrough for most of the playtime. This is mainly because I didn't want to miss the achievements along the way (which are pretty difficult to get on your own really. They are all hidden and some of them require strange actions that you might miss on your own.) I speculate that it would take longer to finish the game without the walkthrough, and definitely more time if you try to complete the achievements on your own.

The story was okay. It had enough suspense to make me want to keep playing to know what's next, but in the end when all was revealed, it didn't feel very satisfying. It has a dark, religious theme to it so maybe that's it. But it was alright. On another hand, I loved the characters and dialogue. The characters felt very real and the dialogues were quite well-written. I definitely liked Kathy. She's not your usual main character and she's definitely an interesting MC.

So yup, I definitely recommend this game although it's best that you wait for a sale. I got this game for $3 at IndieGala, so it was definitely worth but at its original price, it might be a bit much.

51209536.review:
[h1] 2/10 just for graphics, the only element of the game that is somewhat pleasant [/h1] 
This game is lacking in meaning - the result of its plot not having any real depth in it. Weird trying-hard-to-be-disturbing type of storyline is actually just pointless. Meaningless, forced and hollow is how it felt to me. The 'detective' element of the game is weak, most things you find out are predictable.
As for the main hero, Kathy Rain is trying to be the steriotypical 'rebelios' character as hard as the plot is trying to seem interesting and surprise you or something. As annoying as she is, they actually give you achievements if you manage to make her act even more annoying.
And yet, there is no serious difference between the replies you choose - you can't change main character's attitude drastically, it's just all shades of annoying - and what they result in.  Dialogue options are useless, because you get everything you need no matter what you choose to say.
The whole world of this game is shaped to give one Nancy Drew-wannabe appreciation [spoiler] she doesn't deserve [/spoiler], that's what the plot and the dialogs come down to. The game's 'message' seems to be both about [spoiler]responsibility for your own actions and choises, not blaming others for everything and not letting past rule your life and make you a jerk[/spoiler] and [spoiler]still getting your way no matter how much of a jerk you choose to be[/spoiler]. Those two conflict, and such a mixed message is usually a result of saying something when you have nothing to say.

Kathy Rain is an easy game, but it takes too long. And in the end it is not worth playing [spoiler]even if you got it for free, as it was at some point[/spoiler] , as it has little originality.

[spoiler]Overusing (hence, ruining) okey-dokey is an additional flaw in this game I just can not ignore.[/spoiler]

This is an extremely tough one to review.  I was worried for a while that it might be anti-Christian but after playing the entirety, that doesn't seem to be the case.  It seems to be sufficiently neutral about Christians, which makes sense to me.  

The idea that when someone who is guilty of a serious offense commits suicide, it shows that the person has a conscience, seems a bit erroneous since suicide itself is unethical.  HOWEVER, I had to consider the character who made the comment since that character probably cannot be depended heavily on to know this real well.

Extremely good in certain parts.  Good puzzles but maybe sometimes a little too time-consuming to figure out, sometimes maybe even way too difficult to know how to allow our character to proceed.  Perhaps a few more hints from the mind of our character (we can hear what she is thinking sometimes) would be much better.  One time I couldn't determine a code and even after finding the code with youtube searches I still didn't know HOW they got the code, only what the code was.  I ended out having to do even more searching to figure it out.  Yes, too difficult sometimes to follow that narrow path to reaching the end.

Fun traits differing from character to character, adequate amount of thinking involved and some of it involved computing efforts which was really fun for me.  Overall I think a good game.  A few adjustments and I really think it could easily be a great game.  Then again, maybe others will like what I did not?  Cheers!

50978619.review:
I got Kathy Rain free when it was made available for a day or so. [i]Clifftop Games[/i] had just released their next game so I assume making their first adventure game free had promotional purposes. 

You immediately notice the low resolution KR employs - this was made with the use of the so-called [i]Adventure Game Studio[/i]. This is a development tool to design adventure games that are akin to those classic [i]LusasArts[/i] games we used to play back in the '90s. Although the resolution is very low, music and voice acting are top-notch - both help with the immersion, a lot.

The story revolves around a college girl who just learns her grandfather passed away. She attends the funeral and after a long conversation with her grandmother she finds out that he was, for many years, bound to a wheelchair following some sort of an accident. Nobody really knows what happened so Kathy starts investigating. In the 5 days (or chapters) we have we learn a lot not just about grandfather but the entire Rain family.

This is a [i]point-and-click[/i] game, all right. We interact with a lot of items, gradually increase our inventory and we can combine the objects we picked up with others whenever we see it logical. This is something I liked about the game -  solutions to certain puzzles were interesting and at the same time very logical. The only letdown for me was the ending which simply borrowed too much from [i]Twin Peaks[/i].

Throughout the game I felt a [i]Wadjet Eye Games[/i] vibe - in fact, one of the voice-actors was none other than [i]Dave Gilbert[/i]. If you are familiar with the adventure games his studio develops or distributes (such as the [i]Blackwell[/i] series) you're definitely going to like this one. If not, but you're willing to go down on memory lane because you used to love helping [i]Guybrush Threepwood[/i] survive all kinds of perils 25 years ago then Kathy Rain is a good choice when making your next purchase.

50978394.review: Le jugué para probar ya que estaba gratis. Llevo una racha de aventuras gráficas mediocres o que me aburren en seguida porque es lo mismo de siempre pero esta me sorprendió bastante. Rápidamente te das cuenta de que en la historia hay algo raro y quieres saber más. No se me hizo ni corta ni larga, es la cantidad de horas justa para desarrollar una historia de este tipo sin aburrirte con detalles innecesarios. Eso sí, la dificultad igual un poco demasiado simplona, hubiese preferido que no te lo diesen todo tan mascado o evidente, pero no me quejo para nada, recomendable.

50973993.review:
This was a difficult rating to give. On one hand there is certainly a lot to like about this game: I like the classic adventure game vibe - the game obviously draws some influences from games like Gabriel Knight. The characters and the story are interesting (even though the story gets wrapped a bit to quickly for my taste).

However, if like me, you play adventure games at least in part for the puzzles (challenge), you will probably be disappointed. There aren't really a lot of puzzles in the game, but the even bigger problem is that the puzzles that are there tend to solve themselves. The way this works (without going into spoilers) is that the game provides hints that are unnecessary or just too strong - in several instances, Kathy outright tells you how you are supposed to solve a puzzle. This leaves the impression that Kathy (the character) was the one to solve the puzzle and not the player. The end result is that any sense of accomplishment a player would normally get from solving a puzzle is absent.

This is especially disappointing considering difficult puzzles were a major part of classic adventure games from which Kathy draws so many influences. I get that a lot of gamers nowdays play adventure games only for the story, but there are ways to reconcile those worlds. For example, I wish that the game offered a "hard" mode with more puzzles and less hints, or even just an explicit "hints" button that gamers who wanted to salve puzzles themselves could safely ignore.

50914881.review:
Si hay un género que me enamoró desde el primer momento, hace casi treinta años, es el de las aventuras gráficas. Y si hay un subgénero de éste al que nunca he terminado de «pillarle el punto», es el detectivesco; Quizá demasiado «crudo», argumentos demasiado densos, intimistas y poco fantasiosos. Quizá por malas experiencias con títulos concretos que hacía que prefiriese aventuras más disparatadas, en las que resolver los puzles uno tras otro era la premisa fundamental, casi la única. Pero Kathy Rain ha conseguido que rompiese esa barrera después de tanto tiempo.

Es posible que el camino hacia la fantasía (sin entrar en muchos detalles) por los que atraviesa la protagonista, es lo que ha hecho que no vea esta aventura como una simple resolución de un caso de investigación al uso; Esto sin duda le da una vida al juego que hace que si en algún momento para ti ha empezado a «caer», se levante de inmediato.

No puedo describir mucho más sin destripar partes del argumento, así que terminaré diciendo que lo juegues sin prejuicios, ni sobre las aventuras gráficas en general ni en concreto con las de ningún corte determinado. No te defraudará en absoluto.

50894170.review:
The tropes. Oh, there are tropes! It's Chloe Price being MacGuyver-Max Caulfield-Jessica Fletcher, on a clichéd Full Throttle adventure set in a small town that has some rich dude, dead people, and supernatural spookiness. I'm sure the subtle abortion scenes have meaning of some sort, but otherwise it seemed like something coming out of left field because I have no idea what that's all about at that point.

It's basically a point-and-click-sans-walking-simulator. Sure, there are puzzles, but nothing too complicated. It's not Da Vinci Code, just so you don't get your hopes up. They have no meaning, it's just for finding the password and combination locks. Nothing profound or philosophical. The dialogue and actions don't matter as far as I can tell, which is pretty appropriate for what's being delivered. However, if you're looking for character depth, it's lacking. You can only find out about the people by talking with them, and there are questions even Kathy Rain won't ask (so that if you also missed it, you'll have to restart because she will NOT ask it again). So, biographies are out of the picture.

But, check it out if you must. It's not terrible, at least.

50844786.review: Kathy Rain is one of the best detective games I've ever played. It's eerie, funny, and enthralling. If anything has ever come close to a Veronica Mars/Nancy Drew crossover, this would be it. Kathy is cheeky, daring, and she knows how to get what she wants. The puzzles are fun and satisfying, and the story pulls you in and never lets you go. I ended up bingeing the entire game in just two days (it would have been less if I didn't start playing so late). I wanted more of the mystery, and I knew I wouldn't be satisfied until I finished it. I do wish that the game would've been longer. It feels too short for a $14.99 retail game. And the ending was a little disappointing. With the tension being so high in the beginning, the reveal fell a little flat. Still, I enjoyed this game. It reminded me what good detective puzzle games should be - and as someone who has played every single Nancy Drew PC game, I know what I like. The pixel art was also a nice nostalgic trip. Kathy Rain is a must play for all Nancy Drew fans or anyone who loves a good mystery. I can't wait for a sequel.

50808406.review:
I have to say I was not expecting this game to be this good.
I'll try not to spoil anything, but I thought that if any game deserved my time to write a review, this certainly did.

When I first saw the pictures of it, it reminded me a lot of the old Gabriel Knight game which I loved a lot.
I started playing and I was expecting a fairly straightforward mystery detective game with a teenage protagonist, and I was thoroughly confused as the plot got more and more surreal towards the end.

I love the style of the protagonist, and all around everyone has a memorable and enjoyable character.

The art is very nicely made pixel art, and it ranges from good to absolutely stunning, for example the graveyard after the rain is exceptionally nice looking.

The music is nice and atmospheric, and I loved the voice actors, I think they did an amazing work.

And finally the gameplay... 
While it took me some time to get used to the way you interact with items, after that I had no issue usually, except for occasionally expecting it to work differently than it does.

The biggest and most important point however is the puzzle solving. 
I have had to check an online walk-through twice, an both times afterwards I was annoyed with myself for not thinking about the solution on my own. 
I can honestly say that this game had the most intuitive puzzles I've seen in a long time. 

I am not sure if I got this game from the steam store or in a bundle, but it is definitely worth it's price, and I'm probably going to throw more money at this developer!
Also would love for this game to become a series, not sure if that would ever happen but I'll buy it if it does.

Also a small side-note: The fact that this game is less than $15 and still has a demo to let potential buyers try it out is commendable! More developers should think like this one!

There are certainly things to like about this game. One of them is that it reminds me of the Longest Journey - steeped in the supernatural but ultimately about relationships and the human condition.

That's why it's so hard to overlook the game's biggest weakness - its depiction of relationships. Kathy's encounters almost invariably begin with Kathy upsetting or injuring the new character, yet within minutes they're best friends. Even though the voice acting is excellent, the conversations sound far from what real people say to each other.

50682734.review:
I played a lot of Lucasarts Adventure games back in the day. Full Throttle was one of my favorites (I also recommend the remaster). This game is obviously inspired by those, even though it does not contain any of the typical Monkey Island or DOTT "Haha" humor. Instead you get a really good detective story with good characters. And the best of it: everything is pretty logical which means that I finished this without even looking up a guide once - something that pretty much never happens in adventure games for me.
I fully recommend Kathy Rain - it is worth your time.

50681001.review:
I really, really enjoyed playing through Kathy Rain. Kathy Rain is an amazing character. I loved her. There are probably people out there like her, or people out there that can relate to her in some way, whether it be a personality trait or her relationships with her family and the other characters in the game. She's smart, confident, quick-witted and straight up cool af. She's a bad a**. The characters in general are great. 

I loved the dialogue and voice acting. The game shared a lot of similarities to the Blackwell series by Wadjet Eye Games, which is one of my favorites. The same things that made those games great were present here. Each character has so much personality and it's hard not to get invested. It felt like a Wadjet Eye Game, honestly. 

The puzzles were, for the most part, pretty straight forward and simple. There really wasn't anything that was too far fetched or unreasonable. However, I'm extremely sad, upset and embarrassed to say that I needed a walkthrough to do a few of the ones towards the end, specifically the riddle one and cracking the pad lock code at the end of the game. It was on me. They weren't difficult in retrospect, I'm just dumb and couldn't figure them out. Sad. 

I'm also a big fan of the soundtrack. They were simple tracks, but they all fit extremely well with the ambiance of the game. 

As for flaws... Like I mentioned before, the game shared a lot of similarities to the Blackwell series by Wadjet Eye Games. Dave Gilbert, the head of Wadjet Eye Games, was involved with this game, so that shouldn't be too surprising. However, some aspects of the game are eerily similar in a lot of different ways. There are certain locations, game mechanics and aspects of the story that are almost taken directly out of Blackwell. I love the Blackwell series, so I personally didn't mind, but I could see how that can be seen as a flaw. You probably don't want to be this similar to another game. 

The story was a tad bit convoluted at times and difficult to understand. I've seen some people complain about this, but I didn't find it to be that bad. It didn't really ruin the experience. It was fun to play through regardless, despite being confused about what exactly was taking place for the majority of the game. I'm sure a lot of people who finished this game are still confused by the story to some degree. For me, it's a little muddy. I feel like I have questions, but I'm honestly not even sure what they are. I'd say this is probably the biggest flaw in the game. 

That's pretty much it. If you're a fan of the genre, you'll probably like this. Also, the ending hinted that there could potentially be a sequel, which is cool. I'd love to play another Kathy Rain game. Anyway, yeah, awesome game.

50599887.review:
An eerie, captivating point and click adventure game that harkens back to the feel of the heyday of the point and click genre. Technicly the game is somewhat limited, there isn't a ton of screens, cutscenes or crazy setpieces.
But the game is dripping with atmossphere. The music and the voiceover are a true bliss. The developer paid very close attention to details regarding the 90ies setting, people that remember those days and stuff like the dictaphone will know what I mean. 
The setting is very intimate, there is basicly (almost) no filler or cheese in the game. Everything that is there, serves the purpose of telling the story. None of the puzzles were obtuse or in place to fluff up the playtime and there was a sense of direction at all times. Unlike other adventure games Kathy Rain doesn't do the typical pixel hunting, mememing or whacky humour of point and click games.(tho there are some  veiled nods to Lucasfilm games).  The  characters act natural and the tasks at hand are rather mundane. Progression is intuitive, so i'd say even newcomers to the genre will find their way around in no time.
There is something about this type of games that is timeless. I 'd take a point and click adventure over the next best FPS gubbins any day by now. 

I'd love to elaborate on the story, but it would spoil the fun.

My verdict: I am glad i played this one. It's a true gem. 

Woulda bought it on sale anyday....but that is just because I am a scrooge. I think it is worth full price too.
(Got this game for free during a 'Free to pick-up' day.)

It is ocasionally sprinkled with easy riddle (find a key, deduct the code to a lock) or a minigame. This should be classified as a Visual Novel or at least not feature "Adventure" tag. Kathy Rain ... una mujer con problemas. Pero Kathy tiene muchos de ellos, escondiéndose detrás de un estilo demasiado sarcástico. Aunque cuando su abuelo, el hombre que era más padre que sus padres reales, muere, tiene que enfrentar todas esas cosas que enterró en el subconciente, mientras trata de explicar la razón de su muerte.

Con todo, Kathy Rain es tu típica aventura de píxeles de la vieja escuela al estilo de los Wadjet Eye Games o incluso de Gabriel Knight, algo que me recordaba a veces. Es bastante impresionante que el juego esté hecho en su mayoría por una sola persona, ya que tiene buenos gráficos (píxeles), buena música y actores adecuados para todos los personajes (el juego es totalmente expresado). Además, la escritura está bien, mientras que algunos de los enigmas no son muy lógicos. La historia también se convierte en algo poco lógico y en general es bastante "seria" (así que no esperes una aventura cómica, a pesar del comentario sarcástico de Kathys), a pesar de ser una historia de misterio.
También tiene algunos logros curiosos, que probablemente no obtendrás todos, jugando "normal".
Conclusión:
Al final, Kathy me hizo sentir un poco extraño por ella ... pero no quiero arruinar demasiado el final.
Seguramente es una pequeña aventura agradable, que te hace querer ver el final de la historia. Y eso es lo más importante de un juego de aventuras, para absorberte y hacer que quieras ver cómo funciona, como un buen libro. Al menos para mí.
Así que recomiendo a Kathy en general, a pesar de algunos Menos en acertijos y el final tal vez.

50540735.review:
It's a pretty alright game. Just a standard point and click, nothing innovative. Characters are at least unique and aren't boring to talk to. Main character can be sort of funny from time to time. Several puzzles stretched over the 5 chapters that aren't necessarily hard. Although some of the time you might not exactly know where you're supposed to go to continue the story as you'll lose track of your objective, and sometimes you might get stumped at certain sections. Honestly, I'd say you could probably figure it out without cheating if you're patient, but I'm not patient and simply just wanted to finish the story. So in those cases I just popped open one of the dozens of 100% walkthrough guides to get a sense of direction.
Since the story is completely linear and the combinations for everything except one puzzle remains the same. The replay-ability of this game is practically zero. The music is pretty unnerving in certain zones and the Nature Reserve in particular put me a little on edge the first time I went there. Mostly because of the event that unfolds there after the first time you visit it. So I guess I could say this game has some decent 'atmosphere.' 

Overall, the game's pretty good. It was pretty entertaining all the way through. Almost nothing is predictable, although there is some foreshadowing. I can't recall ever being bored at any point throughout and it's a shame that more events aren't randomized, because then you could actually replay the game without getting bored. Only reason it stays fun is because of the suspense created by different unsolved questions throughout the game.
Which becomes absent once you've played the game one time. But, I digress...

Final rating... 6.5/10

50540081.review:
Increíble aventura gráfica. Recibió muchos premios y nominaciones, incluido el de mejor juego del año. 
La atmósfera tan envolvente hace que este juego te meta de lleno en la historia y anima a seguir avanzando hasta descubrir todos los misterios que ocultan la muerte del abuelo de Kathy Rain.

Kathy Rain es una periodista que tras varios años después de olvidar su oscuro pasado, descubre que su abuelo ha fallecido. Su tarea será investigar los sucesos que ocurrieron tras su muerte.

A lo largo de la aventura, dispondremos de varios objetos y un cuaderno en el que la protagonista irá anotando todas las cosas que puedan surgir.

El jugador deberá entablar conversación con todos los personajes del juego, para así ir recabando información sobre todo el caso.

A medida que vayamos avanzando, poco a poco vendrán nuevas conversaciones y deberemos volver a hablar muchas veces con todos ellos. Nunca se sabe si nos hemos olvidado algunas respuestas, que pueden haberse quedado dentro del tintero.

Los puzzles del juego son algo variados. Muchas veces deberemos resolver algún enigma que requerirá que usemos bien nuestro cerebro, para así poder resolver el misterio.

Por último, solo decir que el precio me parece algo elevado para una aventura point & click, con gráficos 2D. Pero si esperas a una oferta, el juego te valdrá menos. Por suerte, yo lo conseguí gratis gracias a la oferta de ayer.

50526593.review:
I got this game when it was being offered for free on Steam.

[i]Kathy Rain[/i] has a lot of strengths. It really nails the old-school point-and-click adventure game aesthetic while having a much better, much more modern UI. I love the pixel art -- the stormy horizons in the background are particularly beautiful -- and the voice acting is good (as you might expect with Dave Gilbert in charge of it). This game has a thoughtful, well-polished production.

The writing is pretty darn good. While the main character doesn't do much for me -- I feel like snarky main characters, [i]especially[/i] in adventure games, are old hat by now, and Kathy sometimes seems like she's trying a little too hard -- she nevertheless has those moments where I just have to smile. By and large, the dialogue is naturalistic, and I quite enjoyed the overall tone of impending Lovecraftian doom. I'd like to draw special attention to the character named Goober. It isn't too often that I see such a charmingly well-written character! His voice actor also deserves special praise. [spoiler]His "movie buff" sequence was frankly some of the most fun I've had in a Steam game in a while.[/spoiler] A true delight to listen to. Well done!

Some of the puzzles near the end of the game may be challenging. [spoiler]I found the mausoleum-related puzzles difficult, personally.[/spoiler] But everything else, so far as I can tell, makes perfect sense. No moon logic here: everything works exactly as you would expect it to, and investigation is extremely logical. Some of the hints are cleverly built into the dialogue itself. [spoiler]The "electrifying performance" hint is a truly inspired example of that![/spoiler]

If you're a fan of point-and-click adventure games, or if you like well-told stories, give [i]Kathy Rain[/i] a shot. I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.

50524589.review: The story just doesn't make any sense. The game ends abruptly, leaving everything unexplained.

50518865.review:
I can't believe how good "Kathy Rain" is. (I originally bought "Kathy Rain" on GOG, but felt the need to spread the love since it's free on Steam today.) 

"Kathy Rain" is beautifully written: crackers dialogue, deep characterisation (and growth), and a somewhat sad story infused with real humour and empathy—the game is funny when it tries to be funny, which isn't a joke-a-minute a la the LucasArts adventure games or pre-"Walking Dead" Telltale. The acting is mostly top-notch. The prologue starts a bit wonky before immediately bringing in the plot (there's some neat storytelling going on here which I can't get into without spoiling the experience). The puzzles are in the vein of post-golden era adventure games, which is to say they're largely logical, with one or two exceptions (if you've played Wadjet Eye's games, you'll have a good idea). The interface is a bit more old school than those, but streamlined (like "Full Throttle" and "Curse of Monkey Island" sans redundancy). A great, great game, and one that took me wholly by surprise last year. I hope they make more in the series.

In the meantime, I have "Whispers of a Machine" to try out. Happy to support such fantastic developers.

50256231.review:
If you enjoy retro style point and click games, then you must pick up Kathy Rain! 

The story starts off in 1995, a young woman named Katherine who shares a dorm room with her roommate Eileen who informs the protagonist of her deceased grandfather Joseph Rain, she later learns he mysteriously died and insisted on investigating what happened to him after she had to move away with her mother. The investigation lasts for 5 days, each day Kathy learns things about her grandfather past and the mysterious deaths and disappearances been going on in the area. Along with these, you'll learn about the hardship she's been through with her parents. The story is well written and you'll get the chance to choose Kathy's responses in some of the scenes. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1719615731

The artwork is splendid! The retro feel of the pixel art brings back the nostalgic feeling of good old Point&Click games. The characters style, environments, and even the music are all blended together nicely. You can't miss the details of the art in each area you visit. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1718427405

The fast-traveling map gives you the chance to move from an area to another without any backtracking is a good thing the developers did. However, there is no hinting system in the game, especially that you have to solve a couple of puzzles which needs a little bit of logical thinking.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1718428221

The voice actors did an amazing job in this game, each one of them sounded really good and in character, especially Kathy. Also, the game has achievements, some of them are missable if you just focus on the story and not interact with everything in the areas.  
 
Pros:
+Great story.
+Good soundtracks.
+Very well-done voice over.
+Good animation and characters design.
+Fast travel map.
+High replay value. 
+Unlimited save files.
+Steam achievements. 

Cons:
-No hinting system.

Although the ending may leave you wondering about what actually happened. I highly recommend this game to all Point&Click lovers or people who enjoy story rich games.

50165514.review:
Kathy Rain is a pretty solid point and click adventure that is pretty near to greatness but fails to reach it for a reason all too common in indie adventure games. Rushing to reach the conclusion. It's something I've seen many times before and I will probably continue encountering it in games (not just of this genre). 

The premise of the game seems simple at first. You are Kathy Rain, a young woman with a troubled past that learns that her grand father that hasn't seen for years is dead. Reluctantly she decides to attend the funeral and also visit her grandmother. From her she learns of the weird accident that left her grandfather in a vegetative state up until his death. From here, Kathy decides to discover what happened to him, something that will also shed more light to the various events that took place while she was gone. It's a pretty compelling story that slowly expands into something way bigger that our protagonist could ever imagine. But just as things start becoming clear and things go into the supernatural, the game rushes the final act and it fails to do anything disturbing or thought provoking. I won't spoil the story, but the protagonist is called to face her past and she is barely affected to things that should shock her and us as well. Again, as I said it was really close to something great, but the final part of the game feels rushed. 

Visually the game is solid using an art style pretty common with 90s adventure games. Given the game also takes place in the 90s, it feels nostalgic and familiar at least for me who grew up playing every game of the genre I could get my hands on. Some may find it a bit too pixely, but everything is well drawn and with pretty solid animations. 

Regarding the puzzles, almost every one of the ones in the game are on the easy side and won't really trouble a seasoned adventure game player. To be honest the only times I got stuck was because I thought way too out of the box, but if you don't overestimate the puzzles, you will never have any issue with them. Items you can pick or use are very limited, you can't pick or use them before their time, in the more intricate puzzles the protagonist kinda points you to the right direction even when it's not really needed, dialogues are usually just for exposition and furthering the plot (except in a couple of scenes). It's on the (very) easy side, without insulting the players intelligence. 

Sound-wise, kudos for the voice actors, all of them did a great job. I liked the protagonist and her friend, as well as the various NPCs you meet along the way. It doesn't feel cheap, in fact I would even say it is better than most classic adventures out there. Sound effects are serviceable and the music even though is fine doesn't really take advantage of the era the story takes place in.

With the game only lasting around 6 hours (add a couple more if you want to chase all achievements since most of them are hidden and require experimentation), the puzzles being on the easy side and the plot, even though intriguing, slightly missing the ball, I find it hard to recommend the game to the hardcore adventure gamer. Still if you want a more casual adventure with a likable protagonist, interesting premise, decent visuals, without being too puzzle heavy, then it's a solid choice especially if you find it heavily discounted like I did. Give it a shot and who knows, maybe we will get a sequel that fixes the issues of this one while expanding on all it's positives.

Excellent point&click adventure game in the spirit of of Full Throttle and Gabriel Knight.  A must for any point&click aficionado!

Pros
-----------------------------------------------------------
-Good voice acting (Kathy stands out especially).
-Well drawn backgrounds and sprite animations.

-Stable no real crashes or bugs (alt-tabing out caused one problem but i can overlook that compared to other Adventure Game Studio titles I've played)

Meh
-----------------------------------------------------------

-Story ending leaves a little to be desired in terms of closure.  I attribute this to leaving an opening for a sequel.

Cons
-----------------------------------------------------------
-Besides a single alt-tab incident necessitating a restart, none to really speak of which is impressive for a point & click.

Overall highly recommended!  Ending leaves an opening for a sequel, which i would love to play! I will be sure to checkout Clifftop Games upcoming title Whispers of a Machine (if its near the quality of Kathy Rain it will be a must play as well!).

49411356.review:
[quote]Kathy Rain is a brilliant first game from Clifftop Games and is a fun and at times captivating adventure, with excellent voice work and attractive pixel graphics. With its strong and personable, albeit tough, protagonist the game offers a good helping of logical point and click puzzling and an interesting narrative. It’s a little short, but the overall quality is very high and aside from being a little easy at times (which is no bad thing!) earns a definite recommendation in the annals of point and click adventures.[/quote]

Was Scooby Doo a detective show? Did the Mystery Machine randomly breaking down somewhere where strange things were happening show that the gang actively sought out the unexplained? Or were they just nosey? It’s a question that I wondered as I played Kathy Rain, the Scooby Doo’iest of point and clicks, as Kathy found herself involved in a mystery that came out of nowhere…attending the funeral of her grandfather she gets drawn into a mystery that has had a multigenerational impact upon the town in which he lived. 

Kathy Rain, an AGS point and click adventure from indie developer Clifftop Games, could be mistaken for being a Wadjet Eye release at times. With its lovely pixel artwork, character portraits that require a bit of imagination to match up with the lo-res faces, and somewhat sombre tone it bears all the hallmarks of what we’ve come to expect from those masters of the point and click revival. The real question is whether something so deceptively retro is worth your time today. And with no prior expectations the answer is most resoundingly yes.

As mentioned above, Kathy Rain has all the characteristic traits of a typical AGS adventure. Its pixel artwork is lovely however, with bright colours and distinctive character and location work that bring the game to life. Kathy is a distinctive protagonist, and despite the potential lack of detail that can come from pixel art, is a nice change from the typical main characters we see in these more sombre games. In fact every aspect of the game seems lovingly rendered, environments, inventory items and puzzles included, and it’s a rare case of a point and click where the dreaded pixel hunt doesn’t become a common occurrence. 

Perhaps the UI is part of the reason for this, with a large cursor that readily picks out objects of interest and indicates how they can be utilised by the player. It’s refreshing to feel unhampered in this regard and with the dynamic interactivity options (if an item has special properties a small tab appears in its display) interacting with puzzles and the environment itself is never a sticking point. Of course Kathy has a standard inventory bar that expands and contracts as required, and you’ll often find yourself combining objects or showing them to people, but the novel controls are easy use and self-explanatory in their operation, never hindering gameplay.

Puzzle difficulty is something that can be a contentious issue. Kathy Rain has some original conundrums that are enjoyable in their novelty, and of course the typical combine and use problems. On the whole this is not a particularly challenging experience, although there are one or two chokepoints that most will run into towards the end of the game (I bruteforced a somewhat cryptic puzzle involving a poem, which seems to be a common problem). The puzzles are logical in their application, taking a refreshing real world approach which may be in part why the game feels slightly easier than some of its fellows. Of course many will play these games to enjoy the story, and as a result I personally felt the difficulty was perfectly pitched, never requiring a guide but still having some head scratching moments that required Kathy’s assistance to solve.

And hearing Kathy speak was a wonderful experience, largely matched by the entire cast. Of special note is Arielle Siegel, Kathy’s voice actor, who is once again brilliant. She brings Kathy’s dialogue to life and creates an attachment that can be difficult for some protagonists to achieve. Of course the dialogue has to be of an equally high standard to allow the voice work to shine, and thankfully there are no clunkers although a particularly zealous priest can get a little annoying. If asked I’d have trouble recalling any of the game’s themes or musical motif’s, but whilst playing I wasn’t troubled by a poor atmosphere or misuse of music, so whilst not memorable it plays a more than adequate role in fleshing out the tale.

So with an interesting cast and good puzzling, can the narrative match the standard and elevate the game to something special? It’s here that I feel Kathy Rain stumbles a little, and whilst it’s a shame that it does so, it certainly isn’t ruinous. For the first half or perhaps two-thirds of the adventure the plot has a slightly chilling effect, with hints of mystery which could veer off in almost any direction. There are leads and questions posed that seem to indicate the direction of the story, and this serves as a brilliant spur to push the story on. However, the exploration of character’s pasts, and the resolution of all the loose ends is unfortunately unsatisfying and somewhat vague. It’s not an open ended disaster, which would indeed be frustrating, but equally the wrap up ends with a fizzle and not a bang.

That being said, Kathy Rain is a very enjoyable point and click game that I’d recommend to anyone without hesitation, with a quality that easily surpasses some of the output of more experienced publishers. The “Detective is Born” subtitle can go some way to explain away loose ends, with potential revelations to follow, but sometimes it’s nice to have the potential options for explanation a little less vague. As it is the denouement becomes somewhat forgettable which isn’t a tragedy but is a little disappointing. With its 5 to 8 hour play time it’s not the longest game (I finished in two sessions) but it doesn’t feel overly short and there’s definitely room for more of Kathy’s adventures in the future. Play it. Enjoy it. Then watch Twin Peaks.

(...and if you already own the game what are you waiting for?!!)

Puzzle-wise, it made me stop and think a few times, and made me feel clever a few times, but I worked the majority out rather quickly. I'd gladly take a few more eureka moments, but not at the cost of a lot of random guessing, which I have a lot less time and patience for these days, so I was pretty happy with it.

Not sure how long it took, as I left it idle a fair amount. It felt fairly short, but sweet, which is a duration I'm a big fan of.

48591500.review:
[h1]Kathy Rain is a well made point and click game which uses pixel graphics art style and set in the 90s era. This game has a deep and rich story which I found to be very captivating.[/h1]

[h1][u]STORY[/u][/h1]
This game is about a rebellious, aspiring journalist named Kathy Rain who is in search of what happened to her grandfather before he died. You play as her digging through clues and interviewing people you find, to unsolve this mystery.

This game has many elements such as supernatural, horror, badass punk-ish female lead, nerdy sidecick, "cool" hackermen, and many more which I found to evoke the mainstream components of 90s era entertainment very captivatingly. While the story wasn't anything mindblowing, it kept me engrossed enough to finish the game within a day.

[h1][u]GAMEPLAY[/u][/h1]
This game plays out as your usual point and click games. You have a number of locations (which gets expanded as you progress through the game) that you can visit anytime. You have an inventory in which you can keep and meaningfully combine the valuable items you collect throughout the game.

There isn't a clear hint system which you can use to progress easily if you're stuck on a specific part, and I do wish there was one. While I found the puzzles to be fun and logical, some players may not enjoy spending a lot of time on them, and if you do not want to spend a lot of time on them, you will have to look for an external guide or walkthrough.

[h1][u]GRAPHICS[/u][/h1]
The pixel art style is perfect for this game. It made me very nostlgic of the games I played when I was very young, most of which had pixel graphics. However, this game is locked at 4:3 aspect ratio, therefore playing it in a widescreen monitor will make the screen have two black bars on the sides.

[h1][u]SOUND[/u][/h1]
I didn't find the soundtrack to be anything special. It was mild, but I think it suited the game as it didn't intrude the gameplay much. However, I found the voice acting to be pretty good. Every line of the game was voice acted and almost all of it was done in a good way. Although I do have to say Eileen's "Okie-Dokie" started to get annoying real fast.

[h1][u]CONCLUSION[/u][/h1]
Highly reccommend this game if you're a fan of old school point and click games. The game is short and I was able to completely finish it within 5.5 hours (including getting all the achievements).

Kathy Rain is an enjoyable adventure game. I feel a need to give a warning about the game that can potentially be spoilers:
[spoiler]The game has some mild horror elements. This should be expected in a homage to early adventure games. But I personally would consider myself quite easily terrified, so I think it is somewhat fair to state that it is mostly safe if you are like me.[/spoiler]
If we look into the game itself, I think it is a very well put together adventure game. The puzzles in the game makes sense. The story flows. Kathy is a well balanced character with the right amount of snark to keep things interesting while not taking the player out of the game. With a couple of exceptions, voice acting is mostly on point. The early adventure game art style is very well realised in this game. One major issue of the game is with the reminders. Basically if you acsidently skip a crucial information in a dialog, though luck, you are likely not gonna hear it again. Kathy also has a notebook where she keeps important information but the information updates are few in far between so it is also not a great way to remmember things with. This issue sometimes leaves you out guessing what you were supposed to do now. Esspecially if you were to take frequent breaks, getting back to the game is quite though.
Even though I've put it in lenght, I think the issues I have with the game are small. And I'd recommend it as a decent experience.

48242983.review:
A short but tight adventure, with interesting characters and a great and lovely protagonist. It's a bit on the easy side, since the hints Kathy gives with her observations are not very subtle, but that's probably better than creating artificial difficulty.
It's mostly an investigation game, so a lot of time is spent talking with people, more than combiing inventory items, but since the game is very well written, this is definitely a good thing.

It probably lacks polish in the very last part, since it's not really clear why certain things happen; my guess is that the last day of investigation should have been expanded a little bit but they run out of time.

Still, a great adventure game, I recommend it to any fan out there.

48175785.review:
Overall Rating: ★★★☆☆

A fun little adventure game.

   The game is entirely voice acted which was a pleasant surprise. The story isn't what I expected, which was also another pleasant surprise and took some strange twists and turns. Some of the mysteries/puzzles felt fairly satisfying to figure out. It was a good length of time, and it kept me invested enough that I played the entire game in one sitting without realizing how much time had gone by, something I rarely do as I start to lose attention playing a game for more than 2-3 hours at a time. 

Some of my only complaints regarding this game would be the pacing, and the illusion of choice. The story is actually quite interesting, but the pacing of which it is laid out feels a little off. It doesn't feel like there's a gradual or tense transition, you go from normal to abnormal almost without really batting and eye or drawing attention to it. There doesn't seem to be any stress or disbelief in the characters. So, some of the suspense is lost as you just jump straight into it. 
The second problem is, as far as I'm aware the game only has one ending. There are often multiple dialogue options, but as far as I can tell they don't actually affect the outcome of anything. In the few instances where I tried different dialogue options, they seem to just offer different voice lines, and then take you back to the initial selection to have you try a different one...Or in some cases result in similar conversation regardless of the option you pick. This didn't really detract from the over all game though.

[b][i][u] Difficulty Running Game [/u][/i][/b]
Initially it took some tinkering and research to get the game to work properly. I have a fairly high end, three month old PC, running Windows 10...And initially could not launch the game. It would tell me the default resolution was not available etc. To solve this, the options were to run the game in an extremely tiny windowed mode, or have it grossly stretched and disproportionate. If you are encountering certain issues, the fix I found was this: In your Steam directory on your C drive, find the game folder and settings file within that folder. Lower the graphic filter to x2, run in full screen with black side bars enabled for wide screen. I'd found some suggestions saying to change one of the settings to Direct Draw 5 but found this unnecessary as long as you lower the graphic filter to x2.

47593323.review:
Link to review: https://backloggd.com/u/RedBackLoggd/review/279175/

Priced at $15.00, Kathy Rain took me about 6-7 hours to complete, so it technically falls just under my price:gametime ratio for recommendation. Combined with my reservations below about the story, I personally don't think I would recommend this to anyone with my tastes without a small discount. That being said, this is an indie developer, and I always say it is worth supporting them, especially when they do put effort into their craft. Plus, many other people will no doubt enjoy the narrative.

A silhouetted city lit up by a crack of lighting against a neon teal night sky. To the casual viewer, this would suggest a dark, neo-noir world, brimming with crime, decay, and civil rot. It's no place for any sane human being, let alone a young woman wanting to make it as a private eye. She calls herself Kathy Rain, a catchy name for a hardboiled detective set on trying to make her town a better place, one small step at a time.

Alas, that's nothing close to the actual result. Kathy Rain is a point-and-click adventure title rendered in the same old-school, early-PC style as other games like Clock Tower, King's Quest, and early-Lucas Arts' products. Our protagonist is no hardened veteran, instead being a journalism major still attending colllege at Conwell Springs. Springs is a bright place, full of a shrewd vibrancy in spite of its small population. Or so one would think.

Despite my disappointment at this sharp contrast between the title graphic and the actual game, I wasn't entirely disappointed with Kathy Rain. For starters, I've always been a fan of unconventional detectives- people who seemed to sort of fall into the line of work, despite being in that general career path. Easy Rawlins, Matt Scudder, and even Nate the Great. And Kathy joins that line-up quite well. While I did feel her interest in finding out what happened to her grandfather was a bit sudden, her characterization more than makes up for it. She has that sardonic style of humor typical of the "bad girl" archetype, but there's enough depth to her revealed over the course of the game that expands her beyond those parameters.

Visually, the game looks good enough. It's hard not to perceive the whole set-up as low budget given the 16-bit graphics, but developer Raw Fury packs every setting with lots of props and details, providing plenty of eye candy and showcasing the artists were far from lazy. There is no set color pallete either, meaning you get a surprising amount of variety from the different locales. I also liked how there were several character boxes a character when speaking that showed different emotoinal states. There wasn't much there, but it was a nice touch.

Voice acting was mostly positive. I wasn't a big fan of Arielle Siegel's Kathy at first, as I felt she was trying too hard to do a Daria/Raven impression. But you get used to her voice, and her performance overall was good. All the supporting performances were top notch, showing that the developers were committed to providing a quality experience for prospective buyers (and proving a point I made about To the Moon losing something without having any actual voice acting). There was one exception, however, and that was Shelly Shenoy's Eileen. It was clear she was trying to go for "cute badass," but ended up coming off as borderline sociopathic ala Lily Aldrin in Karma.

I liked the diversity of dialogue options, especially when examing stuff or trying to combine stuff. It shows the developers were prepared for the crazy things players would try to do (like drinking booze in front of Kathy's grandma, or tasering someone, or smoking in front of someone).

Sound/music not particularly memorable. Seemed like there was only one tune that played for each area.

The story is where the game gets a mixed rep from me. As I said, was admittedly expecting something grounded ala Se7en or those classic noir movies, but Kathy Rain is much more in the vain of Twin Peaks. There are a lot of subtle supernatural elements that go on behind-the-scenes, and to me it hurt the potential the narrative of this game had. There could have been a deep tale about drug abuse, cults, small town cover-ups, and so forth, but by having these fantasy facets, it makes it more akin to the X-Files. Some people will like this regardless, and it was overall enjoyable. But be warned it's not grounded.

I didn't feel Kathy really got proper character development either. There are two narratives at play here- Kathy becoming more into her journalism career and letting go of her morbid past. The first one doesn't really work because, outside of skipping classes, we never get a sense that she's reluctant to pursue journalism, meaning her ultimate decision to go through with it is blatantly expected. The second doesn't work because we don't get enough on her backstory or her inner feelings, only glimpses. And that would have been fine for an introduction into her, but a big part of the final act is about Kathy confronting her past actions, and it doesn't have much weight to it because we weren't given enough info about it and how they affected her.

But the game never gets tear jerky, and it has a nice maturity to it, never caving into the bad young adult writing tropes that, at times, hit Life is Strange.

Didn't like how entering a new area meant repeating the same animations. It was obviously okay when there was no animation for entering, but coming to places like the Cemetery or the Lake House meant seeing Kathy stop her motorcycle, get off it, remove her helmet, and finally enter. It got annoying.

Kathy also moves too slow ala Clock Tower. It's tolerable since the areas themselves are small, but I would have liked for her to move faster than this Morrowind pace.

There are a lot of puzzles in the game with a good amount of variety. None of them are particularly hard, but that isn't a bad thing in the slightest as their variations make up for that. I would have liked for the developers to make environmental interactions a little bigger as there were times where I got stuck because I missed something ala the Water Temple keys in Ocarina of Time (okay, not that bad, but my point stands).

Also didn't like that you had to click twice to interact an object in your inventory with another object. They should've just had left click allow you to drag/drop and right click to open up the other options of examining/thinking about an object.

One of the biggest problems with the game that kills immersion for me is the lack of consequences for making the wrong choices. There are times where you have to give the right dialogue options, and if you fail there is no consequence- you just restart the cycle. Having the deputy fall for the same "hobo is sick" routine or redoing the same conversation with the Air Force guy, for instance, seems strange considering you're talking to authority figures who should be smart.

45693179.review:
Captivating adventure reminiscent of classics from the 90s.

"Kathy Rain" is a point-and-click adventure using dialogue, combining objects and manipulating the environment to progress. All of these aspects are typical for this genre, but there is one aspect which is not very typical: the largely satisfyingly logic and smooth design of these points. All too often have I come across rather frustrating moments which seem stilted in other examples of this kind of games, but not in "Kathy Rain". I can only remember one riddle which was a bit confusing, but still acceptable. That has been very refreshing.

The pixel art of this title is very charming, and the world is brimming with nice and often funny details, just take a look at the operating system of the computers! In general, different emotions and topics are dealt with: I sometimes laughed very hard, and sometimes the game touched on very serious and sad sides of life. This makes for a manifold experience.

As said in the beginning, the sound is another, if not the most, positive point about "Kathy Rain". Not only the voice acting, but also the music, helps a lot in creating an exciting atmosphere. It increases that storyline and feel of the 90s. There are also some influences of "Twin Peaks" and other pop culture delights of that era in this game.

Apart from the above-mentioned puzzle whose design leaves some room for improvement, I could only find a second minor flaw: the game settings were not saved, so I had to adjust these every time I started the game, but that was not too bad.

So, all in all, I would give this game an 85 % rating. If you like classical point-and-click titles, this one is a no-brainer.

44672427.review:
There are two issues that collectively killed my ability to enjoy Kathy Rain. Either of them separately I probably could have tolerated, but collectively it was too much.

Rain's personality got really tiresome past a certain point. I acknowledge that there are real people who are really performative about how edgy and outside the mainstream they are, but I really don't want to deal with them. Kathy spends way too much time reminding you that she's not like the other girls.

The other issue is, in broad terms, some of the needlessly retro elements. There's a lot of quality of life things that point-and-click adventure games have gotten better about that this game doesn't seem to bother with, like double-clicking to change screens. What's more of a concern is the time-wasting puzzles that seem thrown in mostly to extend gameplay length. I'd be going about my business trying to solve a murder when suddenly I need to trick a college student out of an admin password or make a wacky beverage for a biker gang. It's a waste, because some of the central problems are actually pretty interesting to solve, and the puzzles otherwise play pretty fair. 

Which makes it a waste as a whole, because the art is enjoyable and the central mystery is engaging, but there's just too much junk to wade through.

44524003.review:
Talk to your grandma to uncover some odd info about your family. Find a key item in her attic. Distract a cop at the station to pursue your agenda. Indulge in a fake phone message audio editing puzzle. Ride your motorcycle. Find your way through the woods using some kind of tracking help to find the needed location. Ask your female assistant to do some research... Wait, what? Am I retelling a decades old story about everyone's favourite Schattenjäger dude?!

Nope! That's another game! It's such a pity the developer didn't have enough courage to severe these understandable but completely unnecessary Gabriel Knight bonds, because, should Kathy Rain manage to stand on her own feet, it would make for a much stronger game, plot- and gameplay-wise.

The main character has an interesting background and gets very good development during the course of the game, and the story itself is pretty decent. Seeing this, I'm left to wonder just how much better it could be if only it allowed itself to break from that "female Gabe" mold.

44279242.review:
Kathy Rain is a mystery Point & Click with an intriguing story that takes a really weird turn at some point.

It's colourful, the character portraits are very nice looking and well done and the environments are varied, but the pixel art style of the scenes didn't quite click with me. The music, while nice, isn't very memorable. There is voice acting for all the characters in the game which is sometimes a bit rough, but mostly okay.

Gameplay is a bit irritating overall. There are a few puzzles which aren't too hard and actually logical which is nice, but most of the gameplay consists of asking questions and finding clues. The problem is that, as seems to be the standard for these kinds of games, the player character walks really slowly, and you can't even double click to speed her up. With most  environments being small, this is not much of a problem, but you also have to go back and forth between locations a lot - often times to only do, get or ask one single thing before you have to leave again. All this is also very logical in context, yet still feels somewhat like padding.

You play as Kathy Rain, a journalism student whose grandfather just died. Kathy is an insufferable, edgy, special kind of gal who is basically a prick to everyone she meets. She drives a motorcycle, dyes her hair, smokes, drinks, and has an attitude. At one point in the game she uses the phrase, "I'm not most girls."
It should be obvious that I do not like the protagonist, which made it a bit hard to feel empathetic when she finally started acting like a human being and showed emotions over her dead grandpa and her lunatic of a mother; typical badass bitch who hides her emotions behind sarcasm and a "cool" facade. Cliches can work - this one does not.

Now that that's out of the way, the story starts off very intriguing. A few years before the game is set, Kathy's grandfather was involved in a strange incident and he has never been the same since. While in town for his funeral, Kathy lives up to her future career and starts investigating. Eventually she unravels some sort of religious cult conspiracy thing, and that is where it all goes downhill. Sideways. In multiple random directions.

The last chapter (or day, as the game's plot happens over five days) [spoiler]is more akin to a bizarre fever dream than anything to do with a mystery and it's really hard to tell whether what happens in the last half an hour or so - or even the entire game - was real. The thing about that is, there's a scene after everything went down in which Kathy talks to her annoying friend Eileen and even [i]they[/i] aren't sure whether what happened really happened. My guess is they all ate too many of those fancy flowers and tripped out for a couple of days.[/spoiler]
The last bit of the game is also when Kathy comes to terms with her own past and ... one part of it comes out of nowhere and is pretty much glossed over within a minute. It is not a topic to just bring up like that and then forget about; if there were any hints other than a seemingly tacked-on scene at the start suggesting this particular part of Kathy's past, I must have missed them.
[spoiler]Contrary to that, at least the fact that Kathy had her mother commited to a mental institution comes up often enough but not in an "in your face" manner, so that is actually handled fairly well.[/spoiler]

I [i]would[/i] recommend this game since it is mostly well-done and interesting, but the characters - especially Kathy - were not likeable enough to carry anything and the story was too convoluted to be enjoyable in the end.

Old school type of point and click game with nice old school graphics, good characters and intriguing story.  Main character is somewhat difficult to understand at first, but as the story progresses you can figure her drives.

What I miss the most in this game is the fact that the player is often revisiting the same locations. This reduces the feel of progress. I believe progress should be felt not only through the story but also through visual aspects of the game (more locations in case of point and click games).

Lack of visual progression is often the case in new point and click adventures and I guess is greatly caused by the fact that developers of point and click adventures these days can't find enough money to invest in bigger games with more art.

Kathy Rain was on my Steam recommendations list last year and I Iiked the sound of it.

Point'n'click adventure games with pixel animations = happy Lauren.

So basically you play as the awesome, kick ass biker chick that is Kathy Rain. A young woman who says whats on her mind with a cigarette hanging out of her mouth. She takes no crap from no one. Yet her character arch shows how vunerable she can be underneath it all. However, not can be said for the rest of the cast. They dont make me feel anything for them, which is a real shame. 

Its 1995 and Kathy has returned to her hometown from college to attend the funeral of her granddad. This leads Kathy on a mystery surrounding her granddads passing and some twisted crap that happened back in 1981.

The game reminds me of the LucasArt Monkey Island series and its nice to return to that type of setting. The voice acting is great aswell. The game gives off a Twin Peaks vibe, which is awesome as the game does have some direct references to the show.

I was hoping to see more Kathy Rain games, but seems the developers havent released any news regarding that.

43628319.review:
Kathy Rain is the female protagonist in an detective-styled point & click adventure. To track down the facts and truth about the mysterious death of her grandfather, the player embarks on a quest. Through interrogation and clues that can be found, and occasionally some puzzle-solving, the storyline grows more immersive and compelling, progressing through the game. With a rather sinister moral undertone towards the end. Are you prepared to fight Kathy's (and also maybe your own) demons?

If so, this game might be your cup of tea. 

With somewhat 10 hours of gameplay, despite having virtually no replayability, the game can be catalogued into genres such as hidden-object and/or shorter adventure games.

Graphics are pixelated. It feels more like the devs wanted to take the easy route, rather than to contribute to the gameplay, opting for pixel-graphics. There are some scenes where i'd rather have seen graphics like in Sam & Max or Day of the Tentacle, instead of Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis or the first Leisure Suit Larry's. Sometimes this is an issue when playing, simply because the lack of details in items and environment adds difficulty.

And hard this game can be. More than once i had to resort to walkthrough guides to find the solution. These are the sort of games where one has to find the one and only solution, to be able to progess the storyline. Don't expect any sidequests either, there are some small things that can be done, that have nothing to do with the main storyline, but unlock an achievement or invoke a joke or something. Having to turn to walkthroughs however, tend to suck out the fun, for me at least. Therefor i can conclude that Kathy Rain is a bit too hard at given points.

Voice acting is done superb, especially Kathy's voice is appealling and sexy. All of the character encountered have their own speech, which can be more uncommon in games nowadays. Thumbs up to Clifftop Games for this.

The music is rather soothing and relaxing, tuned in to resemble the right atmosphere at the right time. Nothing too spectacular, but well done.

To my own personal taste, it should have been a bit less heavy on the detective, interrogation style, and somewhat more adventurous.

Experiencing some sort of love-hate relationship with this game, sometimes not playing for 2-3 weeks, then coming back to it, to let it rest again for some weeks after playing half an hour or so. Took me 5 months to complete, and perfect it. Really strange, it seems like Kathy's personality channeled through the program, right onto myself.

All in all, Kathy Rain was an enjoyable experience. Would only recommend it to someone who is specifically into these kind of games, though. If you're new to the genre, or not an oldskool gamer (like myself), you may experience a bumpy ride. However, it is to be endorsed and loved that games like this are still getting made.

Cheers!

43293557.review:
If you don't feel like reading it all, this is the review in short: I recommend this game to people who like old-school point-and-click adventure and don't like difficult puzzles and don't mind a story with plot holes -  others might not enjoy it. Graphics are amazing. I didn't like the ending, I felt it was trying to make people become emotional and for me it backfired into eyerolling. 

Long version from here on!

Graphics : 10/10! I love this pixellated style of graphics and the game looks great. The scenarios and characters are varied and the backgrounds are pretty and easy to see and click on. 

Characters: I can understand why some people might not like Kathy, but personally I liked her. I tend to hate many of the female characters in games, so this was a good change for me. She is cynical and angsty, but she has a difficult past (as we learn in the game), so her behavior is understandable. Even her super religious friend was fun and likable. In general, I found all the characters to likable enough and quite different from each other in design. The voice acting was also good.  However, I thought the ending was a bit out of character (see below). 

Gameplay: this game is not very hard, and the puzzles are quite easy. The only thing I found difficult were the achievements, as some of the actions necessary to get them didn't make much sense. If you like adventures with difficult puzzles, this might not be the game for you - I personally got stuck only in a couple of places and just trying out all the objects in my inventory solved the problem. It's also quite easy to understand what you have to do next, as the main character gives you suggestion.  

Plot: This was the only weak point of the game, that prevented it from becoming one of my favorite games of this year. The premise is great and for a good 50% of the game I was hooked and wanted to understand what happened to grandpa. Then the [spoiler] abortion scene came and I figured out right away about the kid at the funeral [/spoiler], and I started realizing the plot would not get better - on the contrary, the more the story continued the more I was confused about some things. For example,  [spoiler] why was the kid visible at the cemetery while there were no flowers around? Maybe there were some on the tomb, but it should have been made clear. What happens to the bodies of people who go in the hole? Do they physically get lost there, since they are not found? Then shouldn't Kathy see them when she goes down? Who arranged the flowers and got rid of them after (since Kathy still hadn't inhaled the flowers, she wasn't under their effect, so the writing was real)? [/spoiler] 
Okay, maybe the solution to these questions is somewhere in the game and I missed it, but even then, the ending still felt shallow to me. 
Let me recap the story: Kathy [spoiler] discovers by chance through her roommate that her grandfather is dead and decides to go to the funeral. We learn that she wanted to visit her grandparents many times but because her mom had lied to her about them being bad etc., in the end she never went - I don't buy it. She just didn't care enough or she would have gone after committing her mother, and please don't tell me otherwise - she didn't even bother regularly checking if the grandparents were still alive! If people really want to do something, they will. But no blame here, it would make sense for her not to visit them given her history. She then learns her grandfather had a mysterious incident and wants to know more - that's understandable, I would be curious too because the circumstances are weird, not necessary because I care about my grandfather I barely remember. Then one day she finds out her grandfather actually tried to get custody of her before his accident - and all of a sudden grandfather is the best person on planet Earth and half an hour later she meets him in spirit and there's a lot of drama and we are supposed to feel something. B*tch you didn't even care about him being alive or dead a week ago! I understand discovering that he actually cared about her was heartwarming and all, but from there to all this drama - no. It's out of character. If she is really cynical and strong as we are supposed to believe for the whole game, the drama is unnecessary. Otherwise she is just yet another forgettable emo teenage character.  Also, I would like to remind you Kathy, that of course your grandma was busy with grandpa being sick, but he was sick for a million years and your grandma didn't bother looking for you AT ALL in all this time. Just some food for thought.  
The whole abortion story line also bothered me. I felt the writer of the game was trying to force on us the view that a fetus is a person and Kathy should feel something, which is something people might not necessarily agree with. We also don't know the circumstances of the abortion - what is she was raped? Why should she feel bad in that case, if it was not something she wanted in the first place? One of the answers even hints at the fact that she doesn't care - the one I chose, "I didn't do anything wrong" - so why would the kid be in the hole in the first place if she doesn't feel guilty about it? I was eye-rolling through the whole kid part, while thinking "just get out of my fucking way so I can go save my friend". I personally didn't feel anything in that part of the game, and that's a risk with that kind of plot point if it's not well-developed.  [/spoiler]
So in conclusion, while I liked the [spoiler] supernatural [/spoiler] turn the story took, I felt that the final scenes were yelling at me "FEEL SOMETHING!!! CRY!!!" while I'm just sitting there stuffing my face with food, eyerolling and being "b*tch please".  I also feel part of the plot was not 100% explained, but some explanation might come in other games, if there's any, so it's a smaller flaw to me. 

In conclusion, I didn't like the ending at all but overall the game was pleasant, was a steal on discount and I can see that a lot of work went into this, so I would recommend it to my friends who like adventure and I will check the sequel if there's one in the future!

43280872.review: I don't get the high reviews. If the entire game was like the last half hour, sure. But the grind to get there is too much. Pass.

43224339.review:
Firstly: Kathy Rain is a good adventure game. The puzzles are well-constructed, the characters are fun and engaging, the art is really pretty, and I enjoyed the whole game. That's all you really need to know from a review, right? Because I'm going to address something that a few reviews and forum posts have picked out, but it might be a bit spoilery, so be warned.

Still here? Okay: some folks, including one reviewer at the top of the reviews page, think it's a shame that Kathy Rain delves into matters supernatural, and that the climax of the story is a weird/creepy psychological horror confrontation. And I understand, I think there's a game in here that could have been *even better* if it had just been a small, personal tale about a girl with a damaged family trying to make sense of things. But it isn't; it's a tale about a girl with a damaged family that links into a weird, Lovecraftian cult masquerading as a local evangelical church. And I think it's the "weird, Lovecraftian" bit that saves Kathy Rain from being just a Blackwell knock-off. Blackwell is never weird, not in the sense of the genre of "weird fiction". It's spooky, and ghostly, and melancholy, but also cuddly and familiar, and we always know what's going on and what we're seeing. Kathy Rain on the other hand quite deliberately does not explain what you see in the final chapter; it's not ghosts, exactly. She's not in hell, she can come back to to normal world, and we never really find out why the final puzzle is what it is. For me, the creator of Kathy Rain has deployed weirdness as a tool of storytelling. The supernatural that you understand is inherently less creepy than the supernatural you do not understand, and that's why the finale of Kathy Rain works so well; I have no idea why those damn flowers had to burn, but that's because Kathy's small, mortal brain cannot encompass the reality that she touched when she went down that escalator. She's alive, her friend is alive, and the eldritch thing that was breaking the townsfolk has gone away. It's like having a monster glimpsed only in shadow to make it more scary; only instead of a monster, it's an unknowable elder force.

43180321.review:
To begin with, the guys and gals at Clifftop Games has given us a real stonker of a Point & Click Adventure game in the form of Kathy Rain; A detective is born. 

Story (5 of 5): 
The Story is, along with the Sound Track, the strongest bits of this game. The premiss, a deceased Grand Father, who died a cripple and, seemingly, lunatic, gives way to a whole heap of twists and turns as you try to unravel the mystery behind his loss of senses and dissapearances in the town of Conwell Springs. 
Trust me, you won't want to miss it, it tears at your feelings and at the same time gives you small ounces of hope in equal messure right to the very end.

Gameplay (4 of 5): 
The game played like most P&C's do mechanically. There was nothing majorly wrong with any of the gameplay really, bar a couple of times when it felt a bit "iffy" when you tried to combine objects in the way the game wanted you to do it when I thought I had it all calmped down in my own thought process, so mainly my fault maybe... 

Music (5 of 5): 
As a Punk-Rocker, the title music immedietly got me on board, with it's soft start into a heavy riff. 
Going beyond the initial music piece, it's gorgously presented. Every time a new piece of music or sound was put forth, it made sense and set the mood for what was happening or you would, correct or not, expect to happen. 

Puzzles and Riddles (5 of 5): 
Every single puzzle and riddle made sense in the whole scheme of things and like any great adventure game, past or present, put you on the spot to make sense of them. Some times I spent a good bit of time to figure it out and some puzzles were really difficult to figure out, but at the same time non of them seemed, at any point, impossible, a difficult tightrope to walk for a developer but Clifftop Games was able to do so. 
Top notch work. 

Summary: 
An adventure game with a great story, awesome music, difficult but no impossible puzzles and almost flawless gameplay, what else could you ask from an Adventure Game. 
If you haven't played Kathy Rain, it should surely be on your "to play list", I'd put it right up there with the best P&C games I've ever played.
