43123007.review:
The truly disappointing thing about Kathy Rain is that it's ultimately HALF of a really good game. It starts out as an atmospheric small-town mystery. and Kathy herself is obviously trying a bit too hard to be a "tough girl" protagonist, but you get the continuous sense that she's intentionally overdoing it in order to hide the emotional problems she very clearly has, and for the most part I'm on board with that. The relationship with her roommate feels genuine underneath all the snark. The atmosphere is palpable, there were several moments that made me smile, and some of the puzzles are remarkable - in that they're challenging, clever and fitting for what you're trying to do without falling into the loop-de-loop bizarro logic normally employed by point and click adventure games.

Those are the good bits. 

The game goes off the rails - and it goes off the rails HARD - when it tries to take a leaf out of the playbook of the much better established Blackwell series and decides to take a turn for the supernatural. Nothing in the plot adds up satisfyingly, everything piles incomprehensibly on top of each other, and you get the growing sense that the supernatural twist was added simply because the developer thought "This worked for Blackwell, right?!" and an "ordinary" murder mystery wouldn't sell well enough. Which is sad.

And for a final, damning nail in the coffin, the game then tries to do the whole "disturbing psychological HORRORRRRR/protagonist's CREEPY confrontation with herself" thing as established by Silent Hill and (particularly) American McGee's Alice, and it just doesn't *work* because the buildup of those games isn't there. It's about as jarring a tonal shift as you can imagine - the low point being the protagonist's father imagined as a zombie-like bogeyman chasing her - and just feels like a desperate attempt to grab attention because "look how distuuuuuurrrrbiiiiiiing."

The less I say about the game's handling of the topic of abortion, the better.

Just so much: No, dude. Just no. Not cool. Not deep. Not even in the slightest relevant. Back to the drawing board and write about stuff you actually understand.

So that's Kathy Rain - a good potential idea that gets ruined by creepypasta and "deep" thoughts on abortion.

43115394.review:
Kathy Rain is alright. A serviceable adventure game that liberally borrows from well known pop culture iconography. The game does a lot right on the technical side, the puzzles feel reasonably satisfying to solve and generally refrain from dipping into the kind of willfull obtuseness adventure games are known for. The pixel art is lovely to look at and the writing is...serviceable. 

Kathy herself comes across as a bit angsty, but is at least tolerable. The story itself is decent but wholly unoriginal. The game borrows heavily form Twin peaks but lacks the kind of meta-awareness and (by nature of being a pixel-based adventure game) the visual panache and artistry that taps into primal human fear that is characteristic of David Lynch.

Kathy Rain instead seeks to get by on tickling your nostalgia while being as unoffensive as possible. Kathy Rain knows you love Twin Peaks, knows you love classic adventure games like full throttle, and knows you feel an inordinate amount of retro love for floppy disks. And it dutifully serves those moments up to you, albeit bereft of anything resembling a fresh take or a cogent realization of theme. 

That's not to say that Kathy Rain is cynical or overtly exploitative. Rather it is simply the passion project of someone with a lot of love for the 90's (and a lot of technical awareness of the typical pitfalls of adventure games) and nothing terribly new to say. 

Kathy Rain is the B- of video games. Solidly executed but utterly lacking in originality.

43055629.review:
First of all: thanks for translating Kathy Rain into Spanish and also for the effort to translate it into several languages, SOMETHING THAT WADJET EYE GAMES COULD LEARN FROM YOU AND REASON WHY I WILL NEVER BUY THEIR GAMES... but well... Now in spanish:

Kathy Rain es una aventura clásica Point & Click al estilo de LucasArts de hermoso estilo pixelart. (Parece redundante siempre aclarar al "estilo LucasArts" pero la verdad es que no, viendo como de a poco empezaron a salir nuevas aventuras gráficas estilo "Sierra" con la posibilidad de "perder" y sus injusticias asemejadas a Dark Souls o plataformeros injustos.) 

En cuanto lo que es no hay mas que agregar, ya que el fuerte de estos juegos son su historia, ambientancion y personajes que adornan la historia.

Ella es Kathy Rain, una inconformista estudiante de periodismo en el segundo año de la carrera durante la decada de los 90' (mas precisamente 1995), la cual se entera que su abuelo paterno fallecio y que su muerte esta rodeada de situaciones sospechosas e inquietantes. 

Decir mas seria hacer spoiler de todo lo que podemos descubrir en un pueblo tan chiquito como lo es Conwell Springs. La trama oscila constantemente entre la realidad y lo surrealista, lo cual para algunos puede confundir un poco y perderse algo importante de la trama... pero en definitiva se entiende que es un thriller policial con surrealismo, y como tal, todos los elementos del juego acompañan esta trama, incluso a la protagonista, la cual es una chica ruda, de mal genio, pragmática, tiene un mechón de pelo teñido, piercing y maneja una moto... en conclusión: un personaje sombrío y duro que va a hacer juego con los escenarios, igual de sombríos y crudos, que a veces pueden resultar reconfortantes y otras veces inquietantes.

La música esta mas que bien, aunque no varia mas allá del escenario donde se estè, lo que da a entender muchas veces algo como "uh, esta música significa que va a pasar algo malo, raro o que va a dar un poco de miedo". No se si es apropósito que la música cobre este rol de "vidente" el cual te vaticina lo que podría llegar a pasar en el lugar donde te encontras.

El resto... delicias para los que amamos el pixelart: Detallados retratos, escenarios hermosos, generalmente buenas actuaciones de voz, la protagonista es solida y su historia también. Los puzzles son justos, nada imposible o fuera de la lógica. Deben haber 3 o 4 que son de dificultad superior al resto.

Kathy Rain es un solido comienzo para alguna futura secuela. Lo que algunos hacen mal en su intento de revivir este genero (aventuras gráficas), Kathy Rain lo hace bien y de forma aireada.

Ah! Y a no confundirse: este juego toca muchos temas adultos que pueden incomodar a mas de uno. Definitivamente no para gente con mentalidad infantil o niños.

42967210.review:
Original review (demo version):

An amazing, slow-burn detective game that switches off its demo light at a crucial moment. Curses. Flawless point and clicking that's penned by a ridiculously attractive script and has great art to boot. My heart longs for the full version, which I will no doubt spoil myself with in the future.

Complete review:

I stand by all my previous comments. When you're raised on LucasArts games you develop a very high standard for graphic adventures, and until now, only Wadjet Eye Games (Technobabylon) and Amanita Design (Samorost 3) had really dared to reach that peak. I'm happy to say Clifftop Games is a wonderful new addition. Kathy Rain has sophisticated puzzles, well defined characters, effortless UI and a convincing plot that briefly veers into supernatural territory towards the end. Like Thimbleweed Park, there's a tender backdrop to the overarching detective story, and I love how Clifftop isn't afraid to explore those more emotional moments; they aren't cheesy or overdone and add extra layers of depth. 

Kathy Rain's difficulty level is well calibrated, too. I struggled a bit during the latter puzzles but somehow resisted looking up walkthroughs. That's testament to the game's design, which made me genuinely care about pushing through unassisted, and I feel much more satisfied as a result. Kathy herself deserves major protag credit; she's original, fantastically written, and full of wickedly good humour that could so easily sustain a sequel. I hope Clifftop reads the last part of that sentence.

Nothing really sticks out musically in Kathy Rain, save perhaps for the excellent post rock menu theme, but the art style will be a hit with lovers of classic pixel art backgrounds and profiles, as it was with me. Voice acting can be a dangerous gamble in the most popular of titles (audiences are quite subjective, after all) however I found Kathy Rain's cast to be well selected. There's a nice variety of accents, performers are self-aware, and they hit all the right dramatic notes. So while Kathy Rain might be a short playthrough, its combination of fantastic sleuthing, great writing and well-balanced voice acting make it a point 'n' click I won't hesitate to recommend.

42689405.review:
This is a [b]neutral[/b] recommendation.


On one hand, Kathy Rain's story is interesting, and the game was essentially made by a single guy (other than art and voice acting) which deserves praise, in my opinion. On the other, it's really short and easy.

There aren't many locations or items, none of these are hard to spot/find, you always know what to do next and your character, Kathy, often gives you heavy hints even when you face very easy problems.

Personally, I like harder Adventure games, even though that often means presenting players with somewhat illogical puzzles (Goblins 1-3 come to mind... they're old, but a must-play for fans of the genre, BTW). In Kathy Rain, I only got stumped in one puzzle ([spoiler]Safe[/spoiler]) but that was mostly me being stupid. One other got me thinking for more than a minute. Another one was easy, but somewhat interesting. The rest of them was just plain obvious.

If you're looking for an easy ride and/or a fairly interesting story, Kathy Rain should do the trick. If you want a challenge, it won't. Either way, get it for 5 bucks or so, since it lasts only 4-5 hours (unless you wanna go after the Hidden Achievements... apparently I only found 1 out of 15).

As long as you know what you're getting into and don't pay too much, you won't be disappointed.

42650618.review:
Out of all the point-and-click games I have played, Kathy Rain is probably one of my favorites. 
The pixel graphics are really nostalgic and work well with the game (which is ambiented in the 90s, after all), the music is great, the voice acting is fantastic...and I enjoyed the story a lot.

While it's true that Kathy is a total edgelord throughout the first half of the game, she changes; as the story advances, we can clearly see the reasons that have lead her to have this tough girl act. I rolled my eyes more than once at her attitude, but I'm glad I held on and kept on playing. 

I also really like the combination of the gritty small-town realism of Conwell Springs and the magical, surreal atmosphere that peeks through the further you play. As some people have already mentioned, it kind of reminds me of Twin Peaks (and Lovecraftian lore as well).

Anyhow, I would certainly recommend this game to anyone!

42456653.review:
Kathy Rain was everything my Veronica Mars-loving heart wanted and more. 

It's a pixel adventure with relatively easy puzzles that focuses on Kathy, a college journalism student, returning home to solve a mystery surrounding her grandfather's recent death. The mystery at the center of the story is multi-layered, and unfolds pretty nicely as you find out more about the folks in the community. I enjoyed wandering around and finding out how folks were connected to Kathy's grandfather, although I wish there were more interactive dialogue choices.

My only gripe is the story's ending takes a weird, supernatural-esque turn that doesn't really vibe with the previous 90% of gameplay. (And, honestly, gets pretty spooky and violent, which also doesn't match up with previous gameplay)

42454481.review:
Even though this genre is very new to me, Kathy Rain was a calm and an enduring story, that captured my attention from beginning to end.

The setting of the story takes place in the 90's and as a person who grew up in that time, it did greatly justice from the soundtrack to the clothing style of the characters. It made me think of a time when we did not have social media and cellphones were just for wealthy citizens and calling other people. The 90's easter eggs itself range from Titanic posters and the famously used yellow pages are what of a small detail that makes the setting of the game really come to life in those times. 

One of the strongest points of the game was how you are taken along Kathy's story right from the get go and as things start to unravel little by little, you become more engrossed in her quest. The issue I had with the story itself was how it changed its genre by the end. It felt like the writers weren't sure of what exactly they wanted to do by the time it finished. Regardless, I thought the overall arc leading to the conclusion was very solid.

You can say the gameplay is pretty simple. It is your typical point and click adventure and you have to logically solve the puzzels as you go along the storyline. Some were harder than others but none made me want to stop playing the game as I gave up with trying to solve the puzzles that were thrown at me. 

Kathy rain is a gem of a story and adventure game that is ready to be explored. Although the ending is fairly weak in comparrison to the story arc, it is definitely a good game to have in your library if you are a fan of story games and point and click mysteries. 

8.0 out of 10

42152161.review:
Pros:
+ The story was a little weird, but interesting.
+ It usually wasn't too difficult to figure out what to do next. I liked that Kathy's comments about certain objects sometimes provided hints.
+Good voice acting, and if it isn't your thing, you can click to skip through lines faster and just read the subtitles instead.
+ I got a kick out of the computer-related puzzles.

Cons:
- The "puzzles" tended to be so logical that they didn't really count as puzzles. There were maybe four instances in the game that took any kind of thought on my part.
- Solving one of the puzzles requires having Kathy act like a horrible human being - she has to [spoiler]tase a homeless guy.[/spoiler] Kathy was abrasive, but she didn't generally act like a sociopath, so this solution never crossed my mind. It was one of the rare instances I had to check a walkthrough.
- I wasn't a fan of the part of the game that [spoiler]tried to guilt trip Kathy about an abortion she'd once had.[/spoiler]
- Like most adventure games, there's almost no replay value, despite the handful of times when you're asked to select between different dialogue options.

Bottom line: If you need your adventure games to be difficult, then this probably isn't a good purchase for you. If you'd like a decent story and puzzles with a low frustration level, maybe give this a shot.

I had some minor gripes, but when I learned that this game was made entirely by one person I changed my mind.  Nothing that I was going to complain about couldn't be fixed with a sequel.  Please make more games.  Kathy Rain, or otherwise.

For those wondering how this game fairs: I was convinced that this game was actually made in the 90s until I read otherwise after playing.  I assume that was the creative goal, so well done.  Story wise it does go a little over the top, and it didn't have me quite as invested in the characters as Blackwell or most Wadjet Eye games, but the mystery is real so that's cool.  The puzzles didn't regularly have me pixel hunting/constantly backtracking either, like Wadjet's typically do. The interface is a little more cumbersome then it needs to be, but adapting to interface should be your forte if these kinds of games appeal to you.  Like I said, anything discouraging here could easily be overlooked with the release of a tight sequel.

41929234.review: Strange story but in a good way. Overall a pretty decent game. There were a few times I needed to consult a walkthrough, but overall neither too hard nor too easy. I'd recommend picking this up on sale if you're a fan of point & click games.

41923049.review: Kathy Rain isn't very long and the setting isn't particularly ambitious, but what it lacks in originality it makes up in detail. While it starts off with a feel of a fairly basic rebel kid simulator, it quickly subverts all that by giving the main characters enough depth and nuance to make them credible and not just stereotypical charicatures. Phantasmagoric developments are secondary to the real world problems and struggles the protagonist encounters, which pushes the genre of this game towards well executed Lovecraftian horror without ever becoming gratuitously spooky. Only one puzzle was obtuse enough to warrant a peek in the guide, since evrything else was quite logical and involved recent information. The game always manages to remind that it is taking place in the 90's with time appropriate technological limitations that set the plot pace really well. The voice acting is really well done and the minimalistic retro game design is stylish and distinct. Play it if you have been missing the old-school narrative driven adventure experience but don't want to commit to a longer game.

41913572.review: Nice detective game, Kathy's lines are funny

41900464.review: A touch obscure here and there, but aren't most point-and-click adventures? Some good, realistic puzzle situations with clever solutions. Obvious references to Twin Peaks, Full Throttle, Gabriel Knight (big, BIG debt to GK). Overall, an enjoyable adventure game experience.

It's Murder She Wrote: 90's Feminist Edition.

To be more serious, it's an old fashioned adventure game like those from the 90's. It's stiff and not well designed for today. Characters are just stereotypes and caricatures, and the protagonist is just annoying. I didn't like it so I am not recommending it, but if you like that sort of game, where you have to combine items and interview people about a variety of topics it's fine. It just feels incredibly stiff and not well designed in that there is so many options that aren't required. Some people might call this "authentic" but I just didn't click with me. Might be because I have played too many Telltale games.

 I just think that game design has moved beyond 20 years ago, this game is a relic of that time and I guess it's why people liked it. The lack of any resolution changes and the awkward edginess of the protagonist I just completely hated.

41565154.review:
If you are a fan of the genre then I would highly recommend this game! (If you don't already enjoy point-and-click adventures, however, then this won't do anything different that would change your mind.)

The story is interesting, the puzzles are interesting (they are on the easy side if you are a hardened adventure game veteran, but they integrate well into the story), and the main character is interesting and likeable. For the most part it avoids some of the tediousness common to adventure games (it often helps you out rather than requires you to try every possible combination of items or dialog, and it usually doesn't require too much artificial travel back and forth between locations on the same day).

If this looks at all like something you would enjoy then I bet you won't regret buying it and giving it a chance.

41457889.review:
TLDR: Game is excellent! Totally worth the $15 and if you like story driven games it’s a must buy especially if you like classic feeling point and click adventure games.

I bought this game in the humble bundle sale. After playing it I can say I officially would have considered the game a fair purchase at its full price. The story is very well written and compelling. Although the game is a little short the amazing writing and excellent voice acting made it impossible to walk away from and I completed the game in two long sittings.

I do have a couple minor nitpicks about the game, however. The game only really worked well for me in windowed mode which was mildly annoying but easy to overlook after about 5 minutes of getting sucked in. Another minor imperfection that did stand out to me was a relatively limited number of specific situational dialogs when attempting to use items incorrectly. For example, sometimes attempting to use a key in a door that it wasn't meant for would yield a response to the effect of "That action wouldn't be helpful" instead of a more specific "It must be the wrong key for this door". The only time it really stands out though is in emotionally tense moments when Kathy's voice is more intense and emotional to match the current tone. At those points the generic place holder responses for attempting to use an item incorrectly stand out, because she will momentarily slip out of the tone of the situation to give a generic calm or sarcastic response to an attempted incorrect action. 

Those are admittedly some pretty fine-grained complaints that most people probably wouldn't even notice, but I think it helps illustrate how good the game is, that after ~8 hours and 1 playthrough and that's all I have to complain about.

I played the game with my girlfriend and we had different opinions about the ending. Without wanting to give any spoilers I really enjoyed it and was very satisfied with the conclusion, but she felt it got a little to surreal in the last quarter of the game. She did say that the ending wasn't necessarily bad, just not as grounded as she would have liked and that overall the game was still quite good.

I sincerely hope that this review gets at least 1 other person to buy this game and support the developers. My girlfriend and I would really like to see a sequel!!!

41374924.review:
//Full Disclosure: I received this game as a gift. 

Overall, I enjoyed Kathy Rain. It was an interesting point and click adventure which provided the humor, puzzles and intricate hidden details that make the genre enjoyable.

Positives:

+ The art style and VA was excellent. The art is not quite as good as you might see in other games such as Thimble weed Park but its stylized acts more as a homage to the LucasArts style Point-and-Click games.

+ The dialogue was interesting and at times quite humorous. Especially with the character Goober

+The protagonist Kathy Rain is an interesting character, she comes off as this bad ass sarcastic anti-hero  but at the same time the trauma and problems in her life make her a flawed character. While this Characterization has been done before, (Kate Beckett, Anaksha) Kathy problems and stories are interesting enough to keep this story going. 

+ While brief, the game does touch on some sensitive topics such as [spoiler] Mental Illness and Abortion [/spoiler]

Negatives

-The leads can sputter out at times leading one to crawl around the map reading descriptions and trying to reconnect to the story line. A basic hint system might help players who are seeing the forest for the trees. 

- the characterization of the other characters can be a bit week at times. You can get a general sense of what they're about but besides that they don't receive the level of expansion that Kathy does. 

- the fifth day to me felt a bit forced in terms of emotional impact. While the way that Kathy dealt with her trauma was interesting and evocative. the time dealt actually spent dealing with her problems felt rushed. giving more time as a whole to this part of the game could help develop her character and the story more. one suggestion would be to utilize flashbacks or at least expand the sections where she deals with each individual trauma into their own sections or areas instead of some minorly symbolic wonderland backgrounds. Also [spoiler] Kathy Mirror Self [/spoiler] would be a wonderful way to act as a foil to Kathy instead of just the casual white rabbit antagonist that she is currently.

Kathy Rain is a pretty good Point and Click Adventure with an interesting story and a decent amount of polish. I would wait for it to go on sale but I say that about Every Game. 7/10

41363193.review:
Give it a shot, you may be surprised.

Pros
-Competently done point & click
-Nice art style
-Great voice acting
-Logical puzzles

Cons
-Unconventional presentation settings (resolution)
-Politically obvious at times
-Puzzles can lack uniqueness at times

I bought this by chance as I'm a fan of Point&Click adventure games and thought the art style seemed nice enough.  I did notice that the game had some political vibes to it and was a little worried.  While there are some poorly executed moments, I would still encourage people to try and play through them anyways.  They're usually brief and don't linger too long.

I struggled more with the lack of humour as I'm very accustomed to Monkey Island / Indiana Jones / King's Quest games and the sort, so playing a Point & Click game in a thriller/mystery context took me some adjusting (no fault on the game, just something to expect if you're in the same boat).  While I felt like stopping at times, I was also motivated to continue.  I don't know if it was the mystery setting or what, but there was definitely something unique in what the developers made here that made you curious to push ahead (good job!).

The puzzles are done well enough and very logical.  I never felt like the answer didn't make sense or was so abstract that you'd never figure it out (except for one).  Having said that, it did feel like some of the puzzles were too logical.  I haven't decided if that's a good thing or not and am conflicted.  I must sound like an abused person that can't decide if to stay or go.

In terms of feedback, I would encourage the developer to avoid trying to label "right" and "wrong" issues and simply let them play out.  Most people would admit that they're not interested in playing a pro or anti *insert political theme here* game.  At most, they'd much rather play a game that explores the themes of said *insert political theme here* and let the audience experience the events from different perspectives or contexts without judgement.  Funny enough, there is one topic the game tackles this way through a character flashback and I was really worried it was going to be handled poorly, yet it was handled very well by simply showing the character's struggle rather than trying to state whether it was the "right" or "wrong" thing.

Overall, good game, definitely worth getting for ~$5 and looking forward to a sequel or another point & click adventure from this team.

41315491.review:
Very competent and easy on the eyes nostalgia trip, conjuring up Gabriel Knight, Twin Peaks and the 90s in general. Great pixel art chars, very pulpy detective story with maybe a few cliches too many. 

Typically for a retro point&click you run around a number locations questioning characters, keeping a list of clues (& dialog topics) in a notebook. You also acquire a neat tape-recorder for listening to scattered audio logs with disturbing confessions. All fully and professionally voice-acted. And kudos for offering several interaction choices per hotspot.

Nothing special here for adventure game puzzle lover. Puzzles are mostly typical computer login/password or safe code guessing fare. And the game throws at you an abundance of hints that practically give away the solutions. A few more unusual puzzles practically solve themselves if you keep clicking, especially one puzzle refrencing a memorable GK2 moment. I wish the creators added a difficulty setting instead of opting for making it this easy for all.

Like it lost its initial punch and intrigue. It felt like it just dragged on... and on... and on... Until the story got bored and, rubbing its hands, proclaimed "Sequel time!"

The other weakpoint, in my opinion, is Kathy's personality. She shows real human emotions once or twice. She is an unlikeable douchenozzle, pardon my French, that pretty much attacks everyone in her path, apart from her grandma (you meet her at the very start, so no spoiler). I mean, I get it. She had feces thrown on her face multiple times by life, but that doesn't entitle you to make innocent people miserable. Kathy, those people are trying to do their jobs. [spoiler] That childhood friend cop, Lenny, wanted to take you to dinner and your most polite response, sorry correction, YOUR ONLY polite response was "No, I am busy". with most of them tending towards the "Bite me loser!"[/spoiler]
Or
[spoiler] You tased that poor bum, then thought about tasing him again. For the love of all that's holy Kathy![/spoiler]

The UI is ok-ish... I am no programmer and I don't know want to elaborate on that, due to my incomplete knowledge. I am just saying some improvements would be appreciated.

I can't recommend it for anything more than 5-7 euros.

Booting up the game I was immediately reminded of Gabriel Knight Sins of the Fathers and playing it only simply served to bolster that feeling. The developers clearly have something good in their hands and it is left to be seen how and where they will take this franchise to.

Story: What distinguishes a PnC game from the rest is the story, and Kathy Rain has enough intrigue to keep you wanting to play more of it just to see the end. The story starts as any typical mystery would but halfway through evolves into the absurd. Finishing the game you will see where the developers wanted to take the story but I strongly feel that they could have done it a little bit better.

Graphics: Very 90's feel similar to the original Sierra PnC games (for those who remember lol).

Controls: Pointy and Clicky. Though I wished they added warping to speed up travelling, but that would have taken a big chunk of the game time I suppose.

Gameplay: Simple and intuitive enough puzzles that some actually had me scratching my head/beard, if you've played enough adventure games you can probably breeze through this like a champ.

41247725.review:
Kathy Rain es una aventura estilo clásico, point & click, con un arte también de la epoca dorada de las aventuras gráficas.

Manejaremos a Kathy Rain, una chica badass que quiere ser reportera pero aún está estudiando, y que debido a un asunto familiar se verá envuelta en un caso con tintes paranormales para descubrir que pasó en el año 81 y de paso sacar algunos esqueletos del armario.

La historia está bien, se hace interesante y es un gustazo ver como va avanzando la trama poco a poco y como va todo muy bien ligado, aunque quizás el final se les haya ido un poco de las manos, aun así es muy disfrutable, la resolución de los puzzles es lógica, siempre te van dejando caer pistas de lo que tienes que hacer, y salvo algun puzzle todos son bastante sencillitos, lo justo para tenerte pensando unos minutos y seguir avanzando.

Los personajes, escenarios y nuestra protagonista están bien, obviamente Kathy es la estrella y siempre tiene algun chascarrillo o alguna salida que resulta divertida, sobretodo al interactuar con el escenario o ir probando combinaciones, los personajes secundarios están bien sin más, limitados a decir sus frases y hacer sus acciones, no tienen mucho trasfondo y salvo la amiga y quizás la abuela los demás estan un poco por estar, sin tener un background y que aparecerán varios minutos en todo el juego.

La banda sonora está bien sin ser nada del otro mundo, acompaña y ya. Tiene una duración de unas 6 horas aproximadamente, tomandotelo con calma y sacando todos los trofeos (la mayoria perdibles, asi que recomiendo guardar partida al inicio de cada "dia")

En conclusión una aventura gráfica rápida, sin complicaciones, con una historia correcta e interesante, sobretodo en su inicio, algunos chistes que están bien, asi como algunas situaciones y escenarios. Si lo ves baratillo es worth.

41193286.review:
A tidy little point and click adventure!  

Kathy Rain has a charming look, decent (for the most part) voice acting and a story engaging enough to see you through to the end of the game.  

In many ways a love letter to older adventure games (full throttle, in particular), it maintains that solid and satisfying gameplay of poking around and trying objects on everything in sight.  

My only gripe is that it's a bit easy, but who says an adventure game needs to be frustrating?

41189974.review: The pacing of the narrative works well and kept me wanting to push forward and find out more. I would certainly recommend this game if you like point and click adventure games or like narrative driven games that have slightly darker and mature themes, but still manages to have moments of humour.

41185024.review:
Good game. Plays like a classic adventure game, looks good, sounds good. The 320x240 graphics give the game the same feel you get from classics like Full Throttle and Monkey Island. But you can already see that from the screenshots. The writing is good, voice acting is also good.

If I had to find something to complain about, it's that the puzzles are not very difficult, but that's just me. On the other hand, the puzzles are *real* adventure game puzzles. You're not presented with chess puzzles, sliding tiles mini-games, or anything like that. Puzzles are purely environmental, and solved by observing your surroundings, and/or using information you gathered so far. The only exception I found is lock picking, but it's a very easy version of the Splinter Cell lock picking mechanic, and it doesn't actually feel out of place at all. Basically, it's just there to make you feel like you're actually picking a lock rather than having the door open automatically just because you used a lock pick on it.

And I'm happy to say, there's exactly *zero* pixel hunting in this game. By pressing the space bar, you always know what's in the current location without having to scan over every pixel with your mouse. Also, when examining objects, your character doesn't have to walk up to the object first before describing it; you can just examine things from afar.

Finally, I've seem reviews describing the protagonist as "goth" or "emo", and I'm not sure where that comes from. Looks like a rock or metal biker kind of person to me. Has an electric guitar in her room too. And has a strong dislike for religion. If "militant atheist metal biker" is a synonym for "goth" or "emo" these days, I must have missed the memo.

If you like this type of game, it's highly recommended. If you're not sure whether or not you like this type of game, there's a demo (note the "Download Demo" button on the store page) and you should definitely try it.

41126108.review:
Let's not kid ourselves, the game's writer has issues. Specifically political ones that he absolutely has to convey, even when they sound out-of-place or about as subtle as a shovel to the face. I can't imagine any professional writer thinking it's a good idea to have your main character quote gun statistics when being hinted at with said violence - it's jarring, it sounds like a joke and makes me as a player desperate to find any dialogue option that says "JUST EXPLAIN CLEARLY WHY YOU'RE HERE, IDIOT. STOP ACTING LIKE THIS TO EVERYONE YOU MEET." It doesn't help that the main character is asocial, manipulative and introduced so poorly that any sympathy flies out the window.

I get the idea is for Kathy to feel really cool when she snarks and curses her way out of everything, but to me it only sounds like a Mary Sue. A self-absorbed perfect character who can do nothing wrong and will always get away scot-free. She doesn't even get a stern look from a man she tazered as a distraction - this isn't Day of the Tentacle, this is supposed to be taken seriously.

It gets even better when the game has an abortion subplot. Heavy subject in a seriously toned video games? Sure, I can roll with that - so how does it go? [b]Spoilers ahead if you care.[/b]

1. You introduce the abortion in a dream about the past of the main character.
2. You show a ghostly boy yelling at her about it, and she tells him that she did nothing wrong. He dissipates, conflict is forever resolved in the main character's mind.
The end.

I wish I was kidding. How was this even relevant to the plot in any way anymore? I expected the game to have something to SAY since it wanted to bring this up in the first place, and it's just a wet fart of a "this is how the writer feels, kthxbye?" This is something you'd expect from a sunday school cartoon, no one else could be this lazy just plopping their own opinion on the floor with zero effort.

The game just kind of peters out, no showdown using puzzle logic to emerge victorious, you just leave and set everything on fire. WHAT??

If you ever wanted a cool female character you could identify and sympathize with throughout the ordeal, play Blackwell instead. If you wanted a better psychological story with lots of surreal imagery, play Fran Bow instead. If you relate to Kathy, please seek friends and help.

Kathy Rain is pretty good stuff. The art was consistently good, the voice acting was mostly great, as was the writing. It's pretty light on the puzzles, for the most part, though I'll admit I got stumped on the poem section. I think I was over-thinking it, not taking it literally enough.

That's ok by me, though, especially since it gets kinda Lovecraftian by the end. 40907069.review:
Kathy Rain is a wonderful gem of a game that has some stellar voice acting coming from its well-written characters tied together with a compelling narrative. A point & click adventure that I'm sorry I missed out on and am glad to have finally experienced.

The gameplay is about what you'd expect from a point & click adventure game, but Kathy Rain has a twist on the formula that I loved the hell out of. With "A Detective is Born" being the subtitle, you get a lot of moments in the game where you are more or less interviewing people, going down a checklist of relevant things to ask trying to gleam any useful information out of them so that you can find out where to head next. While linear for most of the beginning parts of the game, I felt like I had a lot of ground to cover and no particular order in which to pursue leads. Maybe having more things to investigate at once would be cool. However, that might be overwhelming for some but I would have liked more times in the story to have multiple objectives. I did get very stumped a few times...Okay, maybe a lot. One puzzle requires knowledge of the rules of Scrabble, I'm pretty sure, kinda gave up on most of the hardest parts and just looked up a guide. But that's just me, I hate getting my progression blocked in games, but maybe others would like to take it easy and try to figure it out on their own. You'd certainly be more patient than me (read: Smarter).

Mostly what was compelling me to move forward so quickly though was the narrative. Every character felt like a real, living breathing person, thanks in large part to a combination of high-quality writing and voice acting. Characters acted in believable ways and answered questions to reveal just enough info to point you where to go next without outright telling you whats coming next. Kathy Rain the titular character is also great, which is good because there isn't a point in the game where she's not on screen, being the main character kinda does that. She's witty, funny, and has enough darkness and characters flaws that no one could get away with calling her a Mary Sue.

I don't wanna say more because that might start entering spoiler territory, so let me tell you that I loved this game and wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone interested in a good story and quality voice acting.

40895262.review: I was not expecting this game to go in the direction it did and I was pleasantly surprised. If you enjoy point-and-click adventures with something weird going on then this is the game for you.

40870803.review:
From the very beginning of the game it becomes clear that it was written by a man who seems to have a really narrow view on women. 

The female main character is supposed to be cool but is just really annoying. She displays her coolness by dismissing everything that might seem feminin. Like: „Reading women‘s magazines gives me headache.“ Because clearly being a woman, doing stuff that is associated with femininity is despicable. 

She‘s proud on beeing „not like most girls“ as if there really was somthing like „most girls“ and if „most girls“ would just not be cool. She is comlimented for this by men.

Really harmful is how the game adresses sexism. Kathy solves a problem by calling her opponent sexist which is not the truth. As a result the opponent immediately excuses himself and gives Kathy the information she otherwise would not have gotten. Calling someone sexist without reason is displayed as a female superpower which opens doors straightaway.

In real life women are confronted with sexual behavior all the time and it is really hard to address this especially to the perpetrator himself. That would be a story worth telling. 

Also annoying is the trope that women who had an abortion later are haunted by nightmares about their unborn child because of the guilt they feel.

Also: The evil antagonist seems gay by the way he talks and the eccentric way he dresses himself. A homophobic trope repeated again and again in media. As a player you can choose between the options to shame him for wearing make up or to tell him he‘s looking like he had escaped a circus.

And why is it important, that Kathy got her guitar from a lesbian? The information is irrelevant for the plot. It is nice to have gay characters in media but we don‘t learn anything more about this person than her sexual orientation. It‘s added to the game to proof the edgy side of Kathy who has met a lesbian once. 

Although it is nice to have video games with female main characters, when they just repeat sexist stereotypes, it is better to not write them in the first place.

Still rating up because it's a nice game, but wtf is that technical stack? :s

40646189.review:
The year is 1995, and Katherine Rain is a collage student, who's working on her second year, hopefully to become a full licensed journalist one day. She's not your typical student, though, she had to grow fast and learn about her surroundings quickly, which clearly left a contempt for the human race. Kathy is a tough girl, nor has tough as her biker looks, but still pretty tenacious. She enjoys horror movies, long rides on her bike, annoying her roommates with her guitar, her pack of smokes and sleeping till late. Her adventure starts with this last part being obstructed. Eileen, her roommatewakes her with breaking news; someone named Joseph Rain died, and his funeral will take place in Conwell Springs, Kathy's hometown! Could they be related?

So it begins, the story is unleashed in a storm of events in which Conwell Springs will never be the same. This small town that served as a birthplace for Lil' Kathty is surrounded by mystery. She doesn't remember much, but she has fantastic memories of her grandparents. Joseph was a loving grandfather who fought in WWII, a dogfighter pilot, and a passionate person. One which Kathyhas fantastic memories, and moderately the only good ones, since her father disappeared, and her mother became mentally unstable.
Kathy grew, but she left her childhood in Conwell Springs, and now only nostalgia remains. She hasn't even heard of the tragic episode from 1981, when her grandfather had an accident... A strange circumstance, where Joseph became catatonic, one of many strange incidents occurring in such a small town, where missing reports are away over the charts.

[b]Kathy Rain[/b] involves the player into a plot surrounding the events behind Joseph accident, and goes deep, deeper anyone would ever imagine, to a point of defying Kathy's own beliefs. Her investigation starts as merely a curiosity in hope to close the matter so her grandmother can have some rest, but clues all over town start to pop-up and our main protagonist can't ignore them.
Being a journalist is apparently in her blood since Joseph himself was conducting a private investigation regarding a very specific event, where three bright lights irradiate from the woods. Around them is a deep fog of questionable reports, events and a mist of frightening reactions. 
The plot will take Kathy to uncover different locations, all related somehow to the story.
Locations across Conwell Springs are simple, but camouflaged in a web of lies, such as the strange church aiming to deliver divine guidance, with an obvious tainted intent regarding its purest. Or even your typical police station holding an alien-believer homeless, and a deputy who's a childhood friend.
Undisclosed matters are present everywhere, in particular with Lily Myers, a young girl who committed suicide, leaving behind secrets within her passion for painting. WMuch, much more mystery and secrets are present in this contemporary community. But on the outskirts of town, the enigmatic and obscure woods stand immaculate, with strange clues being held by a bald man dressed in red. Kathy has to discover the truth, not only about Conwell Springs, but about her as well. Her past decisions, are very much still alive within her.

[b]Kathy Rain[/b] would benifit strongly with a resolution update, ther current one (320x240), is small, and considering how everyone plays in full-screen, the whole resolutions just ends stretched, making it feel wierd, although not unconforteble. This is probably due to the game being developed for mobile, or just poor-development decision.Resolutions aside, the game is fantastically well design with pixel art that will leave the old-school fans both impressive and nostalgic. [i]Clifftop Games[/i] made sure to fulfill every area with details not only to interact but to spoil the player, as we walk across a very distinct handful of areas resembling a small town in America. Pixel art is always a challenge to accomplish, when done correctly, that is, and since this is such a good case, I can easily stare at how nice even little objects look, such as computers, or phones, even at stretched resolution when playing in Fullscreen.
Much later in the story, one can easily see inspirations from Silent Hill, where the beautiful landscapes of American's heart become replaced with gears grinding memories, and saws going trough the flesh, seeking answers.
The characters are very distinct and well designed based on their personality, presented in a western style, losing quality only because (once again) of such resolution limitations.

Gameplay goes as simple as [i]Point & Click[/i] means, bringing back the classic, with style. Object interaction is made gracefully, with dialogues for at least 60% of the displayed objects on screen! Kathy can Think, Look and Interact with gadgets and people, giving a wide variety of opinions and hints regarding the specific event. Puzzles demand the player to be focused on the story, in particular names and dates. Everything that becomes relevant is noted in our notebook, such as questions and hints. As for objects, they are kept in a nice brown-backpack that resembles one used by a famous tomb raider! Kathy can combine objects, like tapes in a dictaphones, or showing a photograph to a specific character, hoping for more answers. We can move Kathy by clicking the desired position with our mouse, and we can freely explore every area, and once in a while, crack the traditional puzzles, which are very well constructed and smart, playing with words and numbers.

[b]Kathy Rain[/b] audio works go behind your traditional indie game. The voices are done extremely professionally, with a dedicated director who made sure every single character sounds, and feels exactly as they need to. Each one suits the profile, from the accent, age, personality and even state of mind. It's a work of art, and probably the biggest factor that will attach players into the game for the very first hour. 
Wordplay comes into the show, with 90's references, sarcasm, smart humour, and even with interactions with the player, creating amusing moments!
The soundtrack becomes one with the game, for every mood, and situation. The soft, deep drums, the distant guitar notes, or the piano tracking each footstep creates the perfect atmosphere! The soundtrack is smooth and easily becomes pleasant, worthy of being listened outside the game! It's not for sale though, but it's included with the game, and nowadays, that's always a a pleasant surprise.

[b]Kathy Rain[/b] is a fantastic adventure of a young woman, who fight her own inner demons while discovering what happened to her beloved grandfather. She has to save more than just herself, while dealing with her own problems. Her lost relationship with her mother, her guilt for one less live in her life, all the anger towards her father... Everything becomes a whole, and once you fall into a [w]hole, everything becomes raw, true, transparent, except lucid. It's up to Kathy and the player to overcome everything, uncover the real facts, and becoming a detective!

8/10

40397919.review:
A tremendous success in many ways:

1. The pixel art is extremely good. Both the character animations, character portraits, and the backgrounds are all top-notch work.

2. The voice acting, sounds, and music are all very good. Far better than what I expected for a small dev company to achieve. The protagonist in particular is very well written and acted.

3. The story is compelling. I thought it was going to be a straight-forward murder mystery, or something, but it takes some delightful turns into different genres.

4. The mechanics and puzzles are well designed. The game doesn't punish you with long waits for having to try things multiple times, and it trims your inventory and destinations so you can make more intuitive leaps of available courses of action.

Definitely recommend for fans of the point-and-click adventure game genre.

40260727.review:
This was a delightful little game.  The whole feel of the game from the graphics to dealing with spiritual "strife" so to speak, reminded me so much of the wonderful Blackwell series.  Katherine Rain reminds me of Rosa Blackwell with her snark.  But do not go thinking that Kathy is Rosangela's pixelated twin.  For their similarities, they are still two very different characters.  The outward appearance, Kathy looks like a biker chick who enjoys smoking, detests religion, is proud of her custom built chopper, and could not care less what anyone thinks.  Yet you get the glimpse of her true self throughout the game.  You see that underneath all that snark, she is a human being dealing with some serious emotional issues while trying to uncover what really happened to her grandfather all those years ago.  

The game is not that long, but the content is well worth the asking price.  I do hope that this becomes an ongoing series.  With the way the game ended, I kind of get the feeling that we'll be seeing more of Kathy Rain in the future.  I still cannot believe that this game was put together by one person.  Seriously awesome for a one-man game.

It definitely has a stronger, more dramatic, and emotionally deep story-line than the ND games. Great art, great soundtrack, excellent voice acting. Totally worth checking out. Worth the price, too.

39947429.review:
I first heard of Kathy Rain through simple means. I caught a glimpse of piece of art featuring a leather-clad lady riding a mean chopper. My interest picked up when I realized she was the main character of a videogame, so obviously I went to the steam page and bought it preemptively.

I’m not accustomed to adventure games and I have little experience with point-and-click interactive media but not only did I have a soft spot for ladies operating mean-machines but I was in the mood for a relaxing mystery for a change. And you know what? I have no regrets!

Kathy Rain puts us into the literal tough leather boots of none other then Kathy Rain herself, a tenacious, sarcastic chain-smoking rebel drinking her way through college, rebounding wit and dry cracks off her bubbly Christian roommate until she is brought to a small town in the country following the sudden death of her grandfather. It doesn’t take the player nor Kathy too long to realize something ain’t all what it seems in the town nor were the circumstances of her grandfathers death anything but circumstantial.

Right off the bat, I was sucked into the atmosphere of the game with it’s slick art-style and quick-witted dialogue. I am normally jaded by quick-wit in media (anything by Joss Whedon comes to mind) but I simply fell in love with Kathy’s cracks and observations. She’s snide and a trouble-maker, but is observant, determined, knows when not to go too far and has a bit if a heart under her tough biker jacket. Other characters you meet are well-written and offer entertaining dialogue and confrontations between clashing personalities.

Of course, it being a point-and-click adventure game, the environments you find yourself in will have to be searched for any means to continue Kathy’s investigation and serve logic puzzles for the player to solve. I had a good time rummaging through the environment and getting those “EUREKA” moments as I cracked the codes and rummaged through my clues for the answer, and as someone who very rarely plays games like these, it’s either a positive highlight or just an example of me being a newbie to such a genre.

Of course, no game is perfect. There were a couple of moments where I gave up and rummaged for a (Thankfully spoiler free) walkthrough, judging from several comments, I feel many people got stuck on the Phone-call segment back in the Dorm-portion of the game. There are also a (admittedly) very small number of animation glitches that occurred during dialogue here and there but thankfully it did not detract from the overall experience. And while the voice-acting was pretty damn good and engaging for the most part, there are a handful of voices that clash with the mood and tone.

All and all, I greatly enjoyed my time with Kathy Rain and route it went. I’m not accustomed to this genre, but I am seriously looking forward to whatever the creative team behind this cooks up next!

I sincerely hope we get a Kathy Rain 2!

39642161.review:
I will start off by saying this is one of the toughest games I have come across to review, whether to recommend or not.

Overall I thought the game was good, but the story (beginning to conclusion) was extremely lacking. This is one of those situations some would say "Oh, you just didn't understand it", but there is much more to it. So I will focus the review on story since the rest of the game was done quite well. Some reference will be a bit vague since I am trying to keep it spoiler free.

STORY:
It felt a lot like a M. Night Shymalan story, not his earlier movies though. The story touched on multiple issues such as mental illness, religion, family, abortion and inner struggles. The most frustrating thing was the lack of transition between them all. It was like they were all thrown in bubbles and tossed together, but nothing tied them together well. The most frustrating part is I have more questions finishing the game then I did when I started, but the game is concluded...there is no follow-up (even though its obvious Kathy Rain is wanted to be a series).

Pros:
Graphics - Pixel and great portraits
Kat Rains is HOT
Good character development
Voice acting is great
Realistic puzzles, not too difficult

Cons:
Minor sound issues with skipping/stuttering dialog
Story suffers from ADHD

Do I recommend?
My initial reaction is no, but I absolutely hate giving a thumbs down to someone's creative work. I enjoyed many parts of the game, but was disappointed by the experience.

I just hope if another Kathy Rain is developed then this game becomes a learning experience to make the next better.

39490871.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/al39ajl/]here[/url].

8.5/10

Despite the fact that it only rains, like, once in the game, and she never carries an umbrella, Kathy Rain is one of my favorite modern point-n-clicks I had the privilege of playing.

Starting out as a straightforward mystery and ending up rather Twin Peaksy, Kathy Rain ups the ante slowly, cooly, and with nice pacing. The eponymous Kathy Rain is a punk sophomore in college for journalism when her plucky, polar-opposite roommate Eileen lets her know that her estranged grandfather had just died. When Kathy goes to the funeral and reconnects with part of her family she hadn’t seen since she was a young child, she begins to follow the story of what, exactly, happened to not just her grandfather, but to a number of missing and insane people of the town.

I don’t want to spoil more of the story, because the way it’s unraveled is really fun. The pixel art is gorgeous from the incredible backgrounds to the satisfying and fluid animated sprites. The writing is cool, and Kathy is able to be both at once annoying and likable, like a lot of college students can be. The voice acting in particular was great - it was produced by Dave Gilbert, of Wadjet Eye fame, and ol’ Davie even made an appearance as a minor character.

Point-n-clicks are often criticized for really obtuse puzzles, and Kathy Rain avoids this in a wonderful way. The game is set in 1995, and the best, most satisfying, crunchiest bits of gameplay is just… acting like it’s 1995 again. Using a phonebook, tapping in phone numbers, and dealing with an old timey-ass computer was just so fun for me, for some god damn reason. Most of the major ‘puzzles’ are logic ones about tracking and following information, which is apropo for the game and works really well.

39164145.review:
This is a little gem of a game. If there's such a thing as an old school adventure game renaissance, Kathy Rain is surely on the forefront. An obvious homage to Gabriel Knight: Sins of our Fathers that evades most of the pitfalls that many retro adventures fall in to.

Sure, there are weaknesses: the characters aren't terribly deep, some puzzles are a bit contirved (but far less of them than in most games of this type), the environments are a little bland and same-y and you visit the same handful of them over and over again. Nevertheless, I wholeheartedly recommend Kathy Rain to any fan of "classic" adventure games. It doesn't revolutionize the genre by any means, but it's a damn enjoyable celebration of it.

38825997.review:
This is an interesting little game that starts out like a seemingly logical mystery adventure with Kathy investigating the death of her grandfather. It takes a while to get going before it slowly becomes surprisingly...eerie. Without giving too much away, all I'll say is that it's not exactly eerie in the Gabriel Knight way (even though Kathy Rain kinda resembles the famous New Orleans point 'n click protagonist with her hot bike and witty lines) but rather in the...Silent Hill/Lovecraft kinda way?! I've seen a lot of people throwing Twin Peaks around as a comparison, and even though I've never seen that show, it seems like an appropriate point of reference. In any case, be warned - there is a lot more here than the marketing is letting on. 

Also be warned: the plot ends without answering half of the (VERY) weird questions that it provokes. It gets wrapped up in its own metaphors in the last hour and becomes one of those "MAKE YOUR OWN CONCLUSIONS!!!" kind of things, which I usually hate, but in this instance... I still felt oddly satisfied at the end of my 10 hours? I think it's because the writing is solid, the puzzles are mostly enjoyable (especially some clever ones involving a computer) and Kathy herself turns out to be a very endearing protagonist that I would like to see more of. 

So, a tad rough around the edges, but if you're in the mood for a suspenseful adventure game and don't mind some ambiguity this is pretty good. Best enjoyed with black coffee, on a rainy day with cig breaks in between. I would buy a Kathy Rain 2.

38770549.review: Good mystery game to pass the time

38740580.review:
Technically this game was very well executed! Audio quality is great on speech and music. Some of the music tracks were quite captivating and moody to the theme. A few scenes left wishing for bit longer loops in the music tracks. Graphically really good and the interaction with the environment and puzzles were well implemented. No tiny pixel hotspot hunting, but objects can be reasonably easy found. Also no nonintuitive cause-effect interactions in e.g. unlocking new scenes or locations that point and clicks sometimes have.

The length of the game was suitably short. Do remember to save often, at least in v1.0.3 there is an occassional "CreateOffscreenSurface failed" crash to desktop that happened once every ~hour or so, which corrupts autosave when it happens, so manual saving helps to not risk losing progress.

The storyline and some of the characters did feel a bit hollow at a couple of places, but all in all quite a coherent and well paced arch to play through. Very enjoyable experience overall!

38628578.review:
Hello and welcome to my first Review!

It was a littlebit nostalgia which brought me to this game but I have to admit, as I started playing it I didn't want to stop until I managed to play through. 

The game is an adventure as you like it. The graphics are "oldschool" but it just positively adds to the overall impression.
I love the graphics, they remind me of the countless hours playing with Guybrush Threepwood in Monkey Island or running around as Indiana Jones trying to save the world.

The story is well thought through and the riddles are challenging. 
I especially liked the way my journal kept changing so that I could have a break in between my gaming sessions and didn't have to start over again. 
The score is decent and keeps to the atmosphere of the game without breaking it. 

The main character is very likeable. She is a tough woman, but she is not a saint (her roomamte is something else entirely). She smokes, rides a motorcycle and knows how to stand her woman. 
I liked the character very much and the unfolding of her past and her development through the game was as much a hook for me as the story itself.

If you aske me, the game is worth every Dollar, or Euro, given the fact that it only costs about 15 Euros (or the respective amount of Dollars) 

Thanks a bunch!

38441992.review:
Kathy Rain es una aventura gráfica point and click que bebe de grandes títulos, como los de LucasArts, publicados en la década de los 90.

Cuenta con un apartado gráfico muy cuidado, todos los elementos están muy bien integrados y crean una atmósfera especial. La historia y el guión cumplen con creces, te mantienen pegado a la pantalla esperando saber qué ha ocurrido.

Los puzzles en general no resultan excesivamente complejos en su mayoría, pero sí presentan un reto que acaba por otorgar gran satisfacción al encontrar la solución.

Mención especial para el apartado sonoro, en particular las voces. Geniales interpretaciones que ayudan aún más si cabe a meterte en el mundo que narra este magnífico juego. Tan solo una pega, no está disponible en español, así que mejor que conozcas la lengua de Shakespeare para disfrutar de ellas. Eso sí, el juego ya cuenta con subtítulos en castellano.

En resumen, una gran aventura de la que esperamos nuevas noticias de su protagonista en forma de secuela.

THIS is what point & click should be! However, I have to disagree with the Captain Kangaroo comment, 'relevant'. This is more of how teenagers of this decade speak, not in the '90s. 

I appreciate how you can click and they'll just continue on with their next line, animation is great story is great so far. Atmosphere is good, a lot really captures that '90s feel. I however have a few (perhaps unconventional) quirks:

1.) Controller support.
   - Now I know, it's a point-and-click, but simply mapping ESC to start, cursor to a thumbstick, left-click to 'A', right-click to 'X' goes a long way.

2.) Fixed aspect ratio
   - I know a lot of people don't agree with this, but to have the option would be great to me. I use an HTPC on a 60 inch so cropped screens just don't work for me. I think games look just as great stretched to the edge of the screen. Hell, I used to record television to VHS tapes, a little quality downgrade wouldn't be all that bad. 'As long as it works', as they say.

3.) Launching game in Direct Draw mode does not allow for achievements pop up window. They register sometimes but you have no idea they happened. 
   - Edit: They're still not registering in Direct3D mode. I don't know what's going on here.

4.) Better walking animations
   - Kathy looks too much like a cardbord cutout while walking.

5.) A recap option. I have started the game up and quit quickly because I don't know where I'm at.

6.) Her butt's too big!! ..But I guess it's a little too much to ask to make it smaller.

One thing that bothers me about the beginning of the game is she goes to bed drunk, wakes up and doesn't bother showering or even brushing her teeth. Come on now!

38294523.review:
Point and click adventure game starring edgy biker girl protagonist in the 90s, though the time period mostly seems to be exploited for puzzle purposes.  Pretty similar to the stuff Wadjet Eye puts out, perhaps in the same engine.

There's some clever and different puzzles in this one.  Almost too clever at a few points, though the game is pretty good about guessing your train of thought and putting you on the right track if you overthink things.  The story is split into days and old areas are blocked off, so you don't waste much time wandering.  The voice acting is also very good.

The UI is a little more cumbersome than necessary, as you have to left click and then click again to select the action you want to perform on any interactables.  For some reason, "Examine" and "Think About" are two different options, so it's not just as simple as Right Click:Examine, Left Click:Interact.  The story also kind of spirals out of control near the end which may disappoint some people who got hooked on the initial detective premise.

Around 5 hours long, decent grab on sale.  The intro is pretty eyeroll but Kathy becomes more tolerable afterward.

38179629.review:
Wow Kathy Rain is freaking phenomenal. What starts out as a young woman trying to learn what happened to her Grandfather, upon hearing of his passing, turns into something more sinister and bizarre. A great whirlwind adventure with twists and turns at every end, a true detective story/game for the ages. 
The story is compelling and gripping and you cannot put it down. You find yourself fully immersed in the game wanting to find out anything and everything you can. There's much to do in this simple point & click game with a bunch of colorful characters to boot. 

If you really do enjoy a rich story with really great voice acting and puzzle solving you should really pick up Kathy Rain. You won't be disapointed playing as this tough as nails, wise-cracking, smart-mouth young woman. Follow the clues, learn everyone's secret and uncover a hidden past.

Pros: ACHIEVEMENTS!! Great storyline and plot, comical, strange yet intriguing characters, great set of items you pick up for your inventory to use on almost anything or anyone. Very helpful with hints on what to do next. At least 10hrs of gameplay.

Cons: THERE'S NO SEQUEL! DX At least not yet. Hopefully one day. 

100/100 :D

38151273.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Esta reseña no contiene spoilers[/h1]

¿Tienes dudas sobre si deberías adquirir este juego? ¿Te gustan las aventuras gráficas pero no estás seguro/a si este título te puede llegar a gustar u ofrecerte horas de entretenimiento? Bueno, sigue leyendo y saldrás de dudas en un momento:

Podríamos decir que Kathy Rain es una aventura gráfica notable, con grandes particularidades que en cierto modo la hacen única en ciertos aspectos. No hablo por hablar, he encontrado puzles bastantes originales que no había encontrado en otras aventuras graficas, y he jugado a cientos de ellas.

Lo primero que debes saber es que este juego tiene toda la esencia de los clásicos de los años 90, y muy particularmente a mi me recordó a dos títulos imprescindibles: Laura Bow y la Daga de Amon Ra, y Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father. No es debido a que el argumento sea similar a estos juegos, sino por la esencia de los mismos. 

Por un lado me recordó a Laura Bow por el papel de investigadora de la protagonista, recabando pruebas e investigando su entorno mientras todo se volvía más enrevesado a cada paso que daba. La fuerte personalidad de la protagonista y su modo de afrontar los acontecimientos es algo a destacar como muy positivo.

Por otro lado, me recordó a Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father por ese halo de misterio que embarga la aventura desde el primer momento. Misterio que te llevará de la mano y no te soltará hasta que no veas los créditos finales. Sin duda, eso no es fácil de lograr, y Kathy Rain lo consigue con una aparente facilidad y naturalidad encantadora.

Si eres fan de este tipo de aventuras, Kathy Rain te encantará. Eso seguro. Tanto los personajes, como las situaciones que va viviendo la protagonista, el argumento que va deshilachándose de su madeja de misterio, o los maravillosos gráficos estilo pixel art, son un auténtico canto y tributo a la época dorada de las aventuras gráficas.

Porque lo mejor de todo es que no tienes la sensación de estar jugando a una aventura de 2016 que tiene aspecto gráfico de los 90. La sensación que tienes es que estás jugando a una gran aventura gráfica de los 90. Punto.

No quiero contarte demasiado sobre el argumento para que lo disfrutes como se merece. Tan solo mencionar que la aventura se sitúa en los años 90 y que tomarás el papel de Kathy Rain, una estudiante universitaria de periodismo de 2º curso, que marcha a un pueblo perdido de EEUU para asistir al funeral de su abuelo, el cual a partir de un momento determinado sufrió un ataque que lo dejó en estado casi vegetativo al volver de un paseo por los bosques que rodeaban la zona. A partir de ahí, nuestra protagonista comenzará a investigar qué sucedió, y para ello deberá remover el pasado de su abuelo, y el suyo propio.

El juego solo cuenta con un pequeño inconveniente, y es que no está en español a día de realizar este análisis, pero según parece saldrá una traducción al español antes de acabar el año. Así que si no eres una persona con demasiado nivel de inglés, pronto podrás disfrutar de esta gran aventura en nuestro idioma y ya no habrá ningún impedimento.

Como tal el nivel de inglés no es para nada complejo, pero sí hay ciertos puzles directamente relacionados con el idioma. Así que si no controlas esta lengua, sí que podrás encontrar algunas dificultades a la hora de resolverlos.

Y hablando de puzles, decir que el juego no es para nada difícil, no presenta de manera general puzles enrevesados o ilógicos, y si habitualmente juegas aventuras gráficas, prácticamente irás avanzando por la historia sin mayores dificultades. Aunque si es cierto que en determinados momentos hay puzles de encontrar códigos o similares que pueden presentar un reto bastante significativo. Lo cual es muy bueno, y además son bastante imaginativos.

Otra de las cosas que me ha impresionado, ha sido su doblaje. Es realmente bueno. Las voces son de una gran calidad y encajan perfectamente con todos y cada uno de los personajes. En este aspecto, el juego es de diez.

La música por otra parte, es bastante agradable, y se ajusta perfectamente a cada situación. Aunque no es algo que recordarás en el tiempo, cumple con gran soltura su papel.

Particularmente me ha parecido una gran experiencia, y no solo diría que "ha nacido una nueva detective" como reza el título, sino que ha nacido una empresa desarrolladora que sabe hacer su trabajo y ha captado a la perfección cómo deben ser las aventuras gráficas y el camino que debe seguirse para ofrecer títulos con gran calidad. Un diez para ellos por el trabajo realizado.

Pues con esto finaliza este analisis, espero que después de haberte leído estás líneas tengas claro si este título es o no es lo que estabas buscando. :)

38112169.review:
Picked it up as part of a bundle. Easily the best of the bunch. 

Funky 90s-era LucasArts graphics. Great pacing, characters and voice acting. Long enough to feel good value for what I paid, short enough not to outstay its welcome. Sadly, though the puzzles and plot start well, they both run out of steam about halfway through. Still heartily recommended

38094361.review:
Kathy Rain is an entertaining point-and-click adventure game in the style of Lucasarts and Sierra classics. The game is very well produced: the voice acting and dialogue stand out in particular, which really helps the player connect with the main character. It really has the look and feel of a mid-nineties product, which I imagine is what the developers intend.

The puzzles are fun - they never feel arbitrary and all the solutions obey the game's internal logic so there's always a good sense of reward on completion. However, for a seasoned veteran of old-school adventure games, they never really get too far into headscratcher territory, and some of them seem a little too easy. Sometimes this is because the character will drop hints during her narration. This does stop the puzzles from being unduly frustrating, but it does also mean you will solve them a lot quicker than you otherwise might. Part of the fun of the old classics were the gordion knots you had to unpick over a few days (or weeks). There aren't really any complex puzzle chains of the sort you'd find in Lucasarts classics either.

This does keep the story moving though, and here the game is fairly strong too. Without giving away any spoilers, Kathy Rain keeps just on the right side of cliche and touches some very adult themes. The atmosphere is more often one of unease and tension, rather than horror, and it does this well. That said, I did feel there were a few elements of the story that could have benefited from a deeper telling - and a longer game.

Kathy Rain should appeal to fans of adventure games and is a worthy addition to a point-and-click collection. It's a little too easy, and perhaps therefore a little too short, but what it does it does well.

37941417.review:
I recommend purchasing this game when it's on sale, as the full-price of $15 doesn't quite justify the quality of this game.

The first half is enjoyable and plays out as standard detective plot.  Kathy Rain sets out to solve the cause of her grandpa's mysterious death, and interacts with the quirky inhabitants of the small town along the way; including a drunk bum, two incompetent police officers, and her straight-laced dorm-mate.  Kathy delivers excellent voice-acting as she provides commentary on a number of interactive objects within the game.  The puzzles are challenging, and I especially like how the game removes items and locations when they're no longer needed. 

Without spoiling too much... I feel ambivalent about the second half of the game.  I respect what the creators were trying to achieve, but felt that the latter half was poorly handled and hastily put together.  It certainly leaves more questions than answers.  

Overall, there are certainly better games of this genre, but give this one a try if you're running out of things to play.

37879637.review: Low-res adventure games always bring about a feeling of nostalgia for me. Despite the blocky graphics, Kathy Rain is not an old-fashioned game though. The interface works well; the graphics, despite being low-res, look nicely colourful and detailed; and the sound and voice acting are very good indeed. Although the number of locations you can visit is limited, it doesn't feel overly confined and the puzzles you get to solve make sense, with no great leaps of moon-logic. The backstory is interesting and I quite like it, even though the ending does get a bit trippy. Several people have mentioned that the ending ruined the game for them, but I don't agree. While that was possibly the weakest part of the game, it did all fit together and I enjoyed playing through all of it.

37370323.review:
In a world so full of wimpy whiney gutless main characters, crapping their diapers at the mere sight of their own trembling shadows, shadows so sick, that their owners collapse into a quivering, sobbing pathetic mess, faster than a teenager in Kevin Spacey's bedroom, that they decide to stop casting any at all. 
In a world where main protagonists hide inside the closest locker instead of facing danger, you have Kathy Rain who won't hesitate a second before kicking you in the nuts and tazing your ass for giving her an akward eye.
That said, Kathy Rain is an interesting game that will keep you interested, invested, might cause headaches but using one's brain is what keep one's mind sharp.
The sounds, musics, voice acting are all on point.
Graphics are ok, animations could use some improvements.

The characters you meet...well:
-Evil priest?....check
-Sweet and benevolent Aunt May style old person?....check
-Nerdy roommate that ends up proving herself helpful?...check
-Bastard Rambo1 style sheriff giving you s***?....check

Anyway if you shrugg that off, you get an appealing game with certain depth to it as you unravel mysteries.
The game takes a weird turn at a certain point that you may or may not appreciate, can't say more without spoiling...
I know I didn't mind, it's the author's will, I respect it.

I can give this game a 8 out of 10 without hesitation. You will not forget the name Kathy Rain anytime soon.
