36673435.review:
One of my all time favourite games

Unlike a lot of point and click games, Kathy Rain does not fall into the usual pitfalls of attempting to add complexity with increasingly absurd puzzles like making an octopus molest a man for his belt buckle. The puzzles all make sense, and when you do figure it out (or give up and check the walkthrough which is always an option) there is no "how the fuck was I supposed to figure that out?!" instead you smack yourself on the forehead and call yourself an idiot

The writing was interesting, and I loved Kathy's remarks when I did something (or got frustrated cause I was being stupid and just tried to set fire to stuff). The thinking aspect was also incredibly helpful, pointing me in the right direction. 

HOWEVER, I did have at least 2 points during the game where I just had to go through every location until an event triggered and I could move on with the plot. This was incredibly irritating, and I'm not certain if I missed a clue or not, but I don't see how I could have missed that prompt

The voice acting is stellar, and I give every voice actor a solo round of applause for how well they all did. Everybody had character and delivered their lines with clear intent and emotion. Nobody half assed their performance and it only added to the good base quality of the game

The background are lovely, especially during the last chapter. There is a lot of detail, but it doesn't overshadow the characters, the characters who are so damn detailed and awesome. So much attention and care has been put into every model, about how they look and move, and the short animations that add to every scene

The ending was a touch abrupt however, it could have done with being lengthened a little bit more, not a huge amount, but just to smooth it out a bit and make it feel a little bit more natural

Also Eileen and Kathy make a hella cute couple. If you continue this (which I sincerely hope you do), make it gay pls

36304476.review: I really liked this game.  The biting humor of Kathy was great, and it was her "devil may care" attitude towards everything that shaped so much of the feel of the game. Kathy is a college student, living in a dorm somewhat close enough to Conwell Springs. However, she has not gone "home" to her grandparents house for years. I would definitely recommend Kathy Rain as your dose of strong female protagonist (with some bark and some bite) when you're looking for it.

36000006.review:
WARNING - SPOILERS AHEAD!



I really wanted to like this game, right until its last thirty minutes or so - nice art, nice voice actors, puzzles aren't very obnoxious, but... It's the kind of game in which you're there for the plot and story, and unfortunately the game relies too much in some weird horror tropes, using a lot of obsfuscation to try to hide the fact that there isn't too much to see here, honestly. Do you remember how, after Lost became the new hot thing on TV, a lot of shows sorta tried copying its thing of seven-layered mysteries the audience was supposed to try to figure out, but it was all smoke and mirrors to hide the fact that the writers and producers themselves were lost (pun not intended) on what their show was about? Hell, do you remember watching Lost's finale and figuring out its producers and writers didn't figure out what their show should be about? That's how I feel about Kathy Rain's ending, with the caveat/relief that I spent five hours of my life instead of six years. To use an in-game image, it's a 2-d image of a sinkhole trying very hard to trick you into thinking it has a lot of depth when it's in fact paper-thin. Oh, and it also uses abortion as a plot device in a REALLY tropey, really gross way. 4/10, worst Wadjet Eye game I've played so far, certainly nothing on the level of Blackwell or Gemini Rue.

35635807.review: Nostalgic kind of adventure game. Not overly complex but scores plenty of points for great voice acting, solid plot and a good game flow. All the pieces are finely tuned so you never feel like you are back tracking searching for the right pixel. Logic solves most things and areas are blocked off once there is nothing left to do in them allowing you to focus on the next move required. 35425438.review: Good oldschool point and click adventure game with a really nice voice acting.

35366142.review:
Ultimately I recommend this game, but it's a bit of a lukewarm recommendation. I appreciate the nostalgia, as I was a teenager in 1995 (when the game is set) and I played a lot of games back then that employed the same pixelated style Kathy Rain does. I love a good point and click as well, and this game did entertain me. However, I felt that much like Oxenfree, Kathy Rain leads up to a conclusion that's just not much of a conclusion. 

For example, I spent the entire game very suspicious of Kathy's grandparents. Her grandmother just seemed too sweet, and at one point you hear a phone message from Kathy's mom about how they're sick people and they need to stay away. Maybe, I thought, that indicated a second story taking place underneath the more obvious narrative, Maybe we would glean something from Kathy's mother, or find a clue that would alert us to the fact that something shady was going on. Indeed in the last act when she meets her grandfather in her hallucination, the picture of him on the wall keeps turning to a corpse's grinning face. 

But no. Everything is exactly as it seems, and things like Kathy being pissed at her dad and forced to commit her mom are just there to appear for like half a second in the final act. Also the pixelated nature of the game, while charming, does make certain scenes that are meant to be poignant or horrifying seem comical. I mean, can you really take a hanging seriously when it's in pixels? How about an aborted child holding DNC equipment to his neck? Some characters you've come to care for never appear again after a certain point, either. Where the hell is Sue, in the last couple of chapters? I had come to care about her, and yet I never saw her again for no discernable reason. 

Also, the puzzles are at once too restrictive, and too difficult. There is a point in one of the chapters where you have to get a washed up bum to act out a scene for the nurse on duty at the local clinic. You're then supposed to come up behind him and shock him with the taser, so you can pass it off as a seizure and get the nurse to leave her post. Who the hell thinks of doing something like that? Not me, apparently, since I had to go for a guide over that one. The easier puzzles sometimes have a lot of hand holding (Kathy can't ask about or show certain things at many points in the story) and yet the difficult ones have almost none. 

That said I think the voice acting was generally good, though the grandmother does approach chewing scenery once or twice. It's fun and it did draw me in for the duration. So pick it up, but don't expect a lot of depth or resolution.

35249694.review:
I kept comparing Kathy to Rosa from the Blackwell series -- another female protagonist in her twenties, also a journalist, who investigates supernatural stuff and has a family member in a psychiatric hospital -- and I couldn't help but constantly think about how much I prefer Rosa to Kathy. It's not necessarily about the characters' different personalities, but more about the way in which the player can choose their dialogue. If I want Rosa to be sassy, I can make her say sassy things. If I want her to be mean, I can make her say mean things. If I want her to be kind, I can do that too: Rosa is a more more well-rounded character. Kathy felt more flat in comparison. 
Kathy can be unnecessary brutal towards people. Sometimes you can choose between being nice and being savage, however, there are many times that you'll get a dialogue "choice", but all the choices are the same. (For example: when [spoiler]Lenny asks Kathy out[/spoiler], not only does the player not have the option to accept, but all of Kathy's rejections are mean as well.) Why do I have to be mean all the time? I wanna be able to choose which characters to be mean to according to my likes and dislikes. Having the ability to choose makes me feel more connected to the player character.

I'm not saying I wanted more choice-and-consequence or a branching narrative in conjunction with my choices. Going back to the Blackwell series: none of Rosa's answers in those situations will change the way NPCs behave towards the player character. But they did change how I felt towards Rosa, made me feel closer to her. These choices are not about furthering the narrative, but about conveying different emotions.

Look, I don't know how to end this rant. I literally just finished the game half an hour ago. I'll have to think about it a bit more and come back to this.
Suffice it to say: I liked the game, but I wish it were a bit... more. Maybe in the next installment. eh?


Other thoughts: 
- The visuals are stunning. Clearly the best part about this game.
- The voice acting is pretty good; however, some VAs clearly have not had a lot of training/experience when it comes to unnecessary mouth noises (lip smacking and such), which I found pretty distracting. Especially when it comes to the priest, cause he talks a lot, and I don't need to hear his saliva, thank you very much.
- Sometimes has a case of the Adventure Game Logic when it comes to puzzles. Like, how come the guy I tazered talked to me cordially when I bumped into him again later? Why is he not scared of me now? Wtf, man.

As you progress through the game, you do encounter odd puzzles. I finally hit one where I had to read a playthrough like five times to get WHY what I did was the answer, even after I already knew the answer. Very frustrating. In all, I'd say 2/3 of the game were good, and the last third just flattened out like a punctured tire. Kinda ruined what came before.

35195473.review:
Kathy Rain is awesome. 9.9 out of 10!

If you’ve loved Seirra or any point-and-click adventure games, you’ll love this game. The comparisons to Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father are unavoidable, and both excel at different aspects. 

Overall, the characters are better and the story is much more “human”. The “mystery” and supernatural elements aren’t quite as good, though; GK was about Voodoo and had lots of freaky, unnerving experiences (the nightmares, the symbolism, the professor incident, the man outside the window, the burial wheel, etc.). KR’s supernatural elements are a peculiar blend of Christianity and Paganism, and the antagonists are comparatively drab. The more human dramatics are much more compelling, though, and that's where KR excels. 

Excluding the antagonists (Malia and Tetelo are more interesting antagonists than their KR counterparts), every other character is on par or more interesting. Gabriel Knight is a standard hero plus witty and lascivious plus Southern accent, but not much else, while Kathy Rain is similarly witty and fun, but also deeply wounded in real ways. E is comparable to Grace in being the research assistant, but Grace is too much of a Mary Sue. KR’s grandmother is more emotionally complex as well, where as GK’s grandmother was solely generic sweetness tinged with sadness.  

Strangely, there don’t appear to be any failures. Far as I can tell, it’s impossible to die or progress in a way that makes the game unwinnable (for better or worse). The worst that can happen is that you might be temporarily stalled before figuring something out, which only seems possible if completely not paying attention. This isn't overtly obvious until the end, but it does take some tension out of the game. A few times I tried to induce a failure condition only to find Kathy wouldn’t do it. 

Like any similar games, there’s going to be a few puzzles that are absolute fuckery. This game has two; the audio editing portion and the safe/mausoleum. Both are doable, but tedious enough to ruin the flow of the story; might as well look up the walkthrough for just those two incidents and you won’t lose anything. The rest of the time, Kathy is dropping almost too many hints; makes for a shorter game experience, and the occasional feeling of the game just telling you what to do. 

Highly recommended.

35038205.review:
It looks like a top-tier Wadjet Eye game, and lo and behold, it's every bit as good as one.  

[i]Kathy Rain[/i] is a very well thought-out supernatural mystery set in a small town in the Pacific Northwest.  It starts out, of course, like an ordinary mystery, with the heroine following threads that are surprisingly logical and believable in the course of investigating her grandfather's odd death -- but then things start to get spectral and culty in the classiest of ways.  The tone of the adventure is predominately serious, but Kathy can't help but engage in a few cheeky high jinks of the sort that are hardwired into every point-and-click protagonist's DNA.  Personally, if I don't get to do a little Threepwoodish trollery in an adventure, something just feels [i]off[/i].

If you are skittish about episodic games, know that this is not one, whatever the title suggests.  It's an awesome, self-contained adventure that [i]might[/i] get a well-deserved sequel, more than worth the time of any genre fan.

35034069.review: A very good point-n-click puzzle game. With a nice story, beautiful art and complete voice acting.

35032189.review:
A great point and click adventure game that gets so much right.

Taking the role of Kathy Rain, a 20-something journalism student, you come back home for your grandfather's funeral and begin an investigation into his misterious illness. What follows is the typical point & click process of investigating locations, talking to everyone, picking up items, and solving puzzles. What sets Kathy Rain apart is the pretty pixel art, interesting story, solid writing, good voice acting, and intelligent puzzles that naturally lead into the next.

The pixel art is very well done, particularly given the AGS engine's 320x240 resolution. My favorite part, and a very pleasant surprise, is that the far more detailed character portraits change to reflect the people's emotions. Characters will smile, or smirk, or frown, or roll their eyes during conversations, and it really serves to bring already detailed characters to life. The good voice acting helps a lot with that as well.

The story was slow to get started, but interesting, and had me guessing as to where it was going and what was going to happen next. The characters were likewise interesting. The protagonist, Kathy Rain, was particularly enjoyable to play as, with tons of personality - I loved her comments, observations, and dialog choices. The writing was good, and ranged competantly from funny to sad. This is one of the few games that made me laugh, and I laughed often due to the sharp and witty writing.

The puzzles are logical, and well connected, such that the solution to one puzzle intelligently leads you to the next. The game helps keep you on track with notes / conversation topics in your notebook, and by keeping the inventory largely limited to useful items and greying out locations that you are finished with. There's no pixel hunting due to being able to highlight objects of interest, and there's a clever "Think about" function that serves to both provide backstory and hints as to what the item might be used for. The puzzles are pleasantly on the easy side, though there is a noticeble difficulty spike about 75% of the way through.

I did get stuck three times, about 75-80% of the way through where the difficulty spiked. One code puzzle I just needed a hint for, one I missed that an object had a gained new interaction ability that it didn't previously have, and the third was a poem / riddle that were so vague as to leave me completely stumped and reaching for a walkthrough.

I also encountered some initial technical issues due to the AGS engine. It failed to start when set to automatic resolution as it tried a resolution that was way too big. When manually setting the resolution, fullscreen would stretch the game out even though I had black bars enabled in the launcher. I had to set the game to run in a window to finally make it work.

Overall, Kathy Rain is a great point and click adventure game, one of the best I played. I highly recommend it to adventure game fans.

Alas, point-and-clicks live and die by their story and protagonist, and the game is not that good in either department. The events are clearly intended to touch her deeply, even challenge her very identity, and yet she seems to be entirely unchanged after the denouement. 34466731.review:
I finished this game recently and thought I'd write a review.  I'd happily recommend it for fans of 90s style point-and-click adventures but it probably isn't amazing enough to win over new fans to the genre.  Overall I'd give it about 7 out of 10.

Starting out the game seemed like it was aimed at a younger audience than I expected although towards the end it got much darker and quite surreal.  In hindsight it felt like it was heavily inspired by Twin Peaks and fans of that series would especially appreciate this title.

The game wasn't espcially long or difficult, it took me about 8 hours to get all achievements.  The gameplay was fairly logical - reasonably challenging without being too frustrating (apart from one incident where it turned out you needed to discover a magic computer peripheral could do something quite unexpected in order to progress).  The graphics were effective within their artificially dated limitations - although rather nostalgic some people might well question the overall design aesthetic.

That said though - there was plenty of nice voice acting with dialogue options to explore for the full story, as well as plenty of secrets and extra achievements throughout the game to pad it out somewhat.  And I'd personally be enthusiastic about another Kathy Rain title!

34420536.review:
[b]“Whatever is rejected from the self, appears in the world as an event.” - C.G. Jung[/b]

As Clifftop Games' first project, [i]Kathy Rains[/i] is an intriguing work, which carries much promise for a future series, with invaluable psychoanalytical depth. When I picked this game, two things shined out as brilliant references: the 90s atmosphere displayed with the same engine used in [i]Blackwell[/i] series - another masterpiece of the adventure genre - and Dave Gilbert's name on voice direction department for the game, the creator of Rosa Blackwell himself. So it would be fair to assume Kathy would be an unexpected successor for Rosa. After I've completed the game, I sensed a completely different direction, yet I am much pleased with the outcome anyhow. Where [i]Blackwell[/i] was paranormal, [i]Kathy Rain[/i] could be described as psychoanalytical. Here, paranormal is a cosmetic layer rather than being context specific.

Kathy is a rebellious, snarky biker girl and an aspiring journalist major with a truckload of traumas, mainly concerning her family. Her good girl dorm mate Eileen brings into her attention that a certain "Joseph Rain" just passed away and whether he may be related to Kathy or not. He sure was - no other than Kathy's grandfather to be precise. Taking the news, Kathy takes off to attend the funeral, which opens a gate to her troubled past at the same time. As she investigates the recent demise and prior ailment of her grandfather which left him confided to a wheelchair, Kathy comes in contact with an uncanny mystery engulfing each and every corner of the silent, sleepy town of Conwell.

The storyline begins as an interesting enough detective mystery, yet quickly deviates from that context to take a seemingly supernatural path. Yet, under the layer of the supernatural, the game is - in my humble opinion - is a brilliant example for a psychoanalytical concept: the self and the shadow. According to Jungian psychology, every person bears an archetypal unconscious aspect that would be instinctual, illogical and wrapped in darkness; a mirroring opposite to our light, our self and the consciousness. This part is completely speculative on my behalf, and may contain spoilers, so feel free to skip to the next paragraph. [spoiler]Kathy's journey and her experiences throughout the game, are majorly symbolic acts of self-confrontation. The fictional red scythe flowers serve as hallucinogens which may be used for many psychedelic experiences of transcendence or self-discovery journeys - which explains most of Kathy's "supernatural" experiences. Thus, her main antagonist is herself all along, and all other figures are the ones that try to take similar journeys like her, yet failing to make peace with their own shadows. The antagonistic "Crimson One" is the personification for the hallucinogen flower itself. We already know that both Kathy's parents were somewhat into the consumption of the same drug also. Other characters involved, and their experiences may be explained in a similar manner. Yet, these are all my own speculations and interpretations. In the end, Kathy faces all her demons - her father's departure, her mother's insanity and her guilt driven from committing her into an asylum, the abortion, even not being able to be a part of her grandfather's life - and prevails. Thus, she leaves the hole and destroys the source of these symbolic drugs, preventing anyone who wouldn't be willful enough to face their own demons coming into harm.[/spoiler]

Kathy surely is not the most interesting of protagonists as we start, but as the game progresses, the storyline delivers. There are layers under her seemingly embittered and sarcastic personality, which makes her a realistic, even relatable character. Her relationship with Eileen is especially admirable, since she tries to protect her as if she is trying to protect her own extracted innocence. I regret that other characters were not as fleshed out as I would like, but they all serve their purpose within the plot.

We are familiar with the AGS engine already, and it is spectacular to see that the pixelated texture can present such admirable environment artwork and character designs. The game world itself was somewhat limited and the game time was short here, yet it is a great demonstration for the capabilities of the developer team. Voice acting, is really wondrous, with sincere emotions and character appropriate toning too, but since Dave Gilbert himself was responsible of that department, no less could be expected.

The gameplay? Well, it does not contain the most brilliant of puzzles, and sure has its logical impossibilities - like a scanner capable of copying sound files from cassette tapes, during 90s nonetheless - but I'd say it is quite alright as a whole. If you listen to the narrative itself and remarks made by characters all around, I'd say that you wouldn't have a hard time overall. It would probably take no longer than 5 hours or so to go through a complete playthrough, 6 if you'd go back for the achievements you've missed.

At the end of the day, sure, I'd recommend Kathy Rain but I'd also advise to take a %50 discount. The game is lovely, but it doesn't contain any replay value and quite short of an experience for the full price. I sincerely hope that we'd see a new adventure from Kathy in the future, which may explain various plot details that never see the light of day in this one. Enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

If you're a fan of Twin Peaks, then this might be the game for you. 
If you liked the Blackwell series, this might be for you.

If you're uncomfortable with swearing (not just the f word, but all the way to the c word! GASP!), religious issues, pro-choice issues, and suicide then maybe you should re-think of purchasing. There are subtle triggers here and there.

The puzzles were decent, plot was OK but was a bit disappointed with the cliffhanger at the end. It felt rather.... cheap.
There were creepy moments for sure, and a sub-plot of Kathy's past that explains her anti-social behavior. 

I love PnC games, but sometimes the traveling back and forth drives me crazy. In Kathy Rain, it doesn't happen that much since the puzzles aren't that difficult to solve.

Voice acting was on point and music was good. 

Art style was decent for a pixelated game. 

All in all, this is an OK game. I don't remember how much or when I purchased this but I'm sure it was during a sale so I suggest you do the same. 

I am, however, looking forward to a sequel. It has potential to be a legit series.

Kathy rain is an adventure game (point & click) with retro graphics. I got it from the monthly Humble Bundle, and typically I would not consider buying this type of game.

Overall i found it a very enjoyable game. It feels like reading a short story. It's easy to get through it (there's about 8 hours of gameplay) and it has a happy feeling.

PRO
- Puzzles are not too crazy/or too obscure - something that usually happens in this genre and that I hate. You can solve most of them by yourself. I used some game guides to go faster, but that was laziness more than actual need.
- Well built story. Not cheesy [and there was the risk of having the story becoming much cheesier]

CONS

- The music is probably forgettable, as i don't remember it at all.

34021861.review:
7/10

One of the best point and click adventures I've ever played. The biggest problem with point and clicks of the past is that they contained some puzzles that made no sense either leading you to "try everything on everything" until something sticks or to look up a walkthrough which in turn always screws up the sense of accomplishment one needs to get from these games. Not in Kathy Rain. Perhaps because it is a more modern title the developers have learned from the mistakes of the past and have succeeded in telling a good story with intuitive puzzles that aren't always easy by any means but are always fair as long as you put your mind to it. Thumbs up!

All that being said, there are some concerns, the game is a little short (my playthrough only took 7 hours) which isn't bad value for money but one does get the destinct feeling that the developers ran out of budget not only because of how short it is but because the ending seems a bit ubrupt. There are a few of the puzzles that still cross the line beyond what I'd view as reasonably solveable from deduction, etc. (I'll freely admit to having kept a guide to hand), but the majority of the puzzle scenarios are well-done. There's also a fair amount of focus on investigation through conversations, tying in with the game's "a detective is born" subtitle - I think on balance I prefer more traditional puzzles, but the seeing the variety is a positive. I don't feel that the game quite resolves all of its plot threads in a satisfying way and it starts to rely a little too much on the supernatural towards the end (even if it's clear that it's not wholly real), which is a bit of a shame, but I still enjoyed my time with the game.

33532586.review:
A love letter to the golden age of classic adventure games, Kathy Rain delivers the thrills and chills of this genre most of the time. Its wittiness, style, humor, main characters, dialogues and pacing is exemplary and make Kathy Rain a good game, while the overall story, puzzles and side characters and cliffhanger / episodic nature have a lot of problems, which drags the game down a bit.
 
It all starts with a mystery, when Kathy Rain, a likeably cynical, suspicious young woman that is difficult to connect with others, goes back to her small hometown to witness the burial of her grandfather, who was paralyzed and died under strange circumstances. Kathy decides to put a fedora on and pursue her own investigation into what happened with her grandfather and the hidden history of her hometown.

Made in AGS engine, pixel graphics are highly detailed and made with a lot of care that you’ll regularly stop to enjoy the scenery. It does have a widescreen support, but due to the age of AGS engine, it looks unnaturally stretched out, which might irk some players. The animations are basic; they definitely don’t have the same amount of details as the graphical presentation does. Kathy and her trusty sidekick, Elaine are well-developed and unique characters, both narratively and visually. Kathy is of course the star of the show, with a lot of character layers and quirks, as well as buried secrets that are both the source of her strength and weakness. Kathy’s family that plays a prominent role in the story is also made of likeable individuals with their own traits and shortcomings. And last but not the least: Goober is such a great character that he deserves his own spin-off adventure game. Developers, make it happen :) The banter between these characters is a joy to listen/read and the voice acting is for the most part amazing, with special mentions going to actors of Kathy and Goober. Did I mention we need a Goober adventure game already :D The game is short and holds attentions throughout the entire playthrough and it will take you about 4-6 hours to complete it. And it is another reason to make a Goober adventure!

On the other side, Kathy Rain’s biggest drawback is the lackluster story that builds up until the last 30 minutes and then it ends without answering most of the questions you’ll have during Kathy’s investigation. The supernatural aspect and its lore is not compelling and well-introduced enough to be interesting, and the story just abruptly deflates without any meaningful payoff. If you look at the whole thing metaphorically, you could say that the story is simple and complete, but if you are like me, and you chase for the “the devil lies in the details” aspect, you’ll find the screenplay is just not good enough and self-contained, especially since this was not meant to be an episodic experience that can allow to cut its story to little pieces for future instalments. I am sure an adventure with Goober would solve all this issues, though. Except the first, mausoleum and the last puzzle that are excellent, all other puzzles are quite basic and aren’t fun, especially the hacker puzzle :( but this is not a huge minus since even adventure game legends suffer from this. Let’s make that Goober game already!!

As a game made by a single developer, Kathy Rain turned out to be a good and fun adventure and dev deserves congratulations for it. Some shortcomings with its story prevent Kathy Rain to be a memorable game, but there is a lot of potential for improvement and greatness, if the dev decides to make Kathy Rain 2. But “Goober’s Hollywood exploits” adventure game must come first, naturally :) :) :)

33418012.review:
Lately I've been having pretty long adventure game streak, playing everything from the 90's classics to modern games. At the same time, the third season of Twin Peaks is on and I have suffered some withdrawal symptoms waiting for new episodes. So, a game that combines elements from Lynchian mysteries and classic point-and-click games seemed like a gift from heavens and I definitely wasn't disappointed. This is one of the best written small games I remember playing and that's saying a lot, because I'm a huge consumer of this genre. The voice cast is great, pixel graphics are beautiful and there's just enough music to create the right kind of atmosphere to each scene. If you are used to playing the earlier LucasArts games you might find the puzzles in this game to be relatively easy, but I was positively suprised to find that finally someone might have found a good balance between annoyingly straightforward puzzles (newer Telltale Games...) and stumpers that almost force rookies to google for some hints. In my opinion, even extremely story-driven games should provide at least some challenge.

Only some very minor things to whine about like annoyingly slow walking animations (that you have to watch every single time you arrive or leave a location!) and some pointless loose ends in the narrative. The last part of the game borrows quite heavily from Twin Peaks but for me it felt more like a tribute than a cheap rip-off.

Highly recommended

33409878.review:
This is a really charming game that does a great job in evoking the best parts of Twin Peaks. It has a distinctly 90s retro vibe, surprisingly good voice-acting, and the best parts of the adventure game genre without ever descending into the things that made the genre also obnoxious (walking around the entire map using one item on everything until you finally find the magic combination). Many parts of the story are left unresolved, but I sense that's a combination of two deliberate decisions: the possibility of continuing the story later, and the fact that really complicated mysteries shouldn't just be wrapped up with a little bow on them. If they're that fiendishly intricate, they shouln't be neatly undone.

My chief complaint is just that it is very short. I finished it in about 5 hours, and I walked away wanting more from this game. That being said, I think that shows that it was good enough that it ended with me still on the edge of my seat.

33382274.review:
[h1] Do I need to commit a crime to get your attention to this review? Because I seriously will. [/h1]

Oh man, this game. Where do I even start. 10 hours in, and it was fantastic. I'm not much into point&click adventure games, but i most certainly am into good stories, and this one was plain captivating, much due to the amazing main (and - to a high enough degree - side) characters, marvelous script and outstanding voice acting. 

The plot grips you tight and won't let go until it's all over. And when it is, you feel so connected to Kathy it hurts to leave. Because, in addition to being a highly-likeable, witty, rebellious character packed with some charming and cunning foul language, she has some deep background and progresses as a person enormously along the storyline.

Another point this game nailed is the riddles: they are diverse, they make you think and leave you with a comfy satisfying feeling once solved, and, on top of it, all of them ACTUALLY MAKE SENSE. During the playthrough I could barely even once feel the irritation of being lost or unaware of what to do or where to go at that point.

There is one detail about the plot I feel uncertain of though. It is the fair portion of supernatural being involved into a seemingly-at-first detective story. The further you're in, the more plot swerves off into some eerie and fairly grim as-s s-hit (the darkest moments even reminded me of The Cat Lady, despite the two games being stylistically light years apart).
As long as it contributes to the intrigue, it's not a bad thing per se, but the lack of explanation leaves a mild taste of incompleteness, which, however, fails to spoil the overall satisfaction. Popular belief goes this is to prepare a solid premise for a sequel, which I'll be eagerly looking to.

Overall rating: 1995/1995, would 'electrify' a bum's live performance about a romance with his own bladder with a stun gun again any day anytime.

33375187.review: A decent point-and-click game but it got into a very weird sci-fi-religion plot towards the end. I didn't enjoy the second half of the game and would have preferred a less ambiguous ending.

33303848.review:
You know, when I first booted up the game, I had all these thoughts in my mind about what it could be like. eventually, I settled on it being some sort of blackwell copy. 

And, Well, I must say I was terribly wrong.

Kathy Rain is a very strong game, both in the form of the story, gameplay, and the art, which will captivate you in this 6/7 hour journey, in which you get to know Kathy and get to explore the fascinating story behind her hometown and her grandfather's past, all while giving Kathy enough time to grow as a character.

You might find some similarities to Blackwell, specifically in the art style, the portraits that come up while talking to other people and the whole normal woman turned detective situation, but the story is a very strong story that is not linked to blackwell in any way.

Also, another thing that I must point out is that the game does not include bizarre item combinations, so you can rely mostly on logic.

However, If you did like the Blackwell series, you will most likely enjoy this.

In summary, with a very strong story, a great gameplay pattern compared to other adventure games and a very strong protagonist to support it all, this game is great and I highly suggest it.

33300856.review:
Thank you to the dear friend who gave me this game. Calling this game "A Detective is Born" does not do it justice.

For those who grew up loving LucasArts and those who enjoy the games of WadjetEye, this is a no brainer. I marvel at how refined pixel games are starting to look. When the game goes for pretty....it's really nice. When it wants to be creepy...it is possibly the most disturbing thing I have every seen...and I thought The Last Door was creepy. The game plays as a standard point and click, with easy controls. The soundtrack is very fitting to the game.

Kathy is a strong, irreverant, foul-mouthed, bitter young 20 something year old, and I love her to death. I have seen other anti-heroes who have bad attitutes for the sake of the game, and I HATE that; but Kathy has good reason for being the way she is. Life has happened to her, and it hasn't always been kind. In fact it never really has. Kathy feels like a real person, thanks to the incredible vocal performance. She can be funny, tough as nails, and genuinely concerned. She grows TREMENDOUSLY through the game. I don't want to tell how because of major story spoilers. She is just a well written character who, along with how great the game looks, make this game work.

Kathy is surrounded by some great side characters who give good performances. All round, I really liked the voice acting and the script. Apart from the sci-fi/religion conspiracy gamey plot, the personal relationships between the people of this game felt very genuine. The family drama in this game had me in tears, since it can be extremely relatable. 

This is no point and click for the kiddos, or even the teens for that matter. This game deals in some very serious subject matter: teen suicide, teen abortion, abandonment, and being ostracized from loving familly members. The consequences of these choices are fleshed out, and at times it was hard to sit through. The language is extremely colorful. Kathy has got a mouth on her (lot of f-bombs), but what bothered me was the c**t bomb. That I felt was the writers wanting to be edgy so they gave a bad acting NPC a line with that word. It was only a moment, but it was a moment wasted trying to be edgy, and it stuck with me long enough that I felt I had to write about, so there.

Overall, this game was very enjoyable, in a reflective kind of way. To call it a detective story to me doesn't do it justice. It's more of a "solve a family mystery that is affecting the whole town while dealing with personal demons" kind of game. The ending (which was satisfying) leaves the hint of a sequel, and we better get one!

33298854.review: It's like LucasArts dragged itself out of a moldy sepulchre, and breath life back into 90's styled adventure games. It harkens back to old Sierra Games with it's logic and whacky characters, but it's a fresh game with it's own identity. You play as the protagonist Kathy Rain, who goes back home to Conwell Springs to attend her grandfather's funeral, and figure out why he suffered for most of his life. The best analogy I can give is "Twin Peaks" meets "King's Quest", with a minor bit of humor that would make any Space Quest fan appreciate. Buy this game folks, you'll be happy you did so!

Tras las buenas reseñas generalizadas (y mi gran apego por el género de las aventuras gráficas clásicas) decidí darle una oportunidad.
Si bien no pasará a formar parte de la "Galería de aventuras que me han marcado", la experiencia ha sido mayormente satisfactoria.
Una premisa interesante, que mezcla elementos de diferentes géneros (desde tonos detectivestos a lo Nancy Drew hasta toques de misterio retorcido a lo Silent Hill) con una protagonista que -aunque no es de lo más interesante- resulta bastante simpatica. Voice acting más que decente, puzzles entretenidos y una duración correcta (alrededor de 9 hs. en mi caso).
Pero es justo también nombrar los puntos negativos, comenzando por carecer de una traducción al español. En segunda instancia, ante la mezcla de géneros anterormente mencionado el juego daría la sensación de que por momentos no está del todo seguro de para qué lado quiere encarar. La ambientación noventosa nunca termina de cerrar (podría transcurrir en un tiempo actual y poco cambiaría). Finalmente, aunque puedo aceptar el estilo gráfico que presenta, debo decir que los escenarios en general se sienten muy desprovistos de vida (mucho más que en el caso de algunas las clásicas aventuras a las que remite).

33197684.review:
Good, solid detective game.  Worth your time.

Puzzles are few but reasonably crunchy.  It took a while for me to solve them but I got there in the end.  Easy enough to crack without a walkthrough, hard enough to make you feel smart.  Perfect.

Story and characterization are excellent.  The heroine is likeable enough for player-identification, but has enough of a personality to be memorable on her own, a balance many games fail to strike.  Voice actors range from decent to very good.  The comic relief homeless guy is annoying and overdrawn, but he is the exception that proves the rule of a sympathetic and believable cast.

One nice feature is the game's tendency to clean up after itself.  Once an inventory item or conversation topic has been exhausted, it often disappears.  Some clutter persists to the end game, but it could have been much worse.

Game is about 8 hours, which ran a little long for my taste.  Also, there is no in-game journal keeping track of characters and events.  Play this game all at once, say in 2-3 sessions over a week at the most; otherwise you will risk forgetting important information and the game has no mechanisms to remind you.  I played the game over just 2 weeks and by the end I had to look up the names of people I'd met because there is no record of them.

That's the only downside, though.  Overall this is a solid example of how an adventure and/or detective game should play.  Grab it.

All in all, a fun couple hours. I hope there's more coming.

33146465.review:
A super-dorky mashup of Gabriel Knight and David Lynch -- a combination that is intriguing and absorbing throughout, even as the game lacks some of the heft and sui generis of its two predecessors. I slammed through this game over the course of a single weekend, so obviously I had a great time with it. This would actually be a great game for point-and-click novices, as the puzzles are fairly straightforward and logical (and the almost-too aggressive hint system will no doubt help out as well). I only got stumped once, and that might have been because I missed an important hint somewhere along the way (the forest puzzle, for those curious). I also loved the character of Kathy and hope to see her in another game. 

Anyway, fun game. I'd recommend it, especially at its discounted summer sale price. I'm definitely looking forward to this developer's next game (which looks pretty fab).

33139220.review: I loved this game! Voice acting is perfect, the story is great. Iit's like when you're reading a book and you're so intrigued about what will happen next, who did this, what will happen at the end? I really hope there will be part 2!

33114194.review:
Beginning sumary:
Kathy Rain starts in Kathy's room, with her stalker roommate telling her about someone with "Rain" in the name dying in Kathy's home town. Turns out it was her grandpa. She goes to the funeral and talks with her grandma. She learns that her grandpa was in vegetative state since an accident in 1981 (game's current year is 1995), but something was odd: medical exams showed his brain was totally fine, despite his symptoms of brain damage. Then the game actually starts: Kathy wants to discover what actually happened to her grandpa.

Kathy begins as your standard misfit that smokes, drinks and drives an older-than-her bike that looks like she's part of a biker gang. As the game develops, you see her kind and worried side.

Game mechanics:
It's a pretty standard point and click. You have a bag with items, a notebook with "things you want to talk about with people" and a list of contacts whom you can call to. You can combine items (like a tape and a tape recorder/player to listen to it, or your cigarete with your lighter to smoke), as well as use items on objects (key on door).

Review:
Pros:
- It touches some heavy subjects, like a teenager aborting, suicides, kathy's parents (you'll get it) and some other dark sh*t
- The game hasn't an autoplay mode, meaning you either think about the clues you have until now and do what you have to do or just try everything (which would be exhaustive, don't). Some point & click have too many clues that make the game being all about "Click this place. Now click this. Now this."
- The mystery goes really far and touches religious subjects. I'm a fan of these approachs.
- The MC is actually charismatic and has many fun dialogues and rude answers, including to priests and the sheriff. Oh and she carries a taser.

Cons:
- In a lazy gameplay, I ended the story in 7 hours. That means most of the story and character development is actually made in your mind, not by the game itself. The touches in heavy subjects are mostly shallow due this lack of time.
- Even though it doesn't have clues every freaking moment, the puzzles are pretty easy and the course of actions is rather obvious most of the time. 
- Again, the 7h gameplay doesn't let the game have a great character development. Although you see Kathy growing as the game moves and see her sides, it's too fast.
- (SPOILER OF ONE "PUZZLE") You put a TAPE on a SCANNER to get the audio sound into your computer. That made me go "WTF?" Then Kathy goes on and tells me that putting fire on a wood door that i want to open is not logical. GOSH

Overall:
For the price, it's enjoyable as a casual game. Don't try finding a challenging puzzle-investigative game nor a master piece character development. It's a casual point and click game to spend time. It's worth it with at least 33% off, imo. (77% on summer sale, so 33% should be easy to get during the year)

33086595.review:
A really solid point and click adventure. The graphics, sound, music and voice acting are all top notch. The animation is a bit clunky at times, but that's really just a very minor observation. 

The story progresses nicely, and while the game holds your hand a little bit through the puzzles, I think the developers have walked the line pretty well here in keeping things intuitive and letting you know when you're on the right track. 

One thing the game really nails is tone. I was drawn in from the very beginning and really got a feel for the setting of game and the people who inhabit it. I actually cared about the characters, and they really all did seem quite fleshed out, from the protagonist Kathy to her roommate Eileen, Goober the homeles man and even Hacker Dave, who's only spoken to on the phone. 

Possible spoilers (really just about the feel of the game):
Some people have complained in reviews that the game takes a turn and devolves into "magic/supersition/supernatural" themes, but really the story can be read however you want to read it. The game deals with serious themes from mental illness to drug use and suicide, and any allusions to the supernatural could easily be read as forming some allegory to traumatic struggles in life. 

Overall, this is a great adventure game with strong writing and a real Twin Peaks / Stranger Things / 90s nostalgia vibe. It's pretty short, and can be finished in under 5 hours, but I got it for $4 on sale and it was certainly worth all of that. 

7.5/10

32506466.review:
This is a point-and-click mystery game. We play as Kathy Rain, a slightly stereotypical biker with an attitude and no-nonsense personality, who must figure out the event that unfolded up to her grandfather's death. The puzzles range in difficulty, from pretty easy to slightly out-of-the-box. I wouldn't say any puzzle is especially difficult, but I did find myself stumped for a little while on two or three of them. One puzzle, which should have been easy, was difficult because I didn't pick up the required item earlier in the game... which then lead me to visit every location and try clicking on everything until I found the necessary item (this was a bit tedious). Overall, puzzles aren't difficult. As for the story: it begins reasonable enough but, in my personal opinion, goes off in a direction that I wasn't expecting and (honestly) I wasn't that impressed with. I won't spoil anything, but I imagine the story will be amazing to half the audience and will land flat to the other half. Unfortunately, it felt like the latter to me. I would still recommend the game, however, as I enjoyed the experience of playing Kathy Rain. 

Overall: 7.5/10

To see gameplay and story spoilers, here is my Let's Play of Kathy Rain: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLwZSo_zRz4Slz3KfZgaxL6SAd47UVhXNX

However it had amazing twists and turns that led me astray but... it always came back to the same person I had guessed from the beginning.

Kathy Rain reminded me of my favorite game of all time, Gabriel Knight. This was why I wanted to play it initally, and it didn't disappoint. It is a new point-and-click for a new era and I liked all the quippy one liners Kathy gave when interacting with her environment.
Don't let her sardonic Joan Jet style fool you. Kathy is not just a rock-n-roller, cig smoking, motocycling, punk chick, she is a raven-haired cape cruisader with a deep emotional story that was fun and dreamy to explore and discover. 32143259.review: A unique game with excellent atmosphere and an enjoyable storyline. Some narrative disconnect at times, but compelling characters and often witty dialogue. 4/5 stars.

32069131.review:
So, Kathy Rain. I don't usually write reviews, so this could be a little janky, but bear with me 'cause I think this is worthwhile to say.

--Characters and World

This game shines in characterbuilding. Not a single person (except one who is meant to be) feels out of place or annoying to encounter, and Kathy as a character both suits the position she's found herself in and has a personality you immediately recognize (Jerk with a Heart of Gold). She makes for an excellent protagonist, equally intelligent and witty with a personality that not only shows through her dialogue, but also through the solutions to some of the more impromptu puzzles you face. Rarely does she overstep believable bounds, and even the clues she gives you about objects you find do not come off as patronizing.

In other words, the voice acting and writing is spot-on, just as it needs to be for a story-driven point'n'click puzzler.

Not much needs to be said about the world, as it is for all intents and purposes semi-rural America, before cellphones were invented. Nothing noteworthy is changed, a few things are added (related to the plot), but otherwise it is entirely vanilla and well-represented. 

--Puzzles and Difficulty

Difficulty curve is notoriously hard to judge when it comes to puzzles, and often one individual will find some easier than others regardless of the intent. Despite that, Kathy Rain seems to have taken that a step further with puzzles that are far easier than the one that came before it found late in the game, and the hardest puzzles taking place in the second few hours. Thankfully, Kathy herself will at least let you know if you are on the right track with the harder puzzles, and stays silent when her suggestions aren't solicited. Most solutions (all but one, if I recall correctly) use a 'the easiest answer is the correct answer' policy, and (again, all but one) operate within the bounds of logic- even when reaching an area of the game where logic seems to have no meaning.

Puzzles can invariably be solved just by using the mouse- there is no keyboard usage save for where it makes obvious sense to do so (such as when typing), and even that is extremely rare. If you can't click it, you don't need to worry about it. There is no 'hunt the pixel' gameplay, either- all the items you interact with are well-lampshaded and easy to see, to the point where some of them might as well be draped in neon lights.

Overall, I found Kathy Rain very easy to get through, only having to consult a walkthrough once when I was missing a crucial item. Long-standing lovers of point and clicks will find this a walk in the park, whereas newcomers (are there any?) will find it a wading pool for the harder stuff. Most of these puzzles are character-driven as well, stemming from dialogue choices and showing the personalities and natures of those around Kathy (as well as Kathy herself), making them an integral part of the game rather than 'solve the soup can'-style pointlessness.

---Story and Pacing (no spoilers)

This is the one point where Kathy Rain falls a little short, and it isn't for lack of trying. The story begins excellently and at a medium burn, with the catalyst to adventure occuring soon after you start and with little backstory off the bat. Most of the backstory, in fact, is discovered over the course of the game with notes, dialogue and recorded messages, all of which (save one) is inevitably used in one way or another.

This persists throughout the game's middle in a way that never reaches a white-knuckle grip, but rather a leisurely jog with occasional rests that involve quick humor and fun characters (Goober, I'm looking at you). While there are the occasional twists, they never feel particularly jarring because of the slow speed with which you reach them, lessening their impact and dulling the edge- an edge that I think Kathy Rain sorely needed. Despite that, said twists and developments do grant a desire to keep playing, to remedy the events that go wrong and to wrap up the story. Players are pushed on, also, through small snippets of Kathy's past that she isn't particularly open about, but these have less of an effect both because of the ending and the way they are delivered.

As for the ending, this is where Kathy Rain loses much of its characters and world, instead making it solely about Kathy as a person- and unfortunately proving that she cannot stand on her own as an interesting protagonist. Kathy is at her best when interacting with others, but this last stretch involved only her and her own feelings amidst puzzles that are mostly 'placed' rather than 'organic', and without any of the witty dialogue or charm you find in earlier parts of the game (with a couple notable exceptions). The ending comes and goes, and it left me with a 'well, that happened' feeling that can only be described as mediocre- a sad thing for a game that had me interested and invested up until that point. Despite that, I can say that the more personal details of Kathy's choices earlier in life are handled well and intelligently (at least, on my playthrough. A different dialogue choice may yield a different result), without insulting individuals who have chosen to do the same in her place.

---End result

For a game with a new protagonist never seen before? Not half bad. Not half bad at all. For a point and clicker? Pretty frickin' decent. Is it worth fifteen bucks? That's harder to say. It is a short game, and depending on how quickly you burn through the puzzles at hand you may feel like you did not get your money's worth- especially considering the easy difficulty at hand. So since the puzzles are largely simple, lets judge it on characters and story alone. Would I hand Kathy and E fifteen bucks again, to help fund another investigation?

Fuck yeah, I would.

31830053.review:
First things first...For those that say this is similar to Gabriel Knight......get your fu**ing head examined. There is absolutely no comparison. 

I love adventure games. My father got me hooked on them when I was little....I remember as a kid I would help him (or try to) solve the old sierra games. I feel like a veteran in this genre...with that being said..........

 Kathy Rain does not live up to my personal standards of what I believe an adventure game should be. Its not terrible......but its not good either. Those that have different standards than me will obviously disagree.

One of the main problems is the story and lets be honest, thats what makes or breaks an adventure game. The story feels forced.....like the writers raped the story into this game. As the story progressed I found myself becoming more disappointed than excited. It is supposed to be set in the 90's and other than the story telling me it was 1995. I didn't feel any connection to that decade whatsoever. The protagonist, Kathy Rain, is a cardboard cut out of the classic 90's rebellious edgy teen with a bleeding heart. Kathy didn't feel like a real character but more of a stereotype of what some idiot writer had in mind for the story. 

The story starts off with Kathy coming into her dorm drunk and wanting to sleep it off.  Then Emily, her little stereotypical Christian roommate, tells her she has been doing research on Kathy's hometown because..the writers needed the story to advance and tells her she found out that a man, Joseph Rain had died recently. This is her grandfather and despite being gone for 15 years she decides to attend the funeral and start doing investigations......because the writers needed the story to advance. The games handles story progression this way.... ALL......THE..... FUCK**G..... TIME.....

The puzzles are even worse than the story.....If you are looking for challenging puzzles....Try grabbing a brick and smashing it to your head about 5 times before you play this game. The swelling of your brain might make them more difficult to solve. 

All of the characters in this game are cardboard cutouts of stereotypes. This is why you don't get shitty writers to make your game. 

I won't reveal any spoilers but....the ending didnt answer any questions......fortunatly the story sucked so badly that I didnt care. 

Note: I fell asleep playing this game...so the hours spent on this game can be misleading. The game can be completed in 6-7 hours. (no walkthroughs)

31804768.review: A good classic style point and click adventure game. Quite a creepy/weird story but at the same time compelling. Puzzles are not too difficult but challenging enough to maintain interest.

31790541.review:
This game is pretty short. I'm generally a slow player, and I was able to complete this game in one runthrough over the course of 5 hours. Like a good book, I just couldn't put it down! The fantastic pixel art drew me in, and the plot kept me playing. Kathy suffers a little bit from "edgy grrrrrl" syndrome, but she's still a compelling, likeable character (at least to me). While a few of the plot twists were predictable, others took me completely by surprise.

If you're looking for a game with extremely challenging puzzles, this probably isn't the game for you. With the exception of one of the puzzles in the finale, I found most of the puzzles easy, and I am NOT good at puzzle games. Solving the puzzles still felt very rewarding, though, and most of them weren't tedious or annoying. The only exception is the "computer" portion of the game, which annoyed me solely because of how often I had to switch the computer off, do something else, then turn it on again, rinse and repeat. 

If you're looking for a short game with a good mystery and satisfying puzzles, I highly recommend Kathy Rain.

31682518.review:
Ugh Kathy Rain.  A game that is supposed to be following in the footsteps of Laura Bow, at least I’m pretty sure I read that somewhere.  Like Laura Bow you start out in College as a journalism major, unlike Laura Bow you seem to be a punk biker who is a sociopath.  At the end of the day though I quite liked the character of Kathy Rain and the other major character Eileen.  Their voice acting, what little there is, is good.  Whoever voices Kathy does a good job and the same goes for Eileen.  Since you do hear their voices the most, it’s pretty important for them to be pleasing.  That was one of the big problems with games like Gabriel Knight, Knight’s voice drove me nuts.  It was just awful.  The same goes for Laura Bow.  However, I can’t recommend this game too much is simply bad in it.  

Like that’s probably all the good stuff.  If a lot of stuff was good, I’d recommend the game, but most of it is quite bad.  So lets go with puzzles.  The game basically has very very very easy puzzles.  Which I guess would be fine, except I think they are also bad.  One puzzle required me to pick up a thermometer, which I attempted already pick up earlier in the game and couldn’t.  No dialogue or really anything lead me to think that later in the game I could now pick it up.  It’s the one puzzle I had to look online for a solution to.  Adventure games need to stop this, either let me pick up every single item I need when I see it, or I guess maybe MAYBE if you heavily stress the fact by the character saying something like, “oh I really need to get a thermometer, I think I saw one earlier I need to go back and get it.”  Then that MIGHT be acceptable.  Otherwise, never do this ever!  Almost every puzzle in this game can be solved in the area you are in, normally I would say this is fine, the problem here is that the areas are so small that it takes seconds to figure out puzzles.  That being said I guess I should give props to the game for having all the puzzles basically be logic puzzles as opposed to random math puzzles like a lot of adventure games do and which I hate.

Before getting into the story, I have to just add that one major problem with the game is the length.  It’s a big problem.  There are so few areas to explore.  Each area, might only have one or two screens to it.  You don’t really feel like you are exploring at all, which imo is critical in an adventure game.  The game also simply ends way too fast.  I suppose it’s possible to tell a short story, this game however fails at it.  There wasn’t any real time to get to know characters or have any feel for the town or even really to ponder what is going on in the game.  I’d say it feels more like watching a movie then playing a game, which I know a lot of games do these days, but I don’t like that.

However, the biggest problem is the story and I’m just going to count everything after this as spoilers.  [spoiler] The simple fact is this story makes no sense at all.  First of all I feel like it was a bait and switch.  I bought the game thinking it was going to be an epic murder mystery like a Laura Bow game.  Instead, I guess it’s a horror game? That’s really not the right word for it, it is a mystery, it’s just that the mystery is so terrible I can’t even really call it that.  I would say it’s a very poor version of an HP Lovecraft story.  Yup, that sounds about right.  

So for starters characters act in ways no one ever would.  Kathy is a sophomore in college majoring in journalism.  Her roommate Eileen is super Christian and I guess loves reading obituaries, because the game starts with her finding out that Kathy’s grandfather is dead and demands Kathy attend the funeral.  Even though Kathy hasn’t seen her grandfather in 15 years nor talked to her grandparents she ends up going.  I found it hard enough to believe that your roommate loves reading obituaries and felt it was appropriate to talk to you about it when it certainly felt like at the start of the game that Kathy is super abrasive and doesn’t get along much with Eileen.

Whatever, I got passed that.  Then you get to the funeral though and hear from your grandmother that after a strange incident in the woods your grandfather entered a catatonic state 15 years ago and medical professionals were baffled.  This leads Kathy to “take the case.”  No person would ever act this way, maybe some weird robot would, but no actual human ever.  For one, the incident happened 15 years ago, two no evidence really convinced Kathy this was anything other than a weird medical issue, three she didn’t feel the need to even talk to her grandparents before and now that her grandfather is dead shes going to investigate his medical problems? She literally storms off to the chief of police to interrogate him and then steal evidence to look into this issue? Maybe a sociopath would do this, but even that seems far fetched.

After Kathy learns her grandfather was investigating a woman’s suicide 16 years ago, Kathy seems to decide to investigate that as well? Shes a punk biker sophomore in college, shes a journalism major, but unlike Laura Bow she isn’t studious.  She apparently never attends class, and nothing leads me to suspect shes even a good journalism major, it’s not like she thinks, “oh what a scoop, I’m going to look into this.”  Her chief motivation seems to be guilt that her grandfather died and she didn’t know him so shes going to investigate this for some type of closure.  I just can’t accept that the way she attempts to find closure is to break a variety of laws to investigate what by all appearances is a medical issue. 

There are plenty of ways you could have written this story to work.  How about Kathy is a young detective on the police force in charge of a cold cases unit and is told to look into this girls suicide 16 years ago and through that discovers her grandfather who she was estranged from Kathy also was investigating it and then arrives to speak to her grandfather only to discover he just died?  Or how about Kathy gets a note from her grandmother telling her about how her grandfather was murdered days ago, not years, and Kathy rushes home and is sparked by this to investigate.  See that would make sense, what doesn’t make sense is finding out a medical issue 15 years ago put your grandfather in a catatonic state and you decide to “investigate” it when you have supposedly class the next day and you almost decide not to even bother going to the funeral.

Even then I could look passed allllllll of that if the rest of the story was good, but it’s not!  You can’t build a murder mystery without things like a cast of characters/suspects, dialogue/evidence, suspense, actual mystery.  The mystery is literally resolved in this game before it begins.  You learn people are disappearing a second later you discover the priest in the town is a serial killer murdering people.  I certainly suspected him, because he was literally the only character to really suspect other than either your roommate or your grandmother.  You don’t find much evidence pointing to him, but that doesn’t matter since he just straight up kidnaps and attempts to murder Eileen and you immediately know its him.  

Then there is the whole weird HP lovecraft old God thing, where a weird guy has been I guess taking souls to feed on?  It never really goes anywhere, you defeat his weird puzzle game at the end and burn down his weird old god ceremony seemingly defeating a God and the game ends.  If that sounds abrupt, it’s because it is, you know very little about him. You meet him throughout the game, but again the game is so short you don’t really get any feel for what he’s doing other than being evil [/spoiler]

Sigh, I was really hoping for a new Laura Bow style murder mystery, instead I got a mediocre horror story.  If you want to make a 10-12 hour Kathy Rain murder mystery with Eileen as her partner/girlfriend I would be up for that.  Otherwise…no…just no.

31658463.review: Pleasantly surprised by this title.  You play a young, spunky lady by the name of Kathy Rain.  Kathy was probably my favorite part about the game.  Her voice actress did a great job, and her personality is fun.  It's a classic tale of coming back home to a small town, finding some strange mystery that others are ignoring, and trying to get to the bottom of it.  The game is a point-and-click which I haven't played in quite a while.  It did a great job at feeling retro/nostalgic yet keeping it modern in ways.  I could see others saying that this game is nothing new or not innovative.  But, it doesn't need to, in my opinion.  The story is great.  Almost a Twin Peaks-esque vibe that things are just mysterious enough to keep you engaged.  There are just enough unanswered questions to keep you playing.  The game is somewhat on the short side, but I feel it was a reasonable length.  It didn't overstay its welcome and kept things concise. Definitely recommend for anyone looking for a fun point-and-click game!

31413915.review:
Kathy Rain is a fun adventure point and click with an interesting story.
It was nice to see a cheeky bad-ass female character as the main character and leading us through this story. Its a sort of thriller investagation story line and as the story progressed there were some elements I didnt really enjoy. I wont spoil anything but it didnt go the direction I'd hoped. 
Im not really sure how big a fan I am of point and click games but I enjoyed it. The puzzles were interesting and not too dificult. A small gripe I had was after figuring out a puzzle on my own without any clues, when I had realized what to do the character just said it, "this is what you need to do". For me, it took away from the feeling of accomplishment I had just earned for figuring it out, knowing that you didnt need to use your brain because she just tells you anyway.
Overall its a pretty fun mystery game.

31390779.review:

31382018.review:
Good old fashioned Point N Click adventure, not difficult to proceed (just the once i got stuck!) and subtle hints were available throughout play which gently guided you in the right direction of thinking.

I really enjoyed the characters and the voiceovers were very well done. Even the occasional mature language fitted well within the context of the scenes.

I would imagine around 6-8 hours to complete in a sitting taking your time, I'm slow at 10.5hrs in game and have a habit of reloading "saves" prior to scenes to get the story/characters down.

The only slight downside for me initially was the graphics resolution which I soon forgot about to be honest.

Overall a very solid purchase and would recommend to any point n click adventure buffs. 

A "No-Brainer when on sale", overall i'd say 8.0/10. Solid.

31381514.review:
I want to recommend this game 100% but unfortunately, it has some issues in my opinion. First off, the graphic is really good. The pixel art is nice and full of detail. The protagonist is charming even if she suffers from the I'm-a-woman-hear me-roar and I-don't-need-no-man attitude from time to time. The voice acting is excellent, and so is the music. The music together with the 90s setting sets the atmosphere - Twin Peaks anyone?

The gameplay is also fun. It has the traditional point & click gameplay in which you combine different objects to eventually pass a puzzle and advance the story. It also has this intriguing detective mechanic to the game that is fun. You have to find clues in any way possible, then you use these clues that you have collected to ask other characters about the case. It works well, and most of the time the people you talk to will have something interesting to say about the things you ask about. At times it feels like you are doing true detective work. Though, the game isn't too hard. Most of the puzzles have a logical solution, but it requires you to pay attention to the details.

But... adventure games live and die on their story. The story in Kathy Rain is really good, well, at least 75% of the game. I don't want to go into spoilers here, but right from the start, you get that whatever went down in this small town is not natural. I have no problem with that, it enhances the story since I love that out-of-this-world stuff. The problem comes at the end, or near to it. The game and story have an actual finish, but it feels unsatisfying. As I said, I don't want to spoil anything, but there are way too many loose ends, and nothing about the story is explained. Sure, stuff can be left up to the consumer to draw his conclusions, but there is nothing to draw from here. Stuff just seems to happen at random and then it ends. Disappointing since the road up to that point was great. Maybe, I'm just stupid though, and didn't get it :)

Anyway. I still recommend the game because it's a nice experience, it's just that the story suffers, to me at least. You might not see any faults in it though!

31376517.review:
Kathy Rain is a traditional point-n-click adventure/puzzle game. The game is set in the 90's and it has a genuine nostalgic 90's feel. The story is part detective tale and part surreal horror, and clearly the writers have taken much inspirtation from Twin Peaks. The puzzles in the game are excellent: not only inventory puzzles, but also logic puzzles, words and some number puzzles, lots of variety. Most importantly though the solutions can be found with logic and the balancing is perfect; I never felt lost or needed to hunt down a walkthrough. This is a real quality release, the art, voice acting, music, environments, it's all very well done and detailed. The game has a length of around 6-8 hours, depending on if you get stuck and how much exploration you do.

This is one of the best games I've played in the genre, and I give it extra points for all the 90's and Twin Peaks references. I hope they make a sequel, I'm keen to see more adventures from Kathy Rain. :)

31316849.review: Awesome point and click adventure with a really different and interesting story, 10/10 hope there will be a sequel ! Has a great soundtrack. Warning, I started this in the evening and just played through until the end, I couldn't put it down, had to stop to make breakfast.

31309905.review: Got it in a Humble Bundle - haven't enjoyed a point-n-click this much in years.  Doesn't drag, the puzzles aren't obtuse, and it has a great, fully voice acted story.

31285732.review:
This is a really interesting game. While it falls in comparison to other point and click adventures such as king's quest, this game does have a lot going on for itself

PROS:
- The Music is absolutely incredible. Each main area has its own theme music and each track works so well with the locale.
- The Characters are really well written. Having a main protagonist that you grow to love is really interesting. Some other characters are really interesting and fun to interact with (Goober)
- The story is really fun and exciting. You really don't know what's going to happen next.
- Some of the Achievements in this game are really funny, fitting in with the game's story telling abilities
- Fully voice acted. I don't think there was a single line of dialogue that was written only.
- Multiple Save Files. Really good if you worry about an interaction or forget to do something
CONS:
- The game is a bit short for the price. I bought this game on a sale and felt more justified in the purchase of it. Took me about 5.5 hours to beat the story.
- Some of the voice acting seemed a little off to me. Perhaps the emotion wasn't conveyed as well as it could have been in some instances. BUT ONLY SOME. The rest of the game's voicing is great.

I really had to nitpick to find flaws with this game. A great story, well put together. If the price is a deterrent, just wait for a sale.

31277874.review: Loved the game. If you enjoy LucasArts style adventures then you'll like this. Kind of a cross between Full Throttle and The Dig. Great setting and music. Looking forward to a sequel!

31263273.review: KR is an excellent point-and-click mystery game. If you ever played the Nancy Drew series or the Touch Detective series, this game is for you. The game was the perfect level of spooky without having jump scares, and there was a twist at the end I never anticipated. You'll finish the game in only a few sittings because it's so good. I hope they make a second!

31261224.review:
This is one of the best point-and-click adventure games I have ever played.

GOOD:
- Writing ranges from excellent to brilliant. Pacing is masterful, and the gripping story does not have a weak moment.
- There are some highly original puzzles, and with a single exception I found them all logical and enjoyable.
- Voice acting is top-notch.
- Inventory / clue collecting system is very well implemented.
- Characters are memorable, and especially the main character has exceptional depth.
- Graphics are very good (for this genre).
- I very much enjoyed the Lynchesque mood of this game. Your mileage may vary.

NEUTRAL:
- Sound effects are not spectacular, but help build the athmosphere just fine.
- Music is a bit bland, but does in no way ruin the experience.

BAD:
- Nothing. All aspects of this game are at least solid, and some are exquisite.

If you like this genre, or mysteries in general (and are not put off by a bit darker themes), do get this one.  9,5/10

31223400.review: A really charming point & click detective - mystery adventure game!

8/10

31198638.review:
An enjoyable adventure with a badass heroine and a story that gets gradually weirder and more intriguing... this game had me hooked from the moment I started playing it. It's not a very long game and the puzzles aren't particularly difficult, but I found them enjoyable nonetheless. Not every puzzle was solved by "use object with object", there were some mini riddles that I personally enjoyed solving, and they felt varied too.

Kathy is a great character and I'd love to see more of her in future. She's ballsy, sarcastic, independent, but as you come to learn more about her you see some of whats underneath that too.

The atmosphere of the game was excellent - the art, voice acting and soundtrack really helped convey the feeling of the game. Some of the background music in particular really unnerved me. 

There were some interesting features that I've not seen in point and click adventures much that I think worked well - the "think about" option, to provide some more insight on Kathy's thoughts on things, and the closeup of characters speaking with a few different facial expressions. The method of travelling between locations on Kathy's motorcycle was enjoyable too.

My only complaint about this game was that towards the end I felt like I was just going back and forth between a lot of locations figuring out how to trigger the next event I needed to. With some of the animations it felt a bit slow. Also I felt like it ended a little more abruptly than I'd like, and I would have liked the story to last longer.

All in all I'd love to see a sequel or more from this developer, Kathy Rain was an excellent experience and I enjoyed pretty much every moment.

31175598.review: I picked up Kathy Rain on a 66% discount for $5.09 and at that price I will recommend it and I did enjoy it, I don't think it's worth the original $15 pricetag because the game is just too short and for the most part the puzzle solving is too easy, I completed the game in approximately 5 hours. I just wish the game was longer. more challenging and with less of an abrupt ending.

31141495.review: Enjoyable puzzle adventure with some satisfying puzzles.

31137430.review:
A great game, especially for those of us who fondly remember Monkey Island and other MS-DOS, 320x200 point-and-click adventure games. But this game is not just a trip down memory lane; it offers a real story, with just enough puzzles to solve to make it interesting but not get in the way of the narration.

The negatives? The game is short: I was done with it in 4 hours. The story is great and makes you actually care for the main character, but it doesn't really come to a closure  (what are these lights again!? who are these hair-challenged guys?). This is a tad frustrating; I wish the game was longer.

Will I recommend this game? Absolutely, especially if you can get it for a good price. I would put its money value at $5-10. I look forward for other adventures from this budding (and sometimes foul-mouthed) journalist.
